ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - City commission to hold regular meetings. 
(a)  On the first and third Tuesdays of each month, the city commission will hold a regular meeting, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. Such regular commission meetings shall be held in the city hall at 7:00 p.m. 
(b)  In the month of April where there is a regular municipal election, the city commission will not meet on the first Tuesday of such month but, instead, shall meet on the second Tuesday of April following such regular municipal election at 8:00 p.m. in the city hall as provided by the Charter. 
(Code 1976, § 2-1) 
Charter reference- Meetings of city commission, art. III, § 1. 
Sec. 2-2. - Meetings. 
(a)  Definitions; open meetings; public hearings. 
(1)  Governing body shall mean and be defined for the purpose of interpreting and enforcing this section as the city board of commissioners, board, commission, committee, or any authorized group of persons elected or appointed that serve the interests of the city by official means in a final or advisory capacity. 
(2)  Meetings of the governing body are public meetings unless excepted in accordance with applicable state laws or this section. All matters included herein will further the public's health, safety, and welfare. 
(3)  Public hearings; those affected; public hearing sign in requirement. If a public hearing is listed on a legally posted agenda, a person or entity that received notice from the city on a pending item for consideration, a person that may be positively or adversely affected physically, by use or damage to property, or to any other legally recognizable interest, may be allowed to address the governing body during the public hearing portion of the meeting following registration with the presiding city clerk and prior to the scheduled meeting. A registered speaker during the public hearing may not exceed three minutes when addressing the board. A sign-in form for participation in public a hearing shall be promulgated by the city clerk and be made available at the city clerk's office. The public hearing sign-in form shall include the person or entity's name, address, telephone number, other contact information, organization if applicable, and other notices, authorizations, and acknowledgements as may be allowed by law from time to time. No registered speaker may be allowed to address the governing body once the public hearing has closed. 
(4)  General public participation; sign in requirement; time limit; limitation on speakers. Comments and suggestions by the public are highly valued and encouraged during those parts of a meeting designated for public participation, if any. On each regularly scheduled meeting of the board of commissioners or at such other time as may be designated by the city commission from time to time, a number less than a quorum of commissioners shall be available to the general public for a maximum of 15 minutes after adjournment for public comments with any individual desiring to speak having a limit of three minutes. A person intending on addressing the governing body may speak following registration with the presiding city clerk and prior to the scheduled meeting. The city shall not include public participation during a special called meeting or a workshop session. Persons desiring to speak during public comments shall sign in with the city clerk not earlier than 12:00 p.m. on the day of the scheduled meeting. A registered speaker may speak on several items or topics of public concern; however, a speaker may not exceed three minutes as a whole. A registered speaker may not donate time to another speaker. No more than five registered persons may speak. A sign-in form for general public participation shall be promulgated by the city clerk and be made available at the city clerk's office. The sign-in form shall include the person or entity's name, address, telephone number, other contact information, organization if applicable, and other notices, authorizations, and acknowledgements as may be allowed by law from time to time. No registered speaker may be allowed to address the governing body once the public participation has ended. 
(b)  Procedures. 
(1)  The order of procedure shall follow the order of the agenda; however, the mayor or presiding officer shall have the authority to vary the order of procedure in order to expedite the proceedings, provided that no person shall be denied an opportunity to address the governing body on an agenda item on the day for which the item is scheduled because of a variance to the order of procedure. 
(2)  No person shall address the governing body without first being recognized by the mayor or presiding officer. 
(3)  Any person, either individually or in a representative capacity, shall not address the governing body on an agenda item that is under consideration by the governing body unless recognition is allowed as specified in subsection (b) of this section. 
(4)  The presiding officer or any member of the governing body may make a motion pertaining to the subject matter of such agenda. All motions, authorizations, decisions, and actions, except those requiring a greater number as set out in the Charter or under state law, shall be approved upon a majority vote of the presiding officer and governing body so voting thereon. 
(5)  Any posted meeting of the governing body may be recessed to another time and place for the purposes of consideration and action on any items not acted on during such meeting by the announcement by the presiding officer during such meeting of the time, date and place at which such recessed meeting shall be continued. 
(6)  Each person addressing the governing body shall give his name and address in an audible tone of voice for the record, state the subject he wishes to discuss, state who/whom the person is representing if representing an entity, organization, or other persons. All remarks shall be addressed to the governing body as a whole and not to any member thereof. No person shall be permitted to enter into any discussion, either directly or through a member of the governing body, without the permission of the presiding officer. No question may be asked a member of the governing body, or a member of the city staff, without the permission of the presiding officer. 
(7)  In order to expedite matters and to avoid repetitious presentations, whenever any identifiable group of persons wishes to address the governing body on the same subject matter, it shall be proper for the presiding officer to request that a spokesman be chosen by the group to address the governing body and, in case additional matters are to be presented by any other member of such group, to limit the number of such persons addressing the board. 
(8)  After a motion has been made or a public hearing has been closed, no member of the public shall address the governing body on the matter under consideration without first securing permission to do so by the presiding officer. 
(9)  Any person, business, corporation, or other entity that desires to solicit services to the city shall not use a public hearing agenda item for discussion or consideration of such services. The governing body will consider solicitations only if placed on the agenda and, if applicable, after such legal requirements have been satisfied for the purchasing and contracting of such services. 
(c)  Order and decorum. 
(1)  Board members. While the governing body is in session, the members must observe order and decorum, and a member shall neither, by conversation or otherwise, delay or interrupt the proceedings or the peace of the governing body, nor disturb any member while speaking or refuse to obey the orders of the presiding officer. 
(2)  Employees. Members of the city staff and employees shall observe the same rules of order and decorum as are applicable to the board of commissioners. 
(3)  Persons addressing the board. Any person who willfully utters loud, threatening or abusive language including but not limited to profanities, or engages in any disorderly conduct that may impede, disrupt or disturb the orderly conduct of any meeting, hearing or other proceeding, shall be called to order by the presiding officer or immediately removed. If such conduct continues, the governing body may at its discretion order that any violator be barred from further participation before the governing body. Only persons authorized to address the governing body may use exhibits, displays, and other visual aids as they may relate to the subject of the presentation. 
(4)  Members of the audience; search. All persons in close proximity to members of the governing body and official meeting areas shall be subject to a search of purses, bags, backpacks, and other items used for carrying personal possessions. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in disorderly conduct such as: hand clapping, stomping of feet, whistling, yelling and similar demonstrations, which conduct disturbs the peace and good order of the meeting. Use of placards, banners, signs, exhibits, displays, clothing, and other visual aids or devices that display sentiments that may be threatening, abusive, profane, or result in any disorderly conduct are not permitted in the governing body's meeting area during meeting times. No conversation among persons in the audience shall take place that may disturb the order of business. All mobile and other communication devices including telephones shall be on silent or a non-audible mode. Hand clapping may be allowed as an exception to this provision in instances allowed by the presiding officer such as celebratory or positive acknowledgment. 
(d)  Disturbance abatement. 
(1)  Warning. All persons at the meetings of the governing body shall, at the request of the presiding officer, be silent. If, after receiving a warning from the presiding officer, a person persists in disturbing the meeting, such officer may order him/her to remove himself/herself from the meeting. If he/she does not remove himself/herself, the presiding officer may order that the city manager or a law enforcement officer have the person removed. 
(2)  Removal. The chief of police, or such member of the police department as the presiding officer may designate, shall be sergeant-at-arms of the board of commissioners meetings. The chief shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the meeting. Upon instruction of the presiding officer, it shall be the duty of the sergeant-at-arms to remove from the meeting any person who disturbs the proceedings of the governing body. 
(3)  Necessitating removal. It shall be unlawful for any person at a meeting of the governing body to resist removal by the sergeant-at-arms. 
(4)  Motions to enforce. Any member of the governing body may move to require the presiding officer to enforce the terms of this section, and the affirmative vote of a majority of the governing body shall require him to do so. 
(5)  Adjournment. If any meeting of the governing body is willfully disturbed by a group of persons so as to render the orderly conduct of such meeting unfeasible and when order cannot be restored by the removal of individuals who are creating the disturbance, the meeting may be adjourned and the remaining business considered at the next regular meeting. 
(e)  Use of cameras and recorders. Cameras, including television and motion picture cameras, electronic sound recording devices and any other mechanical, electrical or electronic recording devices may be used in a reasonable manner in the public section of the commission chamber. 
(f)  Provisions applicable to boards and committees. The rules and procedures set out herein shall be applicable to the city's governing body only. Provisions set herein shall not be applicable to other boards and committees. 
(g)  Notice shall be placed in conspicuous place. All or part of the provisions of this section may be placed in an area to be viewed by the public at or near the meeting site. 
(h)  Placement of items on the official meeting agenda. 
(1)  Any elected or appointed official shall be prohibited from placing any item for the purposes of discussion or to be acted upon if the subject matter may result in either an unbudgeted expenditure of funds, or interference with a pending investigation or other legal matter. 
(2)  Matters that have been voted on the governing body shall not be placed on the agenda for reconsideration within six months, unless a member of the governing body on the prevailing side, or a member of the governing body appointed or elected to the governing body since the matter was considered, makes a written request to the reconsider the matter in question. 
(i)  Closed session deliberations. It shall be unlawful for any person present during a closed session meeting of the governing body to disclose the matters discussed or any information received during the closed session to a noon-privy third party unless otherwise ordered by a court of law. Violation of this provision by an elected or appointed official shall be deemed a failure to faithfully execute the duties of office under article X, section 4 of the Charter. Violation of this provision may also result in the maximum fine allowed by law as well as other relief at law or equity allowed by law for violation and enforcement of ordinances. 
(j)  Enforcement; punishment; penalties. 
(1)  Should any person or business violate the prohibitions contained herein, the city attorney may take any action to enforce this or any ordinance to prevent and summarily abate the action, and any and all other relief as may be necessary. 
(2)  Any violation of this section shall be subject to both civil and criminal penalties. A criminal conviction shall be a class C misdemeanor. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. If conduct constituting an offense under this section also constitutes an offense under another law, the person may be prosecuted under all applicable laws. 
(3)  A liable party shall be subject to a civil penalty up to $200.00 per violation, in addition to court costs, and other fees allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-84, §§ 1-7, 12-17-04; Ord. No. O-2008-27, §§ 1-7, 6-17-08; Ord. No. 2010-05, §§ 1-10, 2-16-10; Ord. No. O-2010-32, §§ 1-10, 5-27-10; Ord. No. O-2015-28, §§ 1-10, 6-2-15; Ord. No. O-2018-45, §§ 1-10, 11-19-18) 
Sec. 2-3. - Criteria for municipal services such as permitting, certificates, etc. 
(1)  Authorization; applicability; factors. 
(a)  Any department of the City of Pharr including but not limited to its: board of commissioners, city manager, or designated city personnel, may refuse or terminate any contract at any time, deny, rescind, or cancel an application or a permit, certificate, license, service, or other issuance. The city is further authorized to promulgate necessary forms, guidelines, applications, permits, certificates, licenses, services, issuances, or written agreements to include authorization, releases, and waiver of legal liability and damages. An application, permit, certificate, license, service, issuance, or written agreement may also expire without further action. 
(b)  The authority to be exercised in accordance with this section shall be applicable to any person, corporation, company, partnership, association, or any other legal entity or organization that is in any way directly, indirectly, or as a result of a person in authority or control of the management, operations, land, occupant, or buildings that contracts with the city, submits an application to the city, or receives a permit, certificate, license, service, or other issuance. 
(c)  The following factors may be considered as to any application contract, permit, certificate, license, service, or other issuance: 
1.  Financially indebted to the city or its departments or corporations; 
2.  Is non-compliant or in violation with state, federal, or local ordinance; 
3.  Is non-compliant with any service or contractual obligations with the city or its departments or corporations; 
4.  Has a pending claim against the city or any of its employees, appointed or elected officials in their official capacity, or corporations; 
5.  Any person or entity to whom this section may be applicable is the subject of a criminal complaint that may be either a felony or misdemeanor; 
6.  Any person or entity to whom this section is or may be applicable is liable to the city or any of its departments or corporations for any damage or injury; 
7.  Acts or omissions that may jeopardize the health, safety, welfare of the general public, patrons, or bystanders. 
(2)  Circumvention. It shall be unlawful for an applicant to knowingly conspire to circumvent this section by allowing the use of its name, authority, or official government record, application, or contract to any person, business, or entity to avoid the provisions, restrictions, and prohibitions of this section. A violation of this subsection may subject any violator to criminal penalties as may applicable by law. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-51, §§ 2, 3, 12-17-13; Ord. No. O-2015-08, §§ 2, 3, 3-3-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2013-51, §§ 2, 3, adopted Dec. 17, 2013, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included as § 2-3. 
Secs. 2-4-2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-31. - City clerk. 
    The city clerk shall have the powers and duties prescribed by state law, the Charter, this Code and the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 2-52) 
Charter reference- Appointment, term of city clerk, art. III, § 3. 
Sec. 2-32. - Assistant city manager and deputy city manager. 
(1)  Assistant city manager. The position of assistant city manager is hereby created, and all actions occurring prior are hereby ratified including but not limited to any budgetary allowances and amendments thereto. 
    The position of assistant city manager shall be that of a designee of the city manager that shall be held by a qualified person, appointed as provided by the Pharr City Charter and personnel policies, and administered by the city manager. Qualifications, duties, and responsibilities of the assistant city manager shall be subject to the approval of the city manager. Any approved compensation may be commensurate and limited to assigned functions or duties. 
(2)  Deputy city manager. There is hereby created the position of deputy city manager. The position of deputy city manager shall be that of a designee of the city manager. The position of deputy city manager shall be subject to budgetary funding as may occur prior to or subsequent to this section by the governing body. There may be more than one budgeted position of deputy city manager as may be necessary to further city business and interests. The position of deputy city manager shall be held by qualified persons, appointed as provided by the Pharr City Charter and personnel policies, and administered by the city manager and/or designee including the assistant city manager. Qualifications, duties, and responsibilities of the deputy city manager shall be subject to the approval of the city manager and designees. Any approved compensation may be commensurate and limited to assigned functions or duties. 
(3)  Role and powers. The assistant city manager and any deputy city manager shall carry out the following roles and duties: 
(a)  Carry out any and all assigned functions delegated by the city manager; 
(b)  Fulfill any assigned tasks that may be required, in whole or part, to other positions or duties that may be held simultaneously; 
(c)  Cooperate in multi-tasking and cross-training as may be required to oversee specific divisions, functions, departments, or assignments; 
(d)  Act professionally at all times and remain subject to job descriptions as may be amended from time to time and other directives including but not limited to personnel policies and the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-02, §§ 1-3, 1-22-15) 
Secs. 2-33-2-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY MANAGER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to appoint city manager, art. IV, § 1. 

Sec. 2-51. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of city manager. 
(Code 1976, § 2-16) 
Sec. 2-52. - Appointment, tenure. 
    The city manager shall be appointed for an indefinite term of office and subject to discharge or removal by the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 2-17) 
Charter reference- Dismissal, suspension of appointive officers, art. IV, § 3. 
Sec. 2-53. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The powers and duties of the city manager shall be: 
(1)  To devote all of his working time and attention to the affairs of the city, and be responsible to the city commission for the efficient administration of its affairs. 
(2)  To see that all laws and ordinances are enforced. 
(3)  With the advice of the city commission, to appoint and remove all heads of departments. He shall also have the power to appoint or remove all subordinate employees. 
(4)  To exercise supervision and control over all departments created by the city commission or that may hereafter be created by the city commission. 
(5)  To attend all meetings of the city commission with the right to take part in discussions, but having no vote; and he shall be notified of all special meetings of the city commission. 
(6)  To see that all terms and conditions imposed in favor of the city or its inhabitants in any public utility franchise are faithfully kept and performed, and upon knowledge of any violation thereof to call such violation to the attention of the city commission. 
(7)  To act as budget officer and as such to prepare and submit to the city commission, prior to the beginning of each fiscal year, a budget of proposed expenditures for the ensuing year, showing in as much detail as practicable the estimated amounts required by months for the efficient operation of each department of the city government and the reasons for such estimated expenditures. 
(8)  In addition to the duties prescribed by subsection (7) of this section, the city manager shall make and file a budget as required by state law. 
(9)  To make a full written report to the city commission as soon after the close of each month's accounts as possible, showing the operation and expenditures of each department for the preceding month and a comparison of such monthly expenditures, by department, with the monthly allowances made for such department in the annual budget, and to keep the city commission fully advised at all times as to the financial condition and needs of the city. 
(10)  To recommend to the city commission the salaries to be paid each appointive officer and subordinate employee of the city. 
(11)  To recommend to the city commission, in writing, from time to time, for adoption, such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient. 
(12)  To do and perform such other duties as may be prescribed by ordinance or resolution of the city commission. 
(13)  The city manager or his designated representative shall act as purchasing agent for the city and shall purchase all merchandise material and supplies needed by the city and will establish a suitable storehouse where such supplies shall be kept and from which the same shall be issued as needed. He shall adopt such rules and regulations as he shall deem necessary governing requisitions and transaction of business between himself and the department heads, officers and employees of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 2-18; Ord. No. O-2010-29, § 1, 5-18-10; Ord. No. O-2011-54, § 1, 9-29-11; Ord. No. O-2012-33, § 1, 9-4-12; Ord. No. O-2015-29, § 1, 6-16-15; Ord. No. O-2016-20, § 1, 6-20-16; Ord. No. O-2016-29, § 1, 11-7-16) 
Sec. 2-54. - Acting manager. 
    During the absence or disability of the city manager, the city manager shall appoint a responsible city employee to perform the duties of such office. 
(Code 1976, § 2-19) 
Secs. 2-55-2-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - GENERAL COUNSEL 

Sec. 2-71. - Term of service. 
    The general counsel for the city shall serve at the pleasure of the city commission, and shall provide the services set out in this division. 
(Code 1976, § 2-46) 
Sec. 2-72. - Duties generally. 
    The general counsel shall: 
(1)  Represent the city, and prosecute any and all criminal cases filed in the municipal court of the city; 
(2)  Counsel the city commission on such matters of a legal nature and perform such legal services as the commission shall indicate, including, without limitation, the prosecution and/or defense of civil litigation; 
provided, that as a restriction and limitation of the duties of the general counsel, it is expressly understood that he is not empowered or authorized to perform, nor shall he have the responsibility for, every duty usually and customarily incident to the office of the city attorney. 
(Code 1976, § 2-47) 
State Law reference- Prosecutions in municipal court conducted by city attorney, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.03. 
Sec. 2-73. - Compensation. 
    The city shall pay the general counsel reasonable fees for all services provided. 
(Code 1976, § 2-48) 
Secs. 2-74-2-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, COMMITTEES, DEPARTMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-91. - Membership and procedures for boards, commissions and committees generally. 
(a)  Applicability. The terms and provisions of this section shall not apply to the city commission, the zoning board of adjustment or to any other board, commission or committee of the city which is regulated as to the terms covered in this section by state law or the Charter as the same now exist or as may be amended. 
(b)  Residence qualifications; selection of chairmen. In the case of every board, commission and committee of the city not excepted by subsection (a) of this section, the following residence qualifications and procedures for selection shall apply: 
(1)  The board of commissioners by majority vote of all members present, shall appoint City of Pharr board and/or committee members/officers, and such members/officers shall consist of either of the following: 
a.  Pharr residents: All board and/or committee members/officers must be persons who are citizens and residents of the City of Pharr. A citizen and resident of the City of Pharr, Hidalgo County, Texas, shall de defined as any person who lives within the boundaries of the City of Pharr, Texas, at the time that he or she is being appointed to the board or committee. 
b.  Pharr business owner: A person may be considered for appointment to a board or committee, without regard to residency, if that person is an owner of a business in which the primary location of the business and central decision-making authority are physically located within the boundaries of the City of Pharr, Texas. Any person being considered as a business owner for purpose of this provision shall provide, upon request, any information necessary. 
(2)  All chairmen of boards, commissions and committees of the city shall be selected by the membership of such board, commission or committee, and shall serve for a term and in a manner in accordance with the ordinance or resolution setting up such board, commission or committee and the rules and/or bylaws of the respective board, commission or committee. 
(c)  Tenure in office; absence from meetings. All members of boards, commissions and committees of the city duly appointed shall continue to serve in their appointed capacities until their successors have been duly selected and qualified. However, it is expressly provided that any such member who shall absent himself from as many as three consecutive regular meetings of the board, commission or committee on which he serves shall forfeit his office as a member of such board, commission or committee, and it shall be the duty of the remaining members of such board, commission or committee to declare such office vacant and report such vacancy to the city commission; provided, however, that if such absence is found by the majority of the members of that board, commission or committee to have been occasioned by illness or justified excuse, then such absence shall not constitute a basis for forfeiture of the office of such member. 
(d)  Duration of terms; filling of vacancies. All appointments to boards, commissions and committees for full terms shall be for staggered periods of two years. Any member of a board, commission or committee may be reappointed by the city commission upon completion of a full term. In the event that a vacancy occurs on any board, commission or committee governed by this section prior to the expiration of a full term, the city commission shall appoint a new member to complete the unexpired term. 
(e)  Frequency of meetings; report requirements. All boards, commissions and committees of the city shall meet at least one time each month at designated times and shall report once in writing to the city commission promptly following each meeting, either by furnishing a copy of the minutes of such meeting or by furnishing a written report of the activities of such board, commission or committee to the city manager. 
(f)  Limitation of persons to one board or committee. A person, either citizen/resident or Pharr business owner, shall not serve as an officer or member of more than one Pharr board or committee concurrently. This provision is not applicable to Pharr elected officials. 
(g)  City Charter incorporated. Pursuant to article IV, section 3 of the Pharr City Charter, which is incorporated by reference herein, the board of commissioners may by majority vote of all members present, appoint, suspend, dismiss, remove, and replace any such members or officers of a board or committee and abolish any such boards or committees at any time with or without cause regard to the term of office of a member or officer. 
(Code 1976, § 2-2; Ord. No. O-2002-34, § 1, 8-6-02; Ord. No. O-2004-45, §§ 1-3, 8-17-04) 
Secs. 2-92-2-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIREFIGHTERS' AND POLICE OFFICERS' CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 54; law enforcement, ch. 70. 
State Law reference- Municipal civil service, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 143. 

Sec. 2-106. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Pharr Firefighters' and Police Officers' Civil Service Commission. 
(Code 1976, § 2-111) 
Sec. 2-107. - Duties generally. 
    Members of the firefighters' and police officers' civil service commission shall implement and administer V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 143, the purpose of which is to secure efficient fire and police departments composed of capable personnel who are free from political influence and who have permanent employment tenure as public servants. 
(Code 1976, § 2-112) 
State Law reference- Purpose of civil service law, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.001. 
Sec. 2-108. - Composition; appointment. 
    The firefighters' and police officers' civil service commission shall consist of three members to be appointed by the chief executive of the city and confirmed by the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 2-113) 
Sec. 2-109. - Terms of office. 
    Each of the three civil service commissioners shall serve staggered three-year terms with the term of one member expiring each year. 
(Code 1976, § 2-114; Ord. No. O-2004-54, § 1, 9-17-04) 
Sec. 2-109.1. - Vacancy. 
    Should a vacancy [occur] on the civil service commission, a qualified person shall be appointed to serve for the remainder of the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointment. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-54, § 2, 9-17-04) 
Sec. 2-110. - Qualifications. 
    A person appointed to the firefighters' and police officers' civil service commission must: 
(1)  Be of good moral character; 
(2)  Be a United States citizen; 
(3)  Be a resident of the city who has resided in the city for more than three years; 
(4)  Be over 25 years of age; and 
(5)  Not have held a public office within the preceding three years. 
(Code 1976, § 2-115) 
Sec. 2-111. - Election of officers. 
    Initial members of the firefighters' and police officers' civil service commission shall meet and elect a chairman and a vice-chairman within ten days after the date of appointment. Each January thereafter, the members shall elect a chairman and a vice-chairman. 
(Code 1976, § 2-116) 
Sec. 2-112. - Office space provided. 
    The city shall provide to the firefighters' and police officers' civil service commission adequate and suitable office space in which to conduct its business. 
(Code 1976, § 2-117) 
Sec. 2-113. - Conflict with personnel policies. 
    The city personnel policies and procedures, insofar as they conflict with the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 143, the rules and regulations as adopted by the Pharr civil service commission or the rules and regulations as promulgated by the heads of the fire and police departments of the city, shall to the extent that the same are in conflict not be applicable to the fire and police department civil service employees. 
(Code 1976, § 2-120; Ord. No. O-91-29, § I(2-120), 7-23-91) 
Cross reference- Personnel, ch. 94. 
Sec. 2-114. - City commission action. 
    The city commission may from time to time by ordinance, without the necessity of publication in this Code of Ordinances, take necessary action as required under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 143, for appointment of department heads, approval of classifications of civil service employees, authorization of positions, setting base pay and performing other matters as required by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 143. 
(Code 1976, § 2-121; Ord. No. O-91-29, § I(2-121), 7-23-91) 
Sec. 2-115. - Appointment and removal of person classified immediately below department heads. 
    The department head of the fire and police department in the city may appoint the person or persons to occupy any authorized position in the classification immediately below that of the chief (department head), not to exceed three people, in accordance with the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.014. In the fire department, the total number of persons appointed to the classification immediately below that of chief (department head) may not exceed two persons, in accordance with the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.014. In no event may the total number of persons appointed by the chiefs (department heads) of either department exceed the number of positions authorized by action of the city commission for such department. The chiefs (department heads) may remove any person so appointed in accordance with the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 143. 
(Code 1976, § 2-122; Ord. No. O-91-29, § I(2-122), 7-23-91) 
Sec. 2-116. - Sick leave transition policy. 
    It is further provided that on October 30, 1990, the chiefs (department heads) of the fire department and police department of the city are hereby ordered and directed to certify the number of accrued sick leave days of each civil service employee of the respective departments. Thereafter, on October 31, 1990, all employees with civil service status shall accrue sick leave at the rate as prescribed under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.045. On October 31, 1990, and after such date, should any such employee utilize any sick leave, then such employee shall have deducted from his sick leave, first the sick leave accumulated from and after October 31, 1990, and upon the exhaustion of all sick leave accrued from and after October 31, 1990, then such employee shall have deducted from his sick leave accumulation that sick leave which was accrued prior to October 31, 1990. The provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.045(c) do not apply to any sick leave accumulated on or after such date, and it is further provided that in no event shall any such employee be paid for greater than 90 days accumulated sick leave upon separation from the city, unless otherwise specifically required by statute or as provided in this division. If at the time of retirement or death any such employee has less than 60 days accrued sick leave from and after October 31, 1990, but retains accrued sick leave from prior to October 31, 1990, then and in that event the employee, or if deceased, the person entitled to receive the compensation, shall be paid all accrued sick leave during city employment; provided, that in no event shall such an employee utilizing sick leave accrued prior to October 31, 1990, be paid for greater than 60 days' accumulated sick leave. 
(Code 1976, § 2-123; Ord. No. O-91-29, § I(2-123), 7-23-91) 
Sec. 2-117. - Probationary period transition policy. 
    All civil service employees hired prior to October 31, 1990, shall complete the probationary period in effect at the time of their respective employments. 
(Code 1976, § 2-124) 
Sec. 2-118. - Assignment pay. 
    On October 31, 1990, the chiefs (department heads) of the fire and police departments shall designate the persons who are performing specified job duties for which assignment pay is authorized by the city commission. Thereafter, in designating employees for performance of any specified job duties for which assignment pay is authorized by the city commission, the chiefs shall follow the following procedure: 
(1)  Notice of the availability of such additional duties and assignment pay shall be posted on the department bulletin board for at least seven days; 
(2)  An application form shall be provided to any eligible employee who requests it during the seven-day period; 
(3)  The chief shall personally interview each applicant prior to the designation; and 
(4)  The chief shall designate the best qualified or most suitable applicant to perform the specified job duties. 
Assignment pay shall only be paid to an employee who is actually performing the specified job duties or is in actual and periodic training for performance of the specified job duties; provided, that the training period may not exceed six months. The number of persons receiving assignment pay for the specified job duties set out in this division may not exceed the number of positions authorized by the city commission. The chief is ineligible for assignment pay. 
(Code 1976, § 2-125) 
Secs. 2-119-2-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-136. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Pharr Capital Improvements Committee. 
(Code 1976, § 2-101) 
Sec. 2-137. - Composition; appointments. 
(a)  The capital improvements committee shall consist of seven members with each city commissioner appointing one member. 
(b)  Not less than 40 percent of the membership of the capital improvements committee shall be representatives of the real estate, development, or building industries who are not employees or officials of a political subdivision or governmental entity. 
(Code 1976, § 2-102) 
Sec. 2-138. - Terms. 
    The terms of members of the capital improvements committee shall be for as long as required to complete the capital improvements plan. 
(Code 1976, § 2-103) 
Sec. 2-139. - Ex officio members. 
    The city manager, the city engineer and director of planning of the city and any other city employee deemed necessary by the city commission shall serve as ex officio members of the capital improvements committee without voting rights and shall be in addition to the seven regular members appointed under this division. 
(Code 1976, § 2-104) 
Sec. 2-140. - Meetings; officers. 
    The capital improvements committee shall meet as soon as possible after all of its members are appointed and establish its meeting rules and procedures, and times and dates for such meetings of the committee as may be necessary to accomplish its purposes, which rules of procedure shall be subject to approval by the city commission. The committee shall elect a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary at its first meeting. 
(Code 1976, § 2-105) 
Sec. 2-141. - Capital improvements plan; elements. 
    The capital improvements committee is to prepare a report for consideration of the city commission, such report to be known as the capital improvements plan, which will substantially contain the following elements: 
(1)  An inventory of existing capital facilities and equipment by age, condition, extent of usage, annual maintenance costs, replacement costs, target dates for replacement or expansion and for new facilities. 
(2)  A report to the city commission which recommends which capital improvement projects should be continued, whether additional funds are required and what funds are available from completed and discontinued projects. 
(3)  An analysis that identifies the level of capital improvement expenditures the city can afford for the next five-year period and which identifies the likely effect of such capital improvements on the property tax rate and other revenues. 
(4)  For each proposed capital improvements project there shall be a statement of need, cost, net effect on the operating budget and annual operating costs, and a proposed implementation schedule. 
(Code 1976, § 2-106) 
Secs. 2-142-2-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BEAUTIFICATION COMMITTEE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-32, adopted August 21, 2017, repealed the former division 4, §§ 2-161-2-165.3, and enacted a new division 4 as set out herein. The former division 4 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-2017-23, adopted June 5, 2017. 

Sec. 2-161. - Name. 
    The name of the committee is the Pharr Beautification Committee. 
(Ord. No. 2017-32, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 2-162. - Purpose and duties. 
    The purpose of the committee is to exercise the powers and duties of a beautification committee of the city. It shall promote and encourage the beautification of the city through the participation of the city, the citizens of Pharr, and local business concerns in individual and cooperative efforts. It shall actively pursue and promote the development of civic pride and shall coordinate the efforts of all who will work for the common purpose of improving the beauty and cleanliness of the city. Such committee shall also perform other duties as may be necessary and directed by the city committee of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2017-32, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 2-163. - Membership. 
(a)  The city beautification committee is composed of five members appointed by the committee of commissioners. 
(b)  Members serve at the pleasure of the city council. Any member may be removed from their position on the committee for any reason, or for no reason, by a majority vote of the committee of commissioners. 
(c)  Members shall be appointed for a term of one, two and three years on a rotating basis and removable by the appointing authority. The committee of commissioners shall appoint two one-year members, two two-year members and one three-year member. All cases to be heard and ruled upon will always be heard by a minimum of three members. 
(d)  An individual member may not act in an official capacity except through the action of the committee. When a member is called upon to voice opinions at public or private functions, he/she shall indicate that he/she is speaking for himself/herself and not representing the committee or the city unless a formal action by the beautification committee or committee of commissioners has been taken on the specific issue. 
(e)  A member who is absent for three consecutive regular meetings or half of all regular meetings in a "rolling" twelve-month timeframe automatically vacates the member's position. This does not apply to an absence due to illness or injury of the committee member, an illness or injury of a committee member's immediate family member, or the birth or adoption of the member's child for 90 days after the event. The committee member must notify the director of parks and recreation of the reason for the absence not later than the date of the next regular meeting of the committee. Failure to notify before the next regular meeting of the committee will result in an unexcused absence. 
(f)  At each meeting, each committee member shall sign an attendance sheet which indicates that the member does not have a conflict of interest with any item on that agenda, or identifies each agenda item on which the member has a conflict of interest. Failure to sign the sheet results in the member being counted as absent and his/her votes are not counted. 
(g)  A committee member who seeks to resign from the committee shall submit a written resignation to the chairman. If possible, the resignation should allow for a 30-day notice so the committee of commissioners can appoint a replacement. 
(h)  All committee members must be a resident of the city. 
(i)  The director of parks and recreation and the assistant director of parks and recreation shall be ex officio members of the beautification committee without a right to vote but will provide technical support and expertise to the commission. The provisions of subsection (e), above, do not apply to ex officio members. 
(j)  Committee members serve without compensation. The committee and its members have no authority to expend funds or to incur or make an obligation on behalf of the city unless authorize and approved by the board of commissioners. Committee members may be reimbursed for expenses authorized and approved by the board of commissioners. 
(k)  Members will comply with city ordinances, rules and policies applicable to the committee and its members, including but not limited to ethics, courtesy and respect. Members are prohibited from engaging in conduct that adversely reflects on the city, bears a negative impact on public perception of the city, its employees or elected and appointed officials. 
(l)  Members shall not have any administrative or enforcement authority in the day to day operations of the city. They shall have no authority or right to enforce any rule, ordinance or regulation of the city. Any violations are violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2017-32, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 2-164. - Officers. 
(a)  The officers of the committee shall consist of a chairman and a vice-chairman and secretary. 
(b)  The chairman is appointed by the mayor and the city council shall approve the recommendation by a vote of the majority of the board of commissioners during the annual appointment process. Should the mayor fail to recommend a chairman for each committee, committee or commission, and/or the committee of commissioners fails to approve any chairman recommended by the mayor, a majority of the board of commissioners plus one (super-majority) may approve appointment of a chairman. The other officers (except for parliamentarian) shall be elected annually by a majority vote of the commission at the first regular meeting in January. In the event a current officer becomes ineligible to serve as an officer, the commission may hold an emergency election as needed for all officers. 
(c)  The term of office shall be one year, beginning January and ending December. An officer may continue to serve until a successor is elected. A person may not serve as an officer in a designated position of a commission for more than three consecutive one-year terms. A person who has served as an officer in a designated position of a committee for three consecutive terms is not eligible for re-election to that designated office until the expiration of two years after the last date of the person's service in that office. 
(d)  A member may not hold more than one office at a time. 
(Ord. No. 2017-32, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 2-165. - Duties of officers. 
(a)  The chair shall preside at committee meetings, appoint all sub-committees, and represent the committee at ceremonial functions. 
(b)  In the absence of the chairman, the vice-chair shall perform all duties of the chair. 
(c)  In the absence of both the chairman and the vice-chair the secretary shall perform the duties of the chairman. 
(d)  In the absence of all officers the most senior member by appointment date shall chair the meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2017-32, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 2-165.1 - Agendas. 
(a)  Items may be placed on the agenda by the chairman, director of park and recreation, the city manager or his designee or at the request of two or more committee members. The requests must be at least five days before the meeting. Committee members must consulting with and receiving input from the director of parks and recreation. The director shall seek consultation from the city attorney as to the legalities of the agenda item(s) and whether it is within the committee's discretion. 
(b)  Staff shall assemble all regular meeting items as directed by city ordinance and internal city policy. 
(c)  Posting of the agenda must comply with V.T.C.A., Govt. Code ch. 551 (Texas Open Meetings Act). 
(Ord. No. 2017-32, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 2-165.2 - Meetings. 
(a)  The committee meetings shall comply with V.T.C.A., Govt. Code ch. 551 (Texas Open Meetings Act). 
(b)  Committee meetings shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order. 
(c)  All meeting of the committee shall be open to the public. The committee shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member on each questions, or if absent or failing to vote. The director of development services shall be custodian and possessor of records and minutes of the meetings. 
(d)  The committee shall meet at least twice a month. In November of each year, the committee shall adopt a schedule of the meetings for the upcoming year, as composed by staff. 
(e)  Special meetings may be called by the chairman or at the requested by three or more members. The call shall state the purpose of the meeting, the time and the date. A committee may not call a meeting in addition to its regular scheduled meetings as identified in its adopted meeting schedule, more often than once a quarter, unless the meeting is required to comply with a statutory deadline or a deadline established by council. 
(f)  If a quorum for a meeting does not convene within one-half hour of the posted time for the meeting, then the meeting may not be held. 
(g)  An affirmative vote of at least three members must be made to approve any motion. 
(h)  The chairman has the same voting privilege as any other member. 
(i)  The committee shall allow citizens to address the committee on agenda items and during a period of time set aside for citizen communications. The chairman may limit a speaker to three minutes. In the interest of fairness to the applicants and appellants appearing before the committee and those appearing in opposition to the same, no discussion shall be held by a member or members of this committee with the applicant, appellant, or opposition, who is attempting to influence any committee member concerning the application or other matter involving an applicant or appellant before the committee either at home or office, or in person, by telephone, letter or electronic communication. All such discussions shall be held during a meeting at which the item is posted for discussion so that all members shall have the full benefit of such a discussion. 
(j)  The parks and recreation staff shall prepare the committee minutes. The minutes of each committee meeting must include the vote of each member on each item before the committee and indicate whether a member is absent or failed to vote on an item. 
(k)  The city clerk shall retain agendas, approved minutes, internal review reports and bylaws. The parks and recreation department shall retain all other committee documents. The documents are public records under V.T.C.A., Govt. Code ch. 552 (Texas Public Information Act). 
(l)  Each person and committee member attending a committee meeting should observe proper decorum. 
(m)  Debate and motions. Motions are usually classified in several ways: 
(1)  Main motion; 
(2)  Subsidiary motion/Un-debatable motions; 
(3)  Privileged motions; and 
(4)  Fully-debatable motions. 
    A main motion is a motion that brings business before the committee. Main motions are made while no other motion is pending. Any of the subsidiary or privileged motions may be made while the main motion is pending, and in many cases these motions, if passed, will affect the committee's consideration of the main motion. A subsidiary or un-debatable motion is a type of motion by which a deliberative assembly deals directly with a main motion prior to (or instead of) voting on the main motion itself. Subsidiary motions are motions such as to postpone indefinitely, amend and to table. 
    A subsidiary or un-debatable motion involves procedural questions that can be resolved without discussion, such as tabling a main motion, moving the previous question, restricting further discussion of a main motion to a fixed number of minutes, postponing action, or referring an item under discussion to a committee. After a subsidiary or un-debatable motion is offered, the chairman must immediately take a vote, without discussion. 
    Privileged motions grant precedence over ordinary business. Such motions have limited debate permitted. They include setting the time of the next meeting, adjourn, recess or executive session. Any discussion of a privileged motion must be addressed to the motion itself. A motion to fix the time for adjourning the commission meeting, for example, might require limited debate as to the advisability of such a decision, but other points of discussion would be out of order. 
    Fully-debatable motions are subject to unlimited discussion prior to a decision. 
    One of the most important principles of debate is that committee member's statements be directly relevant to the item under consideration. Committee members recognized by the chairman are given the floor only for the purpose of discussing the item then pending, and they are out of order if they depart from that item. "Debate" can easily evolve into statements of personal philosophy. As interesting though as these statements may seem to the speaker, such departures do not belong in a commission meeting. 
(Ord. No. 2017-32, 8-21-17) 
Sec. 2-165.3 - Amendment of bylaws. 
    A bylaw amendment is not effective unless approved by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2017-32, 8-21-17) 
DIVISION 5. - LIBRARY BOARD 

Sec. 2-166. - Created. 
    There is created a library board to be known as the "South Pharr Outreach Library Board," which shall be composed of five members appointed by the board of commissioners, each member to be a resident of South Pharr. The term of members of the board shall be three years; however, two of the initial members shall serve two-year terms, the other three members three-year terms. Vacancies, as they occur, shall be filled for the unexpired terms at the will of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. O-2001-41, § 1, 11-6-01) 
Sec. 2-167. - Duties generally. 
    The South Pharr Outreach Library Board shall have the power and shall be required to: 
(a)  Act in an advisory capacity in all matters pertaining to public library; 
(b)  Consider the annual budget of the South Pharr Library program and make recommendations with respect thereto to the city manager and the city commission; 
(c)  Assist in the planning of programs, promote and stimulate public interest in such programs; 
(d)  Any other duties as set forth by the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. O-2001-41, § 2, 11-6-01) 
DIVISION 6. - ALL-AMERICA CITY BOARD 

Sec. 2-168. - Creation; membership/officers, appointments; number of members; quorum. 
    The City of Pharr hereby creates the All-America City Board ("board"). The board shall be composed of nine members. The city commission shall, upon approval of Ordinance No. O-2004-59, initially select members to be the chairman, a vice-chairman to act in the absence of the chairman, and a secretary. Thereafter, the board shall annually select through from its membership a chairman, a vice-chairman, and secretary. The members shall be selected by a majority vote of the City of Pharr Board of Commissioners. A majority of the members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-59, § 1, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 2-169. - Terms; filling of vacancies. 
    The members shall serve staggered terms: three members shall serve a one-year term, three members shall serve a two-year term, and three members shall serve a three-year term. Appointments to fill vacancies on the board prior to the expiration of a term shall be for the remainder of the term. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-59, § 2, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 2-170. - Purpose. 
    The All-America City Board shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city commissioners. The board in all things shall obtain, pursue, and satisfy the requirements necessary to be considered and attain the All-America City designation. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-59, § 3, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 2-171. - Projects; creation of subcommittees and ad-hoc committees. 
    The board shall focus on improving every aspect of the City of Pharr that could improve the quality of life of those who reside and travel within the city's boundaries, including but not limited to the following: 
(a)  Weedy lots; 
(b)  Brush pick-up; 
(c)  Junk cars; 
(d)  Flooding; 
(e)  Holiday projects; 
(f)  Community, youth, and business involvement; 
(g)  Beautification; 
(h)  Community outreach; and 
(i)  Any other necessary functions and projects. 
    In accomplishing its purposes, the board may create subcommittees and ad-hoc committees from its own membership which will be under the control and supervision of the board. The board may also seek the advice of the elected and/or appointed officials, city manager and, if authorized by the city manager, may seek assistance from department heads. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-59, § 4, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 2-172. - Expenditure of funds. 
    The board shall not be authorized to create any debts or incur expenses on behalf of the city incident to the operation of its board, projects, and programs unless expressly authorized to do so by the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-59, § 5, 10-5-04) 
Sec. 2-173. - Organization; meetings. 
    The board is hereby authorized to establish its own rules and procedures, not in conflict with this or any other ordinance, the City Charter, or any state or federal laws. 
    The board shall provide for regular and special meetings necessary to carry out the functions and its business as set out in Ordinance No. O-2004-59. All meetings, regular and special called, shall be conducted within the boundaries of the City of Pharr, Texas. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-59, § 6, 10-5-04) 
DIVISION 7. - MAYOR'S CHAIRMAN COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-174. - Creation. 
    The city hereby creates the "Mayor's Chairman Commission," and is referred to in this division as the "commission." 
(Ord. No. O-2016-21, § 1, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 2-175. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to establish procedures and standards for the appointment of the commission. The commission shall consist of the chairmen of all the appointed boards and commissions within the city. Members shall not be entitled to compensation for the performance of their duties. The commission shall act in an advisory capacity to the mayor and board of commissioners. The mayor shall serve as the chairman of the commission. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-21, § 2, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 2-176. - Member terms. 
    Members shall serve for a one-year term from January 1 to December 31. Members will serve at the pleasure of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-21, § 3, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 2-177. - Meetings. 
    Members shall meet at least twice a year at such time and place to be determined by the mayor. The commission shall serve to brief the mayor on the status of their respective board or commission, the status of their decisions and impacts thereof upon the city, and are encouraged to provide feedback on the ideal characteristics and experience for potential new board or commission members. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-21, § 4, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 2-178. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    In order to run an efficient and effective city, all boards and commissions must be in line with the mayor and board of commissioners goals and objectives. The choosing of an independent chairman for each board or commission is paramount to the successful implementation of good corporate governance and the wishes and vision of the mayor and board of commissioners. The chairman of each individual board or commission is charged with the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Provide the board or commission with leadership and harness the talents and energy contributed by each individual member of their board or commission; 
(2)  Serve as the board or commission's lead representative which will involve the presentation of the city's goals, objectives and policies to the outside world; 
(3)  Determine the order of the agenda; ensuring the board or commission receives timely, accurate and clear information to enable them to reach an informed decision; 
(4)  Govern the workings of the board or commission, including directing the meetings and acting as a conciliatory element when the board or commission differ; 
(5)  Keep track of the contribution of individual members of the board or commission and ensure that they are involved in discussion and decision making; 
(6)  Direct all discussion towards the emergence of a consensus view and sum up all discussions so everyone understands what has been agreed upon; 
(7)  Setting the ethical tone for the board or commission; 
(8)  Presiding over board meetings and ensuring that time in the meeting is used productively; 
(9)  Act as the link between the board or commission and the city management and elected officials; 
(10)  Engaging the board or commission in assessing and improving its performance; 
(11)  Overseeing the induction and development of new board or commission members; 
(12)  Monitoring how the board works together and how individual members perform and interact at meetings; 
(13)  Encourage and ensuring that all members play a full and constructive role in the affairs of the city board and commission and taking a lead role in the process for removing non-performing or unsuitable members from the board or commission; 
(14)  Upholding rigorous standards of preparation for meetings; 
(15)  The chairman is obligated to use his or her power appropriately and not to influence the outcome of the meetings towards a specific agenda; and 
(16)  Ensuring that decisions of the board or commission are executed. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-21, § 5, 6-20-16) 
Sec. 2-179. - Appointment. 
    Given the vast importance of an active and committed chairman for each and every board or commission and through this division the mayor shall appoint the chairman of each respective board or commission. The appointment shall be made by a "mayors appointment form" certified by the city clerk and signed and dated by the mayor, with the official seal of the city and filed in the official records of the city clerk. The appointment shall be made during the annual appointment process (prior to August 1 of each calendar year). Should the mayor fail to appoint a chairman for each board or commission by August 1 of each year, the board of commissioners may approve by resolution the chairman of each board, by a majority of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-21, § 6, 6-20-16) 
DIVISION 8. - PUBLIC SAFETY COMMUNICATIONS DEPARTMENT AND PURCHASING DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 2-180. - Departments established. 
    The public safety communications department and purchasing department shall be created pursuant to the City Charter, municipal chain of authority and city employment policy. This division and provisions herewith shall be included in this Code. All acts occurring prior to the effective date of this division shall be ratified and adopted. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-38, § 1, 9-18-17) 
Sec. 2-181. - Authorization. 
    As matters related to procurement practices, public safety and welfare of the residents of the city, the public safety communications department and purchasing department shall be authorized to carry out any and all duties and responsibilities as directed by the city and as may be allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-38, § 2, 9-18-17) 
Sec. 2-182. - Creation and duties of public safety communications department. 
(a)  The public safety communications department is hereby created. 
(b)  The creation of a director full time exempt position is authorized. 
(c)  The creation of a public safety communications advisory committee is authorized within the department. A chairman, vice-chairman and secretary is authorized. The chairman appointment shall be filled by the mayor and all other officers shall be filled by an election of the board. This committee shall consist of at least five members and not exceed nine. Composition shall be the city fire chief, police chief, city manager and a designee from the mayor. Other members may be appointed by inter-local agreements from other government entities which have obtained services from the public safety communications department. 
(d)  The department shall provide: 
(1)  Specialized public safety dispatch services for all city public safety departments and ambulance service and will serve as the primary and secondary 911 public safety answering points for the city; and 
(2)  Participate in regionalization of service for PSAP/911/dispatching services. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-38, § 3, 9-18-17) 
DIVISION 9. - PUBLIC SAFETY COMMUNICATIONS ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-182.1. - Name. 
    The name of the committee is the Pharr Public Safety Communications Advisory Committee. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-33, § 2, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 2-182.2. - Purpose and duties. 
    The purpose of the committee is to exercise the powers and duties of a city public safety communications advisory committee. It shall promote and encourage public safety of the city and those cities that we serve, through the participation of the city, the citizens of Pharr, and local business concerns in individual and cooperative efforts. It shall actively pursue and promote the development of civic pride and shall coordinate the efforts of all who will work for the common purpose of improving public safety services of the city and those cities that we serve. Such committee shall also perform other duties as may be necessary and directed by the committee of commissioners. Some of the duties of the committee shall include but not limited to review if needed calls of service, response times, recommend changes to policy. Personnel matters and budget compliance shall be the responsibility of the director of communications. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-33, § 2, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 2-182.3. - Membership. 
(a)  The city public safety communications advisory committee is composed of seven members, appointed by the board of commissioners. 
(b)  Members serve at the pleasure of the board of commissioners. Any member may be removed from their position on the committee for any reason, or for no reason, by a majority vote of the board of commissioners. 
(c)  Members shall be appointed for a term of one, two and three years on a rotating basis and removable by the appointing authority. The board of commissioners shall appoint two one-year members, two two-year members and one three-year member. All cases to be heard and ruled upon will always be heard by a minimum of three members. 
(d)  An individual member may not act in an official capacity except through the action of the committee. When a member is called upon to voice opinions at public or private functions, he/she shall indicate that he/she is speaking for himself/herself and not representing the committee or the city unless a formal action by the city public safety communications advisory committee or board of commissioners has been taken on the specific issue. 
(e)  A member who is absent for three consecutive regular meetings or half of all regular meetings in a "rolling" 12-month timeframe automatically vacates the member's position. This does not apply to an absence due to illness or injury of the committee member, an illness or injury of a committee member's immediate family member, or the birth or adoption of the member's child for 90 days after the event. The committee member must notify the director of communications of the reason for the absence not later than the date of the next regular meeting of the committee. Failure to notify before the next regular meeting of the committee will result in an unexcused absence. 
(f)  At each meeting, each committee member shall sign an attendance sheet which indicates that the member does not have a conflict of interest with any item on that agenda, or identifies each agenda item on which the member has a conflict of interest. Failure to sign the sheet results in the member being counted as absent and his/her votes are not counted. 
(g)  A committee member who seeks to resign from the committee shall submit a written resignation to the chairman. If possible, the resignation should allow for a 30-day notice, so the board of commissioners can appoint a replacement. 
(h)  The director of communications and the deputy city manager shall be ex officio members of the city public safety communications advisory committee without a right to vote but will provide technical support and expertise to the committee. The provisions of subsection (e) do not apply to ex officio members. 
(i)  Committee members serve without compensation. The committee and its members have no authority to expend funds or to incur or make an obligation on behalf of the city unless authorize and approved by the board of commissioners. Committee members may be reimbursed for expenses authorized and approved by the board of commissioners. 
(j)  Members will comply with city ordinances, rules and policies applicable to the committee and its members, including but not limited to ethics, courtesy and respect. Members are prohibited from engaging in conduct that adversely reflects on the city, bears a negative impact on public perception of the city, its employees or elected and appointed officials. 
(k)  Members shall not have any administrative or enforcement authority in the day to day operations of the city. They shall have no authority or right to enforce any rule, ordinance or regulation of the city. Any violations are violation of this division. 
(l)  There shall be a standing subcommittee compromised of those agencies whom the city public safety communications department provides services for. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-33, § 2, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 2-182.4. - Officers. 
(a)  The officers of the committee shall consist of a chairman and a vice-chairman and secretary. 
(b)  The chairman is appointed by the mayor and the city council shall approve the recommendation by a vote of the majority of the board of commissioners during the annual appointment process. Composition shall be: 
(1)  The chairman. 
(2)  City fire chief. 
(3)  City police chief. 
(4)  City manager or deputy city manager. 
(5)  City representative we serve or appointee. 
(6)  City representative we serve or appointee. 
(7)  Lower Rio Grande Valley Development Council 9-1-1. 
    Other members may be appointed by inter-local agreements from other governmental entities which have obtained services from the public safety communications department. 
(c)  The term of office shall be one year, beginning January and ending December. An officer may continue to serve until a successor is elected. A person may not serve as an officer in a designated position of a commission for more than three consecutive one-year terms. A person who has served as an officer in a designated position of a committee for three consecutive terms is not eligible for re-election to that designated office until the expiration of two years after the last date of the person's service in that office. 
(d)  A member may not hold more than one office at a time. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-33, § 2, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 2-182.5. - Duties of officers. 
(a)  The chair shall preside at committee meetings, appoint all sub-committees, and represent the committee at ceremonial functions. 
(b)  In the absence of the chairman, the vice-chair shall perform all duties of the chair. 
(c)  In the absence of both the chairman and the vice-chair the secretary shall perform the duties of the chairman. 
(d)  In the absence of all officers the most senior member by appointment date shall chair the meeting. If there is a quorum of the committee. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-33, § 2, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 2-182.6. - Agendas. 
(a)  Items may be placed on the agenda by the chairman, director of communications, the city manager or his designee or at the request of two or more committee members. The requests must be at least five days before the meeting. Committee members must consulting with and receiving input from the director of communications. The director shall seek consultation from the city attorney as to the legalities of the agenda item(s) and whether it is within the committee's discretion. 
(b)  Staff shall assemble all regular meeting items as directed by city ordinance and internal city policy. 
(c)  Posting of the agenda must comply with V.T.C.A., Govt. Code ch. 551 (Texas Open Meetings Act). 
(Ord. No. O-2018-33, § 2, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 2-182.7. - Meetings. 
(a)  The committee meetings shall comply with V.T.C.A., Govt. Code ch. 551 551 (Texas Open Meetings Act). 
(b)  Committee meetings shall be governed by Robert's Rules of Order. 
(c)  All meeting of the committee shall be open to the public. Unless in accordance with V.T.C.A., Govt. Code ch. 551 needs to go into executive session to discuss items pursuant to V.T.C.A., Govt. Code §§ 551.071, 551.072, 551.074, 551.076, 551.084, 551.087. The committee shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member on each question, or if absent or failing to vote. The director of communications shall be custodian and possessor of records and minutes of the meetings. 
(d)  The committee shall meet at least once a month. In November of each year, the committee shall adopt a schedule of the meetings for the upcoming year, as composed by staff. 
(e)  Special meetings may be called by the chairman or at the requested by three or more members. The call shall state the purpose of the meeting, the time and the date. A committee may not call a meeting in addition to its regular scheduled meetings as identified in its adopted meeting schedule, more often than once a quarter, unless the meeting is required to comply with a statutory deadline or a deadline established by council. 
(f)  If a quorum for a meeting does not convene within one-half hour of the posted time for the meeting, then the meeting may not be held. 
(g)  An affirmative vote of at least four members must be made to approve any motion. 
(h)  The chairman has the same voting privilege as any other member. 
(i)  The committee shall allow citizens to address the committee on agenda items the beginning of the committee meeting and as specified in Ordinance No. O-2015-28. The chairman may limit a speaker to three minutes. In the interest of fairness to the applicants and appellants appearing before the committee and those appearing in opposition to the same, no discussion shall be held by a member or members of this committee with the applicant, appellant, or opposition, who is attempting to influence any committee member concerning the application or other matter involving an applicant or appellant before the committee either at home or office, or in person, by telephone, letter or electronic communication. All such discussions shall be held during a meeting at which the item is posted for discussion so that all members shall have the full benefit of such a discussion. 
(j)  The communications staff shall prepare the committee minutes. The minutes of each committee meeting must include the vote of each member on each item before the committee and indicate whether a member is absent or failed to vote on an item. 
(k)  The city clerk shall retain agendas, approved minutes, internal review reports and bylaws. The communications department shall retain all other committee documents. The documents are public records under V.T.C.A., Local Govt. Code ch. 552 (Texas Public Information Act). 
(l)  Each person and committee member attending a committee meeting should observe proper decorum. 
(m)  Debate and motions. Motions are usually classified in several ways: 
(1)  Main motion. A main motion is a motion that brings business before the committee. Main motions are made while no other motion is pending. Any of the subsidiary or privileged motions may be made while the main motion is pending, and in many cases these motions, if passed, will affect the committee's consideration of the main motion. A subsidiary or un-debatable motion is a type of motion by which a deliberative assembly deals directly with a main motion prior to (or instead of) voting on the main motion itself. Subsidiary motions are motions such as to postpone indefinitely, amend and to table. 
(2)  Subsidiary motion/un-debatable motions. A subsidiary or un-debatable motion involves procedural questions that can be resolved without discussion, such as tabling a main motion, moving the previous question, restricting further discussion of a main motion to a fixed number of minutes, postponing action, or referring an item under discussion to a committee. After a subsidiary or un-debatable motion is offered, the chairman must immediately take a vote, without discussion. 
(3)  Privileged motions. Privileged motions grant precedence over ordinary business. Such motions have limited debate permitted. They include setting the time of the next meeting, adjourn, recess or executive session. Any discussion of a privileged motion must be addressed to the motion itself. A motion to fix the time for adjourning the commission meeting, for example, might require limited debate as to the advisability of such a decision, but other points of discussion would be out of order. 
(4)  Fully-debatable motions. Fully-debatable motions are subject to unlimited discussion prior to a decision. 
    One of the most important principles of debate is that committee member's statements be directly relevant to the item under consideration. Committee members recognized by the chairman are given the floor only for the purpose of discussing the item then pending, and they are out of order if they depart from that item. "Debate" can easily evolve into statements of personal philosophy. As interesting though as these statements may seem to the speaker, such departures do not belong in a commission meeting. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-33, § 2, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 2-182.8. - Amendment of bylaws. 
    A bylaw amendment is not effective unless approved by the city board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. O-2018-33, § 2, 9-17-18)

(Ord. No. O-2018-47, § 1, 12-10-18)

DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Purchasing and contracting authority of municipalities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 252.
