(a)  The owner of an animal declared vicious shall have the right, within five days after service of the notice under section 18-42, to personally serve upon the animal control officer, designee, or an employee of the city public works department written request for a hearing to contest the vicious animal declaration. The animal control officer or designee shall immediately file the request with the municipal court, and a hearing shall be held within five business days after such filing with the municipal court. 
(b)  The hearing under this section shall be before a municipal judge of the city and shall be formal, and strict rules of evidence shall apply. The owner may be represented by counsel, present oral and written evidence, and cross examine witnesses. 
(c)  The municipal judge shall issue a decision within two business days after the close of the hearing under this section and shall notify the owner in writing of the decision. 
(d)  The municipal judge may uphold the vicious animal declaration, in which event the owner shall comply with all of the requirements and conditions for keeping a vicious animal as set forth in section 18-44 or may unconditionally release the animal to its owner. 
(e)  The decision of the municipal judge on the vicious animal declaration shall be final. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 13, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 13, 4-3-17) 
Sec. 18-44. - Requirements for keeping vicious animal. 
    The owner of a vicious animal shall be subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Confinement. All vicious animals shall be securely confined upon the premises of the owner indoors or outdoors in an enclosed and locked kennel. Confinement shall comply with the provisions of subsection 18-39(d). 
(2)  Leash and muzzle. The owner of a vicious animal shall not allow the animal to go outside its kennel unless the animal is muzzled, restrained by a chain or leash not more than four feet in length, and under the physical control of a person. The muzzle must not cause injury to the animal or interfere with its vision or respiration, but must prevent the animal from biting any human or animal. 
(3)  Signs. The owner of a vicious animal shall display in a prominent place on the owner's premises a clearly visible warning sign indicating that there is a vicious animal on the premises. The sign lettering must be at least two inches high. The owner shall also display either separately or in conjunction with the warning sign, a pictorial, symbolic or illustrative sign that conveys to children and those who do not read the idea of the presence of a vicious animal. Similar signs shall be posted on the animal's kennel, if any, in such a manner as to be clearly visible. 
(4)  Insurance. The owner of a vicious animal must provide proof to an animal control officer or designee that the owner has procured public liability insurance of at least $100,000.00, insuring the owner for any damage or personal injury which may be caused by such owner's vicious animal. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 14, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 14, 4-3-17) 
Sec. 18-45. - Violations-Impoundment of animals. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of an animal control officer or designee, and in compliance with any procedural requirements in this article, to seize and deliver to the designated animal center any and all animals, including livestock, poultry or fowl, dogs or cats, found in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Subject to any limitation or requirement in this article to the contrary, and provided an animal control officer consents, the owner of any animal impounded under the provisions of this article may claim such animal after paying any applicable impoundment fee to the designated animal center and otherwise following their rules and regulations. 
(c)  No impounded cat or dog shall be released unless proof is presented that the animal is in compliance with this article's vaccination and licensing requirements. 
(d)  Whenever an owner has had two prior impoundments of any animal it shall be a condition of the release of any subsequently impounded animal owned by that person that such animals shall be altered. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 15, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 15, 4-3-17) 
Sec. 18-46. - Impoundment for destruction. 
(a)  An animal control officer or designee may order the impoundment for destruction of an animal only when the animal: 
(1)  Has attacked, bitten or injured a human being or domestic animal and the circumstances indicate that there is a probability of additional similar conduct by such animal; 
(2)  Has been declared a vicious animal pursuant to section 18-41 and, if applicable, section 18-42, and the owner, if any is ascertainable, has failed to comply with the requirements and conditions for keeping a vicious animal as defined provided in section 18-44; or 
(3)  Poses a threat of serious harm to the public health or safety. 
(b)  Any animal impounded for destruction under the provisions of this section may be claimed by its owner only with an order issued by the municipal court after a hearing pursuant to section 18-48, and in compliance with any conditions of such an order. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 16, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 16, 4-3-17) 
Sec. 18-47. - Notice of impoundment for destruction. 
    Within two days of any impoundment for destruction under this article, an animal control officer or designee shall notify the animal's owner in writing of the impoundment, by personal service acknowledged in writing by the owner or certified by the server. In the alternative, service may be by certified mail and by posting on the animal owner's property. The notice shall advise of the owner's right to a hearing under section 18-48. Service of notice shall be deemed completed upon mailing. In the case of stray animals an attempt to notify the owner is not necessary. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 17, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 17, 4-3-17) 
Sec. 18-48. - Impoundment for destruction-Hearing. 
(a)  The owner of an animal impounded for destruction shall have the right, within five days after service of the notice under section 18-47, to personally serve upon an animal control officer, designee, or any police officer a written request for a hearing to contest the impoundment. An animal control officer or designee shall immediately file the request with the municipal court, and a hearing shall be held within five business days after such filing with the municipal court. 
(b)  The impoundment hearing shall be informal, and strict rules of evidence shall not apply. The owner may be represented by counsel, present oral and written evidence and cross examine witnesses. 
(c)  The municipal judge shall issue a decision within two business days after the close of the hearing under this section and shall notify the owner in writing of the decision. 
(d)  After considering all of the relevant evidence, the municipal judge may order the destruction of the impounded animal or may release the animal to its owner, conditional on the owner complying with the requirements for keeping a vicious animal as set forth in section 18-44 and/or complying with any other requirements necessary to protect the public health or safety, or may unconditionally release the animal to its owner. The municipal judge may in any event make the animal's release conditional upon the owner's payment to the designated animal center the costs of impoundment and boarding. 
(e)  If after proper notice the owner of an animal impounded under this article fails to appear at a hearing or fails to request a hearing, the animal may be destroyed. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 18, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 18, 4-3-17) 
Sec. 18-49. - Cruelty to animals prohibited. 
(a)  It is unlawful for anyone to beat, cruelly ill-treat, torment, overload, overwork or otherwise abuse an animal, or cause, instigate or permit any dogfight, cockfight, bullfight or other combat between animals or between animals and humans. 
(b)  It is unlawful for anyone to breed or train an animal for fighting with any other animal. 
(c)  Failure to provide acceptable standards of housing and care constitutes animal cruelty. 
(d)  It is unlawful for anyone to intentionally or knowingly leave a pet in a motor vehicle for longer than five minutes, knowing that the animal is not attended by an individual in the vehicle who is 14 years of age or older. 
(e)  This section is not intended to contravene the provisions for animal cruelty contained in the Texas Penal Code. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful to raise, keep or pen any livestock or any type of reptiles upon any premises within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 19, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 19, 4-3-17) 
Sec. 18-50. - Pets riding in motor vehicles. 
    It is unlawful to have any pet ride in a motor vehicle, except if it is humanely confined in an enclosed carrier, or the entire vehicle's doors are closed and all windows are raised, or it is securely tethered in a way which humanely precludes their ability to jump off or fall from the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 20, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 20, 4-3-17) 
Sec. 18-51. - Quarantine method and testing. 
(a)  When a dog, cat, or domestic ferret that has bitten a human has been identified, the custodian will place the animal (regardless of its vaccination status) in quarantine as defined in the V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, § 826.002, until the end of the ten-day observation period. 
(b)  The animal must also be quarantined if there is probable cause to believe that it has otherwise exposed a human to rabies. 
(c)  The observation period will begin at the time of the exposure. 
(d)  The animal must be placed in a department-licensed quarantine facility specified by the local rabies control authority and observed at least twice daily. However, the local rabies control authority may allow the animal to be quarantined in a veterinary clinic. As an alternative to quarantine at a department-licensed facility or a veterinary clinic, the local rabies control authority may allow home confinement. 
(e)  To allow home confinement, the following criteria must be met: 
(1)  A secure enclosure approved by the local rabies control authority must be used to prevent escape. 
(2)  The animal has been vaccinated against rabies and the time elapsed since the most recent vaccination has not exceeded the manufacturer recommendations for the vaccine. If an unvaccinated animal is not over 16 weeks of age at the time of the potential exposure, it may be allowed home confinement. 
(3)  During the confinement period, the animal's custodian must monitor the animal's behavior and health status and immediately notify the local rabies control authority if any change is noted. 
(4)  The local rabies control authority or a veterinarian must observe the animal at least on the first and last days of the home confinement. 
(5)  The animal was not a stray as defined in the V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, § 826.002, at the time of the potential exposure. 
(f)  If the potential rabies exposure described in subsection (b) of this section occurs in a city or county other than where the animal's custodian resides, the animal may be transferred to a department-licensed quarantine facility or a veterinary clinic in the city or county of the custodian's residence or allowed home confinement, if applicable, if there is mutual agreement to do so between the local rabies control authorities for the city or county where the exposure occurred and where the custodian resides. 
(g)  The alternative to quarantining (to include home confining) a dog, cat, or domestic ferret that has bitten or otherwise potentially exposed a person to rabies as described in subsection (a) of this section is to have the animal euthanatized in such a manner that the brain is not damaged and a suitable specimen submitted to a department-designated laboratory for rabies testing. A list of department-designated laboratories may be found on the department's website or may be obtained from any of the department's regional zoonosis control offices. 
(h)  A domestic animal that has potentially exposed a human to rabies and has been designated by the local rabies control authority as unowned may be euthanatized. If the animal is euthanatized, a suitable specimen shall be submitted for rabies testing. 
(i)  "Free-roaming animals" as used in this section includes animals that have been in captivity less than 200 days immediately prior to the potential exposure and those that are not in captivity. If the animal implicated in the potential exposure is a free-roaming high-risk animal, it shall be euthanatized and a suitable specimen submitted for rabies testing. If the animal implicated in the potential exposure is a high-risk animal that has been in captivity without contact with free-roaming animals for 200 days or more immediately prior to the potential exposure or is less than 200 days old, has always been in captivity without contact with free-roaming animals, and is the progeny of a dam that has been in captivity without contact with free-roaming animals for 200 days or more immediately prior to the potential exposure, the local rabies control authority shall conduct a risk assessment to gauge the probability that the animal could have been exposed to rabies and, therefore, poses a public health risk. If the probability that the animal implicated in the potential exposure could have had animal contact conducive to rabies transmission is low and the potential exposure poses a negligible public health risk, the local rabies control authority may require that the animal involved in the potential exposure be quarantined at a department-licensed quarantine facility or a veterinary clinic or confined elsewhere as deemed appropriate by the local rabies control authority for a 30-day observation period as an alternative to euthanatizing and testing. The local rabies control authority or a veterinarian must observe the animal at least on the first and last days of the quarantine or confinement that was deemed appropriate by the local rabies control authority. 
(j)  If the animal implicated in the potential exposure is a low-risk animal, neither quarantine nor rabies testing will be required unless the local rabies control authority has cause to believe the animal is rabid, in which case it shall be euthanatized and a suitable specimen submitted for rabies testing. 
(k)  The local rabies control authority may require an animal that has inflicted multiple bite wounds, punctures, or lacerations to a person to be euthanatized. If the animal is euthanatized, a suitable specimen shall be submitted for rabies testing. 
(l)  If the animal implicated in the potential exposure is not included in subsection (a), (f), (g), (h), (j), or (k) of this section or the portion of subsection (i) of this section pertaining to a free-roaming high-risk animal, the animal either will be euthanatized and a suitable specimen submitted for rabies testing or the local rabies control authority may require the animal to be quarantined at a department-licensed quarantine facility or a veterinary clinic or confined elsewhere as deemed appropriate by the local rabies control authority for the 30-day observation period as an alternative to euthanatizing and testing. The local rabies control authority's decision on whether to quarantine or euthanatize and test those other animals described in subsection (i) of this section will be determined by risk-assessment parameters as described in subsection (i) of this section. If the potential rabies exposure occurs in a city or county other than where the animal's custodian resides, the animal may be transferred to a department-licensed quarantine facility or a veterinary clinic in the city or county of the custodian's residence or allowed confinement deemed appropriate if there is mutual agreement to do so between the local rabies control authorities for the city or county where the exposure occurred and where the custodian resides. During the observation period, the animal's custodian must monitor the animal's behavior and health status and immediately notify the local rabies control authority if any change is noted. The local rabies control authority or a veterinarian must observe the animal at least on the first and last days of the quarantine or confinement that was deemed appropriate by the local rabies control authority. 
(m)  Any animal required to be quarantined under this section that cannot be maintained in secure quarantine shall be euthanatized and a suitable specimen submitted for rabies testing. 
(n)  All laboratory specimens referred to in subsections (g)-(k) of this section shall be submitted in accordance with Texas Administrative Code § 169.33 (relating to submission of specimens for laboratory examination). 
(o)  At the discretion of the local rabies control authority, assistance animals may not be required to be placed in quarantine (to include confinement) during the observation period. During the applicable observation period, the animal's custodian must monitor the animal's behavior and health status and immediately notify the local rabies control authority if any change is noted. The local rabies control authority or a veterinarian must observe the animal at least at the beginning and on the last day of the applicable observation period. 
(p)  Police service animals are exempted from quarantine per the V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code, § 826.048, including confinement. During the applicable observation period, the animal's custodian must monitor the animal's behavior and health status and immediately notify the local rabies control authority if any change is noted. 
(q)  Animals should not be vaccinated against rabies or receive other vaccinations or non-essential medications that may complicate assessment of behavioral change or health status during the observation period; however, animals may be treated for medical problems that are diagnosed by a veterinarian and are not related to rabies. If the animal becomes ill during the observation period, the local rabies control authority must be notified by the person having possession of the animal. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 21, 4-3-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 21, adopted April 3, 2017, added a new section 18-51, renumbering the former §§ 18-51 and 18-52 as 18-52 and 18-53. The historical notation remains with the affected sections. 
Sec. 18-52. - Enforcement. 
(a)  An animal control officer or designee is hereby granted the authority and it shall be their duty to carry out the functions of, and to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Should any person or business commit a nuisance, or allow the commission of any act or condition that creates a nuisance, the city attorney may take any action to enforce this or any ordinance to prevent and summarily abate and remove a nuisance. These actions may include but not be limited to allowing for municipal resources and personnel to: abate any premises or property, closure, condemn, remove any person or thing, court action, suspend, cancel, or void any license or permit issued by the city, and any and all other relief as may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 21, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 22, 4-3-17) 
Note- See note to § 18-51. 
Sec. 18-53. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  Any violation of this article shall be subject to both civil and criminal penalties. A criminal conviction shall be a class C misdemeanor. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. 
(b)  Any person found guilty of the violation of any provision of this article shall be punished as follows: 
First violation involving an altered animal ..... $50.00 
First violation involving an intact animal ..... $100.00 
Second violation involving an altered animal ..... $100.00 
Second violation involving an intact animal ..... $200.00 
Violations after second involving an altered animal ..... $200.00 
Violations after second involving an intact animal ..... $400.00 
(c)  In addition to the fine specified in subsection (b) hereof, the municipal court shall sentence owners, at their own cost, to complete a responsible owner course every time they are found guilty after a first violation. 
(d)  In the event the municipal judge allows community service in lieu of or in addition to the imposition of a fine, whenever possible such community service shall be served at an animal shelter or similar institution. 
(e)  Prior to sentencing in the case the owner of an intact animal is found guilty of or pleads no contest to a violation of a provision in this article, if the defendant represents that the animal will be altered, the municipal court may reset the sentencing, but only once and for no more than 60 days, for the purpose of allowing the defendant to present sufficient proof that the animal was altered after the finding of guilt or entry of the plea of no contest. Upon presentation of such proof the fines imposed pursuant to this section shall be reduced by one-half. 
(Ord. No. O-2015-23, § 22, 4-21-15; Ord. No. O-2017-12, § 23, 4-3-17) 
Note- See note to § 18-51. 
Secs. 18-54-18-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RABIES CONTROL 

Sec. 18-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means a warm-blooded animal. 
(Code 1976, § 6-61) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-102. - Quarantine of biting animal. 
    Any animal which bites or scratches a person shall be immediately reported to the city health officer and shall thereupon be securely quarantined at the direction of the city health officer for a period of ten days, and shall not be released from such quarantine except by written permission of the city health officer or under his direction. At the discretion of the city health officer such quarantine may be on the premises of the owner, at the shelter designated as the city pound, or at the owner's option and expense in a veterinary hospital of his choice. In the case of stray animals, or in the cases of animals whose ownership is not known, such quarantine shall be at the shelter designated as the city pound. 
(Code 1976, § 6-62) 
Sec. 18-103. - Duty of owner to surrender animal upon demand; redemption. 
    The owner, upon demand by the city health officer, shall forthwith surrender any animal which has bitten a human, or which is suspected as having been exposed to rabies, for supervised quarantine, the expense of which shall be borne by the owner. The animal may be reclaimed by the owner if it is adjudged free of rabies, upon payment of fees determined therefor by the city commission from time to time, and, if a dog, upon compliance with the licensing provisions set forth in article II, division 2, of this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 6-63) 
Sec. 18-104. - Disposition of dead rabid animal. 
    When rabies has been diagnosed in an animal under quarantine or rabies suspected by a licensed veterinarian, and the animal dies while under such observation, the city health officer shall immediately send the head of such animal to the state health department for pathological examination and shall notify the proper public health officer of reports of human contacts and the diagnosis. 
(Code 1976, § 6-64) 
Sec. 18-105. - Areawide quarantine-Imposition; duration. 
(a)  When the report provided for in this article indicates a positive diagnosis of rabies, the city health officer may order an areawide quarantine, and upon the invoking of such quarantine, no pet animal shall be taken into the streets, or permitted to be in the streets, during the period of quarantine. During such quarantine no animal may be taken or shipped from the city without permission of the city health officer. 
(b)  The quarantine imposed pursuant to this section shall remain in effect until the 181st day after the date on which the last case of rabies is diagnosed in a dog, cat, or other animal species that caused the city health officer to declare a quarantine, unless the city health officer, by declaration, removes the quarantine before that date. 
(Code 1976, § 6-65) 
Sec. 18-106. - Same-Vaccinations. 
    During the areawide quarantine period authorized by this article and as long afterward as the city health officer deems it necessary to prevent the spread of rabies, the health officer may require that all dogs three months of age and older shall be vaccinated against rabies. All vaccinated dogs shall be restricted, by leashing or confinement on enclosed premises, for 30 days after vaccination. During the quarantine period, the city health officer is hereby empowered to provide for a program of mass immunization by the establishment of temporary emergency canine rabies vaccination clinics strategically located throughout the area of the health jurisdiction. 
(Code 1976, § 6-66) 
Sec. 18-107. - Same-Redemption of strays restricted. 
    No animal which has been impounded by reason of its being a stray or unclaimed by its owner shall be allowed to be adopted from any animal shelter during the period of a rabies emergency quarantine, except by special authorization of the city health officer. 
(Code 1976, § 6-67) 
Sec. 18-108. - Destruction, isolation of bitten animals. 
    Animals bitten by a known rabid animal shall be immediately destroyed or, if the owner is unwilling to destroy the exposed animal, strict isolation of the animal in a kennel, designated by the city health officer, for six months shall be enforced. If the animal has been previously vaccinated within the time limits established by the public health service based on the kind of vaccination used, revaccination and restraint (leashing and confinement) for 30 days shall be carried out. 
(Code 1976, § 6-68) 
Sec. 18-109. - Destruction, removal of rabid animals. 
    No person shall kill or cause to be killed any rabid animal, any animal suspected of having been exposed to rabies, or any animal which has bitten a human, except as provided in this article, nor remove such animal from the city limits without written permission from the city health officer. 
(Code 1976, § 6-70) 
Sec. 18-110. - Surrender of carcass of exposed animal. 
    The carcass of any dead animal exposed to rabies shall, upon demand, be surrendered to the city health officer. 
(Code 1976, § 6-71) 
Sec. 18-111. - Failure to obey health officer. 
    No person shall fail or refuse to surrender any animal from quarantine or destruction as required in this article when demand is made therefor by the city health officer. 
(Code 1976, § 6-72) 
Sec. 18-112. - Report of bite cases. 
    It shall be the duty of every physician, or other medical practitioner, to report to the city health officer the names and addresses of persons treated for bites inflicted by animals, together with such other information as will be helpful in rabies control. 
(Code 1976, § 6-73) 
Sec. 18-113. - Report of suspected cases. 
    It shall be the duty of every licensed veterinarian to report to the city health officer any animal considered by him to be a rabies suspect. 
(Code 1976, § 6-74) 
Secs. 18-114-18-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMMERCIAL ANIMAL ESTABLISHMENTS AND SHELTERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Animal shelters, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 823; riding stables, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 827. 

Sec. 18-141. - Permit required. 
    No person shall operate a commercial animal establishment or animal shelter in the city without first obtaining a permit in compliance with this article. 
(Code 1976, § 6-81) 
Sec. 18-142. - Separate permit required for each facility. 
    Every facility regulated by this article shall be considered a separate enterprise requiring an individual permit. 
(Code 1976, § 6-82) 
Sec. 18-143. - Exception to permit requirement. 
    Persons operating kennels for the breeding of dogs or cats which handle fewer than ten animals may elect to license such animals on an individual basis. 
(Code 1976, § 6-83) 
Sec. 18-144. - Failure to obtain permit deemed violation. 
    Failure to obtain a permit before opening any facility covered in this article is a violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1976, § 6-84) 
Sec. 18-145. - Permit issuance. 
    Upon a sufficient showing by an applicant for a permit under this article of willingness and ability to comply with this chapter and all other applicable laws, a permit shall be issued upon payment of the applicable fee. 
(Code 1976, § 6-85) 
Sec. 18-146. - Conviction of cruelty to animals to require denial or revocation of permit. 
    No person who has previously been convicted of any offense under V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.11, or V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code §§ 821.021-821.025, or any other offense, whether against municipal, federal or state law, of this or any other state or country, which is reasonably equivalent to an offense of cruelty to animals, shall be issued a permit or license to operate a commercial animal establishment. If issued, such permit or license shall be revoked. 
(Code 1976, § 6-86) 
Sec. 18-147. - Withholding or falsifying application information. 
    If the applicant has withheld or falsified any information on the application for a permit or license under this article, the licensing authority may refuse to issue a permit or license or may revoke any such permit or license already issued. 
(Code 1976, § 6-87) 
Sec. 18-148. - Permit fees; exception. 
    Annual permits under this article shall be issued upon payment of the applicable fee as set out in this section. 
(1)  For each kennel authorized to house fewer than ten dogs or cats ..... $ 25.00 
(2)  For each kennel authorized to house ten or more, but fewer than 50, dogs or cats ..... 50.00 
(3)  For each kennel authorized to house 50 or more dogs or cats ..... 100.00 
(4)  For each pet shop ..... 75.00 
(5)  For each riding stable ..... 75.00 
(6)  For each animal auction ..... 50.00 
(7)  For each grooming shop ..... 50.00 
No fee shall be required of any veterinary hospital, animal shelter or government operated zoological park. 
(Code 1976, § 6-88) 
Sec. 18-149. - Reclassification for assessment of fees. 
    Any person who has a change in the category under which a permit was issued under this article shall be subject to reclassification, and any required increase of the permit fee shall be paid. 
(Code 1976, § 6-89) 
Sec. 18-150. - Permit period; renewal applications and applications for new facility permits. 
    The period for permits issued under this article shall be the calendar year. Renewal applications for permits may be made 30 days prior to the start of the calendar year. Application for a permit to establish a new commercial animal establishment under the provisions of this article may be made at any time. 
(Code 1976, § 6-90) 
Sec. 18-151. - Transferability of permit; fee. 
    If there is a change in ownership of a commercial animal establishment, the new owner may have the current permit transferred to his name for the remainder of the current calendar year upon payment of a transfer fee of $10.00 and a showing meeting the requirements of section 18-145. 
(Code 1976, § 6-91) 
Sec. 18-152. - Reapplication upon denial of permit; fee. 
    Any person having been denied a license or permit under this article may not reapply for such license or permit for a period of six months. Each reapplication shall be accompanied by a fee of $10.00. 
(Code 1976, § 6-92) 
Sec. 18-153. - Inspection. 
    It shall be a condition of the issuance of any permit or license under this article that the city or its agent shall be permitted to inspect all animals and the premises where animals are kept at any time during reasonable hours or regular business hours. If permission for such inspection is refused, the permit or license of the refusing owner may be revoked. 
(Code 1976, § 6-93) 
Sec. 18-154. - Revocation of permit, general grounds for. 
    The city may revoke any permit or license issued under this article if the person holding the permit or license violates or refuses or fails to comply with this article or any applicable law governing the protection and keeping of animals. 
(Code 1976, § 6-94) 
Sec. 18-155. - Duties and liabilities upon revocation of permit. 
    Any person whose permit or license under this article is revoked shall, within ten days thereafter, humanely dispose of all animals owned, kept or harbored by such person, and no part of the permit or license fee shall be refunded. 
(Code 1976, § 6-95) 
Chapter 22 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Fire limits. 
    The fire limits of the city shall be as shown and indicated on an official map thereof on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1976, § 7-1) 
Sec. 22-2. - Asbestos survey. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, are defined for purposes of this section as follows: 
    Asbestos survey shall mean an inspection of a building or facility to determine the location, quantity, and condition of asbestos containing material therein by taking samples for analysis or by visual inspection. 
    Commercial building shall mean all other buildings which are not defined herein as "residential buildings." 
    Demolition shall mean operations in which load-bearing structural members of a building are wrecked or removed. 
    Person shall mean any individual, partnership, company, association, trust, foundation, governmental subdivision or agency, or any other entity recognized by law as the subject or rights and duties whether operated for profit or not for profit. 
    Renovation shall mean additions to or alterations of the interior surfaces of a building for purposes of restoration by removal, repairing, and rebuilding. 
    Residential building shall mean a single-family structure primarily used or capable of being used for human habitation. 
(b)  Prior to issuance of a permit to any person for the renovation or demolition of any commercial building within the city limits of the City of Pharr an asbestos survey [shall] be conducted of the areas to be renovated or demolished. 
(c)  An asbestos survey shall not be required prior to issuance of a permit for the renovation or demolition of a residential building unless the renovation or demolition involves more than two contiguous residential building sites which are part of a commercial or public project such as an urban renewal project, a highway construction project, a project to develop a shopping center or mall, the construction of an industrial facility or other large private development. 
(d)  Any asbestos survey required herein shall be conducted by an individual licensed by the State of Texas to do an asbestos survey. The cost of the asbestos survey under subsections (b) and (c) shall be borne by the person seeking the permit. The cost of the asbestos survey under this subsection shall be borne by the seller of lessor. 
(e)  Any person who shall fail to have performed an asbestos survey as defined herein under circumstances when required herein under subsections (b) and (c) shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine or not more than $1,000.00. 
(Ord. No. O-99-01, §§ 1-5, 1-5-99) 
Secs. 22-3-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING AND STANDARDS COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, adopted August 17, 2010, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 22-26-22-35, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. O-2007-18, § 1, adopted April 3, 2007. 

Sec. 22-26. - Organization. 
(a)  Created; membership; removal of members; filling of vacancies; compensation. The building and standards commission shall be created, consisting of not less than seven members. Three members shall be chosen from the general public and four members shall be chosen from the following professions, with no more than two from each specific field: master electrician, master plumber, building contractor, and registered architect and professional engineer. The members shall be appointed for three-year terms. The members shall be residents and taxpayers of the city. Any member of the building and standards commission may be removed or replaced by the city commission, for cause, after a public hearing before the city's governing body, after prior written notice to the member setting out the charges against him or her; or shall be replaced by the city's governing body upon the occurrence of three consecutive unexcused absences from regular or special called meetings. A vacancy on the building and standards commission for an unexpired term shall be filled by a majority vote of the city commission. The members of the building and standards commission shall serve without compensation. 
(b)  Ex officio member. The director of planning or his authorized representative shall be an ex officio member of the building and standards commission without power of vote. 
(c)  Officers. Every year at the first annual meeting of the building and standards commission, there shall be elected by the members of the building and standards commission three officers: a chairman, vice-chairman and a secretary. 
(d)  Quorum. No matter shall be considered by the building and standards commission without the presence of at least four members of the commission. No order, requirement, decision or determination of the director of planning or his authorized representative may be reversed nor a decision made in favor of an applicant on any matter under the International Code Council (ICC), including the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International UrbanWild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code or affecting any variance from such codes without the affirmative vote of four members of the board. 
(e)  Rules of procedure. The building and standards commission shall establish its own rules of procedure for accomplishment of its duties and functions, provided that such rules shall not be in conflict with the laws of the state or the Charter or ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Sec. 22-27. - Meetings; public hearings. 
(a)  The building and standards commission shall meet at regular intervals to be determined by the chairman. Reasonable notice of the place, time and date of meetings shall be given to all members of the commission. All meetings of the building and standards commission shall be open to the public. 
(b)  At a public hearing relative to any case before the building and standards commission, any interested party may appear in person or be represented by agent or by attorney. The burden of proof shall be on the owner to establish the necessary facts to warrant favorable action of the board. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Sec. 22-28. - Records. 
(a)  The building and standards commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep a record of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of the director of planning and shall be a public record. 
(b)  As an ex officio member of the building and standards commission, the director of planning shall set up and maintain a separate file for each case presented before such board and keep a record of all notices published and posted. All records and files pertaining to such cases shall be permanent and official files and records of the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Sec. 22-29. - Notice of public hearing; posting and publication. 
(a)  Notice shall be given to the public and all interested parties in each case to be heard by the building and standards commission by publishing two times in the official newspaper of the city the date and time of the hearing, no more than 20 days and no less than five days prior to the meeting. 
(b)  A notice of the public hearing to be held before the building and standards commission shall be posted at city hall, and at the office of the director of planning, 72 hours prior to the meeting. 
(c)  No case shall be heard by the building and standards commission without being specifically identified on notices complying with this section. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Sec. 22-30. - Duties. 
    The building and standards commission shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To consider and determine appeals whenever it is claimed that the true intent and meaning of the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code and/or any of the regulations thereunder have been misconstrued or wrongly interpreted. 
(2)  To grant exceptions to the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code which will not be injurious or otherwise detrimental to the public health, safety, morals and general welfare. 
(3)  To determine a specific period of time in which the appellant must conform to the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code by either repairing, renovating, or demolishing those structures not in compliance. 
(4)  To grant one or more extensions of time, not to exceed 120 days each, from the date of such decision of the building and standards commission where it is determined that the time of performance as required by the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code causes undue hardship to the owner and such delay will not do harm to the public health, safety, morals and general welfare. Any such extension shall be at the discretion of the commission. Requests for additional extensions of time shall be filed with the director of planning or his authorized representative not less than 30 days prior to the expiration of the current extension. Requests for additional extensions of time shall be heard by the commission. 
(5)  To designate any conditions in connection with any exceptions granted to the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code and/or any extensions of time granted in which the appellant must be in conformance with such codes. 
(6)  To include the duties and responsibilities for the administration and oversight of the Pharr Main Street Program in an advisory capacity to the city's governing body to support and facilitate, through the Main Street Manager, community and public/private initiatives to revitalize the city's downtown as may be allowed under the program's guidelines and requirements, as per exhibit "A". This article abolishes and supersedes Resolution: R-2002-26. 
Each decision of the building and housing board shall also include the reasons for the board's decision. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Editor's note- Exhibit "A" referenced above is not set out herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the city offices. 
Sec. 22-31. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any property owner receiving written notice from the building official/inspector of one or more instances wherein his property fails to comply with the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code may, within 30 days following the date of such notice, enter an appeal in writing to the building and standards commission. Such appeal shall state the location of the property, the date of the notice of violations, and the number of such notice. The appellant must state the variance or modification requested, the reasons therefore, and the hardship or conditions upon which the appeal is made. 
(b)  In the case of a building or structure which, in the opinion of the building official, is unsafe or dangerous, the building official may, in his order, limit the time for such appeal to a shorter period. 
(c)  The building and standards commission may not reconsider a case which has been previously decided by it involving the same premises and the same instances of noncompliance, until one year has lapsed after the date it was considered by the commission. 
(d)  Where it is shown to the satisfaction of the building and standards commission that one or more owners of property affected by this article have not received notice pursuant to subsection (a) of this section or cannot attend a hearing set before the building and standards commission due to good faith presence outside the state, the commission may continue such hearing for up to 60 days or until such owner is properly notified of such hearing. If, at the time such continuance is allowed or at any time during such continuance, the building and standards commission determines that the condition of the premises in question is such that the premises constitute an immediate and serious threat to public health, safety, morals or general welfare, the commission may declare that such premises be closed to public occupancy, access and/or use pending a hearing as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Sec. 22-32. - Fees. 
    Upon notice of appeal being given to the director of planning and before such appeal shall be construed as having been perfected, the applicant must file with such notice of appeal to the commission a fee. Fee shall be $150.00 per appeal. The fee shall be for the purpose of recovering such administrative costs of processing requests and appeals called for by this article. Such fee shall be paid by the applicant and shall not be designed for restricting the applicant's ability to seek a hearing and/or to generate revenue for other than recovery of administrative costs incurred by the city. Immediately upon receipt of such application and fee, the director of planning shall note thereon the date of filing, and make a permanent record thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Sec. 22-33. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or agent thereof who shall violate a decision of the building and standards commission, or who shall fail to comply therewith, shall lose the benefit of any exceptions, variances, or extensions of time from the requirements of the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code previously granted by such commission. Any person, firm, corporation or agent thereof who shall fail to comply with any of the requirements of the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code, or who shall erect, construct, alter, demolish or move any structure, or who has erected, constructed, altered, repaired, moved or demolished a building or structure in violation of the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code, shall be punished by a fine of up to $1,000.00. Each separate day during which a violation as set out in this section is committed or continued shall be deemed a separate violation. For purposes of this section, a violation taking place or continuing during any portion of a day shall be deemed a full day's violation. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Sec. 22-34. - Appeal from building and standards commission. 
    Every decision of the building and standards commission shall be final, subject, however, to such remedy as any aggrieved party might have at law or in equity. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Sec. 22-35. - Provisions supplemental to city codes; conflicts. 
    This article shall be used in conjunction with the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code currently adopted by the city. All matters prescribed by the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code shall remain in effect. Where there is determined to be a conflict between this article and the ICC Electrical Code, International Energy Conservation Code, International Existing Building Code, International Fire Code, International Fuel Gas Code, International Mechanical Code, ICC Performance Code, International Plumbing Code, International Private Sewage Disposal Code, International Property Maintenance Code, International Residential Code, International Urban-Wild land Interface Code and the International Zoning Code, the provisions of this article shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-40, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Secs. 22-36-22-60. - Reserved.

(b)  Moving permits (manufactured homes excluded). 
(1)  A new wood frame house (driveway included): $100.00 
a.  A building code compliance report must be submitted to this department prior to moving the house. The inspections for the house must have been made by the jurisdiction having authority where the house was built or by a certified building inspector. 
b.  The seller or buyer must submit to the development services department a site plan showing the house setbacks and location of the driveway. 
c.  The house mover must be licensed and bonded with the city. With the approval of the house mover, the seller or buyer may obtain the moving permit. 
(2)  A used house older than five years (driveway included): $100.00. 
a.  The house must comply with the 2012 International Residential Code. 
b.  The building official or his deputy must conduct a visual inspection of the house prior to it being moved. 
c.  A $100.00 inspection fee, in addition to the moving permit, shall be paid by the seller or buyer before the moving permit is issued. 
d.  If the application for the moving permit is approved, the seller or buyer must submit to this department a site plan showing the house setbacks and location of the driveway. 
e.  The house mover must be licensed and bonded with the City of Pharr. With the approval of the house mover, the seller or buyer may obtain the moving permit. 
f.  Fifty cents per mile of travel round trip from city hall (non-refundable), if outside city limits. 
(c)  Demolition permits. 
(1)  Fifty dollars for a building of 500 square feet or less + $.10 per square foot after 500 square feet. 
(d)  Inspections' certificate of occupancy. 
(1)  It shall be illegal to occupy a house or building without a certificate of occupancy issued by the City of Pharr. 
a.  The construction of the house must be completely finished. 
b.  All-weather surface parking must be provided. 
c.  All utilities must be connected, (water, electricity and sewer drain) 
d.  All landscaping must meet ordinance requirements. 
(e)  Manufactured homes. 
(1)  [New manufactured homes.] A $50.00 placement fee (driveway included) shall be charged for the placement of a new manufactured home in a legally recorded subdivision for manufactured homes. 
a.  Prior to moving the home, the seller or buyer must submit to this department a manufactured home application and obtain the city's planning department's approval. 
(2)  [Used manufactured homes.] A $50.00 placement fee (driveway included) shall be charged for the placement of a used manufactured home in a legally recorded subdivision for manufactured homes. 
a.  The building official or his deputy must conduct a visual inspection of the manufactured home prior to it being moved. 
b.  A $100.00 inspection fee shall be paid by the seller or buyer before the placement fee permit is issued. Fifty cents per mile of travel round trip from city hall (non-refundable), if outside city limits. 
c.  If the manufactured home is in good condition and it complies with all applicable codes, the seller or buyer must submit to this department a manufactured home application. Prior to moving the home, the seller or buyer must obtain the city planning department's approval. 
(f)  Valuations. 
(1)  The city will determine the valuations of a building or an alteration by the use of "valuation data" as attached (see exhibit 1). 
(g)  Contractors' responsibilities. It shall be the duty of every contractor or builder who makes contracts for the construction or repairs of buildings or structures for which a permit is required to submit to the building safety division a license & permit bond in the amount of $5,000.00 or a $100,000.00 general liability insurance and pay license fee of $50.00 annually. The term of such license shall be 12 months after the license was issued. Said license may be revoked by the planning director upon complaint from the building official for violation of said code. The contractor may appeal such ruling before the board of adjustments and appeals by filing a written application for appeal, stating the grounds therefore within seven days from the time of such revocation. The contractor shall be ineligible to apply for a new license after such revocation for a period of six months. 
    A contractor or builder shall be identified as a person who makes contract for construction purposes and makes his/her livelihood in the construction business. 
(1)  All house movers shall furnish a good and sufficient bond in the sum of $5,000 to be approved by the building official, conditioned upon compliance with all building regulation and related ordinances of the city and laws of the state and the United States. 
(2)  The contractor/builder or house mover shall be responsible for code compliance and for any damages caused to city property. 
(3)  The building contractor shall maintain the construction site clean of all debris. Building inspections will not be conducted until the construction debris is removed. A dumpster or a fenced area for debris is required at the construction site. A $50.00 re-inspection fee must be paid by the building contractor if an inspection was denied because of construction debris.
