Sec. 22-63. - Interpretation of terms. 
(a)  Whenever the word "municipality" or the word "city" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the City of Pharr, Texas. 
(b)  Whenever the term "corporate counsel" or "city attorney" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the general counsel of this city. 
(c)  Whenever the term "building official" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the city building inspector or his duly authorized deputy or assistant. 
(Code 1976, § 7-19) 
Sec. 22-64. - Penalty for violation of code. 
    Anyone who violates this article shall upon conviction thereof be fined in any amount not less than $1.00 nor more than $1,000.00. Each day that the violation continues to exist is a separate offense. 
(Code 1976, § 7-20; Ord. No. O-2000-36, § 5, 8-1-00; Ord. No. O-2003-47, § 5, 11-4-03) 
Sec. 22-65. - Conflicting provisions. 
    In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the code adopted by this article and the provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations, the provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations shall prevail and be controlling. 
(Code 1976, § 7-21) 
Sec. 2-66. - International Existing Building Code adopted; amendments to. 
(a)  Adopted. A certain document, which is on file in the office of the city clerk of the City of Pharr, being marked and designed [designated] as the International Existing Building Code, 2012 edition, including Appendix chapters A1, A2, A3, A4, A5 and Appendix B (see International Existing Building Code Section 101.7, 2003 edition) as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the existing building code of the City of Pharr, in the State of Texas for regulating and governing the repair, alteration, change of occupancy, addition, and relocation of existing buildings, including historic buildings within the city's Historic Main Street District, and for historical buildings/landmarks outside the district, as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefore; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said existing building code on file in the office of the City of Pharr are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Amendments to. The following sections are hereby revised: 
Section 101.1 Insert: "City of Pharr". 
Section 1201.2 Insert: "2003". 
(Ord. No. O-2005-20, §§ 1, 2, 3-15-05; Ord. No. O-2013-32, § 1, 9-3-13) 
Secs. 22-67-22-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL CODE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-91. - Adoption of National Electrical Code. 
    The National Electric Code, 2011 Edition, is herein after adopted as the electrical code of the City of Pharr, Texas, and shall be known as the "City of Pharr Electrical Code." 
(Ord. No. O-93-11, § 1, 4-20-93; Ord. No. O-96-06, § 1, 2-6-96; Ord. No. O-99-32, § 1, 7-20-99; Ord. No. O-2002-41, § 1, 8-6-02; Ord. No. O-2013-32, § 1, 9-3-13) 
Sec. 22-92. - Local restrictions. 
    The following provisions shall prevail and be controlling within the city in the event of any conflict therewith and the provisions of the electrical code adopted by the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Minimum size of conductors: Whether solid or stranded, shall not be smaller than 20-amp rated, except for control circuits, flexible cords, fixture wire and signal circuits. 
(2)  Open wiring in or on insulators: Shall be permitted only by special permission. 
(3)  Concealed knob and tube wiring: Shall not be permitted in any installation. 
(4)  Metal clad cable: Types MC and AC cable shall not be approved for installation in concealed locations. 
(5)  Nonmetallic sheathed cable: Shall be limited to single-family dwellings and multiple-family dwellings. 
(6)  Service entrance cable shall not be used for meter services. 
(7)  Underground feeder and branch circuit cable, type UF: Shall follow the same restrictions as stated in subsection (5) of this section. 
(8)  Service entrance cable, type USE: Shall not be approved for direct burial installations. 
(9)  Minimum grounding electrode shall be five-eighths inch by eight feet copper clad. 
(10)  Temporary power poles and temporary power and light permits shall expire at the end of 90 days or at the completion of work for which it was issued, whichever occurs first. 
(11)  State health regulations. 
(Code 1976, § 11-148) 
Sec. 22-93. - Local utility rules and regulations. 
    Rules and regulations of the utility companies serving the city relating to point of service and meter location for the kind and character of service to be rendered as passed and approved by the city commission are incorporated in this article and made a part hereof. 
(Code 1976, § 11-149) 
Sec. 22-94. - Conformance required. 
    All electrical equipment and materials, and the installation thereof, shall be in conformity with the provisions of this article, the applicable statutes of the state, and any rules or regulations issued by authority thereof. 
(Code 1976, § 11-150) 
Sec. 22-95. - Evidence of conformity of equipment, materials. 
    Conformity of electrical equipment and materials with the current published electrical appliance and utilization equipment list, or the electrical construction materials list, or the hazardous location equipment list, of the Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., or an approved agency, shall be prima facie evidence that such equipment or materials are reasonably safe to persons and property. These lists and pamphlet shall be on file in the chief electrical inspector's office and are made a part of this article by reference. 
(Code 1976, § 11-151) 
Sec. 22-96. - Penalty for violation of article. 
    Anyone who violates this article shall upon conviction thereof be fined not to exceed $200.00. Each day that the violation continues to exist is a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-93-11, § 2, 4-20-93; Ord. No. O-2002-41, § 4, 8-6-02) 
Sec. 22-97. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized person means any person registered under the provisions of this article to do the work as permitted under the specific provisions of this article. 
    Electrical construction means all work and materials used in installing, maintaining or extending a system of electrical wiring and all appurtenances, apparatus or equipment used in connection therewith, inside or outside or attached to any building, structure, lot or premises. 
    Electrical contractor means any person engaged in the business of installing or altering, by contract, electrical conductors or equipment. Such term shall include any authorized person, whether actually doing electrical work or not, and any authorized person who subcontracts to do such work, but does not include bona fide employees by such contractor to do or supervise such work. 
    Electrician means a person who is engaged in the trade or business of electrical construction and who is qualified under the terms and provisions of this article. 
    Elevator contractor means any person licensed by the state who engages in the business of servicing, maintaining, installing, or altering the electrical conductors and equipment used to operate, limit or control electrically operated elevators. Such term shall include any authorized person, whether actually doing electrical elevator work or not, and any authorized person who subcontracts to do such work, but does not include bona fide employees employed by such contractor to do or supervise such work. 
    Escalator contractor means any person engaged in the business of servicing, maintaining, installing, or altering the electrical conductors and equipment used to operate, limit or control electrically operated escalators. Such term shall include any authorized person, whether actually doing electrical escalator work or not, and any authorized person who subcontracts to do such work, but does not include bona fide employees employed by such contractor to do or supervise such work. 
    Inspector means any individual who has been qualified and employed by the city as an electrical inspector. 
    Journeyman electrician means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications, training, and technical knowledge to install, maintain, and extend electrical conductors and equipment. Such person shall be capable of doing such work in accordance with plans and specifications furnished him and in accordance with standard rules and regulations governing such work. 
    Maintenance electrician means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications, training, and technical knowledge to repair, operate, and replace electrical conductors and equipment in a specific building or premises. 
    Master electrician means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications, training, and technical knowledge to plan, lay out, and supervise the installation, maintenance, and extension of the electrical conductors and equipment. 
    Registered means that the person has made application to the board of electricians and has satisfied such board that he is qualified to do the work stated in the application, that he has paid the necessary registration fees, and that his name is carried in the records of the chief electrical inspector as a person authorized to do the electrical work for which he is registered as defined in this article. 
    Special permission means the written consent of the office of the chief electrical inspector. 
    Special ruling means a written ruling filed in the office of the chief electrical inspector. 
    Specialist electrician means any individual who possesses the necessary qualifications to construct, repair, install or maintain specific electrical conductors and equipment under the specific classification of electrical work for which the specialist is qualified. 
Words used in any regulation or standard of the National Board of Fire Underwriters as a standard of good electrical practice shall, if defined in this section, have the meanings assigned them. 
Words relating to buildings and building use, when not otherwise separately defined, shall have meanings which conform to the meanings set out in the building and zoning ordinances of the city, otherwise they shall have their usual dictionary meanings. 
(Code 1976, § 11-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-98. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is the practical safeguarding of persons and of buildings and their contents from electrical hazards arising from the use of electricity for light, heat, power, radio, television, signaling, and for other purposes. 
(Code 1976, § 11-2) 
Sec. 22-99. - Scope. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall apply to all installations of, and work done on, electrical conductors, fittings, devices, motors, appliances, and fixtures, referred to in this article as "electrical equipment," within or on public and private buildings and premises, with exceptions as provided in this article. 
(b)  On all installations of electrical conductors or equipment to be made on all existing installations which are altered, all work shall be done in a manner that will conform with the requirements for a sufficient and safe electrical system as described in this article. 
(c)  Repair and maintenance work shall be such that if any electrical conductors or equipment are removed and later replaced, they shall be replaced in a manner which conforms with this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-3) 
Sec. 22-100. - Public utilities. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to installations used by electricity supply, electric railway, or communication agencies in the generation, transmission or distribution of electricity or for the operation of street railways, signals or the transmission of intelligence when located within or on buildings or premises used exclusively by such an agency or on public thoroughfares; provided, however, that such agencies excepted are operating under a franchise agreement with the city and are under the jurisdiction of the supervisor of public utilities or an officer of similar general jurisdiction. 
(Code 1976, § 11-4) 
Sec. 22-101. - Radio and television stations. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all electrical equipment used for power to supply radio and television transmitting equipment. 
(Code 1976, § 11-5) 
Sec. 22-102. - Federal buildings. 
    Buildings which are owned, leased, and/or occupied by the United States government shall be subject to all of the provisions of this article, including inspections and the payment of fees. 
(Code 1976, § 11-6) 
Sec. 22-103. - State, county and city buildings. 
    Buildings owned and occupied by the state, county and the city shall be subject to the provisions of this article but shall be exempt from the payment of permit fees. This exemption shall be claimed in writing. 
(Code 1976, § 11-7) 
Sec. 22-104. - Other buildings. 
    All other buildings within this city not specifically exempted by this article shall be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-8) 
Sec. 22-105. - Responsibility for safe work. 
    This article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility or liability of any party owning, operating, controlling or installing any electrical equipment for damages to persons or property caused by any defect therein, nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of the inspection or reinspection authorized in this article; or the certificate of approval issued as provided in this article; or by reason of the approval or disapproval of any equipment authorized in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-9) 
Sec. 22-106. - Energizing customer's service entrance conductors. 
    Only authorized employees of the local serving utility shall be permitted to make the connection between the local serving utility company's service conductors and the customer's service entrance conductors. 
(Code 1976, § 11-10) 
Secs. 22-107-22-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL INSPECTORS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 22-126. - Chief electrical inspector. 
(a)  Office created. There is hereby created the office of the chief electrical inspector. 
(b)  Qualifications. The person chosen to fill the office of chief electrical inspector shall be of good moral character, shall be possessed of such executive ability as is required for the performance of his duties and shall have a thorough knowledge of the standard materials and methods used in the installation of electrical conductors and equipment. Such person shall be well versed in approved methods of construction for safety to persons and property, and in the provisions of the National Electrical Code, as adopted in section 22-91. Such person shall have had at least five years' experience as an electrical inspector or in the installation of electrical equipment, or in lieu of such experience shall be a professional electrical engineer registered in accordance with the laws of the state. 
(Code 1976, § 11-22) 
Sec. 22-127. - Employment of other electrical inspectors. 
    The employment of electrical inspectors for the inspection of electrical installations, as provided for in this article, shall be authorized by the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 11-23) 
Sec. 22-128. - Appointment of inspectors. 
    The chief electrical inspector and the inspectors shall be appointed by the city manager with the approval of the city commission. Appointment and removal of any such person shall be in accordance with the rules and regulations of the city government. 
(Code 1976, § 11-24) 
Sec. 22-129. - Conflict of interest. 
    It shall be unlawful for the chief electrical inspector or any of the inspectors to engage in the business of selling, installing, or maintaining electrical conductors, devices, appliances, apparatus, or equipment, and they shall have no financial interest in any concern engaged in such business at any time while employed by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 11-25) 
Sec. 22-130. - Duties of chief inspector generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief electrical inspector to enforce the provisions of this article. The chief electrical inspector shall, upon approval of an application, grant a permit for the installation, extension, or alteration of electrical conductors and equipment, and shall make inspections of all electrical work, as provided for in this article. The chief electrical inspector shall keep complete records of all permits issued, inspections and reinspections made and other official work performed in accordance with the provisions of this article. The chief electrical inspector shall keep on file a list of inspected electrical appliances issued by Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., which list shall be accessible for public reference during regular office hours. 
(Code 1976, § 11-26) 
Sec. 22-131. - Liability of inspectors. 
    Where action is taken by the chief electrical inspector or any inspector to enforce the provisions of this article, such action shall be done in the name of, and on behalf of the city, and the inspectors in so acting for the city shall not render themselves personally liable for any damage which may occur to persons or property as a result of any act committed in good faith in the discharge of their duties. Any suit brought against any inspector by reason of such actions made on behalf of the city shall be defended by the city attorney until final termination of the proceedings contained therein. 
(Code 1976, § 11-27) 
Sec. 22-132. - Police power of inspectors. 
    The chief electrical inspector and the inspectors shall have full police power and shall have the right to arrest any person who violates any of the regulations of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-28) 
Sec. 22-133. - Assistance from police. 
    Whenever, in the opinion of an electrical inspector, it shall be necessary to call upon the police department for aid and assistance in making an arrest or stopping work, he shall have the authority to do so; and it shall be the duty of any member of the police department, when called upon by such inspector, to act immediately in giving the required assistance. 
(Code 1976, § 11-29) 
Sec. 22-134. - Right of entry. 
    The chief electrical inspector and the inspectors shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building or premises in the discharge of their official duties, or for the purpose of making any inspection, reinspection or test of the electrical equipment or installations contained therein. 
(Code 1976, § 11-30) 
Sec. 22-135. - Correction of dangerous equipment. 
    When any electrical equipment is found by an inspector to be dangerous to persons or property because it is defective or improperly installed, the person owning the electrical equipment shall be notified in writing and shall have any changes or repairs made as required by the electrical inspector which will place such equipment in safe condition. If such work is not completed as specified by the inspector in the notice, the chief electrical inspector shall have the authority to disconnect or order the disconnection of electrical service to the dangerous electrical equipment. In cases of emergency, when necessary for safety to persons or property, or when electrical equipment may interfere with the work of the fire department, the senior officer of the fire department at the site shall have the authority to immediately cause the disconnection of any electrical equipment. 
(Code 1976, § 11-31) 
Sec. 22-136. - Service of notices. 
    When any order or notice is issued pursuant to the provisions of this article to any person who cannot be found after a reasonable search, then such order or notice may be served by posting it in a conspicuous place upon the premises where the defects are alleged to exist. Such posting of the notice shall be considered equivalent to personal service of such order or notice. An order sent by registered mail in a sealed envelope with postage prepaid and directed to the last known address of the electrical contractor, owner, lessee or occupant of the premises shall be equivalent to personal service of such order. Electrical inspectors are hereby empowered to attach to electrical cabinets and equipment an official notice or seal to prevent the use of electricity. It shall be unlawful for any other person to place or attach such seal, or to break, change, destroy, tear, mutilate, cover, or otherwise deface or injure such official notice or seal posted by an electrical inspector. 
(Code 1976, § 11-32) 
Sec. 22-137. - Special rulings. 
    If a special ruling by the chief electrical inspector is necessary to govern electrical construction not covered by this article or by the National Electrical Code, whereby all wiring for similar types of electrical construction will be changed in the future, such special ruling shall first be approved by the board of electricians. A copy of such ruling shall be filed in the office of the chief electrical inspector, and additional copies shall be sent to each registered electrical contractor. 
(Code 1976, § 11-33) 
Sec. 22-138. - Special permissions. 
    The regulations of the National Electrical Code may be modified or waived by special permission in specific cases where such modification or waiver is reasonable and does not differ from the intent of this article. Such permission shall in all cases be obtained from the chief electrical inspector and confirmed in writing. A copy of the permission shall be filed in the office of the chief electrical inspector and additional copies shall be sent to each registered contractor. 
(Code 1976, § 11-34) 
Secs. 22-139-22-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 22-156. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to commence, begin, or proceed with the installation, or cause to be installed, electrical conductors or equipment within or on any building, structure or premises publicly or privately owned or to make or cause to be made alterations in, or additions to, electrical conductors or equipment until an electrical permit has been obtained as provided in this division. 
(Code 1976, § 11-103) 
Sec. 22-157. - Exceptions to permit requirement. 
    No electrical permit shall be required for the following electrical work: 
(1)  The replacement of lamps, fuses or the connection of portable electrical equipment to permanently installed receptacles. 
(2)  The installation of electrical conductors or equipment for or by a public utility in the generation, transmission, sale and use of electrical energy or in the transmission of intelligence as outlined in its franchise. 
(3)  Work involved in the manufacturing, repair or testing of electrical equipment or apparatus in the course of manufacture. 
(Code 1976, § 11-104) 
Sec. 22-158. - Temporary connections. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall prohibit the restoration on a temporary basis of electrical service under emergency conditions before the obtaining of a permit when approval of such work is obtained from the chief electrical inspector prior to the commencing of the work and inspection of such work is done as provided in this division. In such cases a permit shall be obtained immediately for such work, but in no case to exceed 48 hours from such installation. 
(Code 1976, § 11-105) 
Sec. 22-159. - Starting work without permit. 
    The chief electrical inspector is empowered to stop at once electrical work which has been begun without a permit having been secured in violation of the provisions of this division, and to order any and all persons engaged therein to stop and desist therefrom until permits are secured. Such action shall not defer any other penalties which may be imposed for the violation of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-106) 
Sec. 22-160. - Responsibility of owner, occupant to obtain permit. 
    The owner, agent, and/or lessee of the building or structure wherein or whereon any work is being, or to be, done under the provisions of this article shall determine that electrical permits are obtained as provided in this division, by a properly licensed person, before work is started, for all electrical work performed on the premises, and shall be subject to the penalties provided for the violation of this article for failure to do so. 
(Code 1976, § 11-107) 
Sec. 22-161. - Signs, elevators. 
    An electrical permit shall be secured for the installation of circuits and/or feeders which are provided for the supplying of electrical energy to a sign. A permit shall be secured for all electrical changes, installations and revisions that are done on electrical elevators. A permit shall not be required when electrical equipment on electrical elevators is being maintained by elevator contractors by repairs or replacement of any kind. 
(Code 1976, § 11-108) 
Sec. 22-162. - Classes of permits. 
    There shall be three classes of permits for electrical work, as follows: 
(1)  Specific permits. 
(2)  Annual permits for specific premises only. 
(3)  Annual permits for lighting maintenance contractors. 
(Code 1976, § 11-109) 
Sec. 22-163. - Application for permits-Generally. 
    Separate application for permit for each installation, describing the work to be done, shall be made to the chief electrical inspector by the person installing the work. The application shall be accompanied by such information as may be necessary to determine whether the installation as described will be in conformity with the requirements of this article. When required by the chief electrical inspector, the applicant shall state the size of conductors to be used for all services, mains, feeders, and subfeeders, size of main and subfeeder switches and fuses, the area to be served by such conductors and the basis used in computing the required sizes of such conductors. 
(Code 1976, § 11-110) 
Sec. 22-164. - Same-False information. 
    The applicant for a permit required by this division shall represent that the statements contained in such application are true and correct, and any misrepresentation or false statement thereon shall be grounds for revocation of the applicant's certificate of registration and cancellation of the permit issued. 
(Code 1976, § 11-111) 
Sec. 22-165. - Deviation from permit. 
    No deviation shall be made from the installation described in the permit without notifying the chief electrical inspector. 
(Code 1976, § 11-112) 
Sec. 22-166. - Specific permits. 
(a)  Specific permits when issued shall apply to a specific installation, alteration, addition or replacement of electrical conductors or equipment to be done within a specific single building, structure or premises. 
(b)  The chief electrical inspector shall issue a specific permit for each installation and alteration of electrical conductors or equipment where application for such permit has been made in accordance with the requirements of this article; provided, that no specific permit shall be issued unless the person applying for such permit is registered as an electrical contractor or elevator contractor and has in his employ, at the time the application is made, a registered electrician; and provided, that the inspection fees shall be paid; and provided, further, that the right of a homeowner to secure permits shall not be denied. 
(Code 1976, § 11-113) 
Sec. 22-167. - Permits for specific premises only. 
(a)  In lieu of a specific permit for each installation or alteration, a permit shall, upon application therefor, be issued to any person regularly employing one or more electricians including a registered master electrician for the installation, alteration, and maintenance of electrical equipment in or on a specific single building, structure or premises owned or occupied by the applicant for the permit. Before such permit is issued to any person, he shall file with the chief electrical inspector an affidavit form of application as required and furnished by the chief electrical inspector. The application shall contain a description of the premises on which work is to be done under the permit, and the name of the master electrician to be appointed and employed to do the work. 
(b)  The chief electrical inspector shall be notified if the master electrician is replaced by another master electrician who has qualified as required by this article. If the requirements of the annual permit as set forth in this division are not met, or if the work is not done in compliance with this article, the chief electrical inspector shall suspend all the rights conveyed by such permit until such time as all deficiencies have been corrected or the permit expires. Notice of such suspension shall be in writing to the person to whom the permit was issued. 
(Code 1976, § 11-114) 
Sec. 22-168. - Permits for lighting maintenance contractors. 
    Any person registered as a lighting maintenance contractor shall make application for a permit at the office of the chief electrical inspector. The permit shall be issued in lieu of specific permits for individual locations, however, the chief electrical inspector shall be furnished, in writing, the address of each location where lighting maintenance work is to be done before the work is commenced. If the work is not done in compliance with the requirements of this article, the chief electrical inspector may suspend all rights conveyed by the permit until such time as all deficiencies have been corrected. Notice of such suspension shall be in writing and addressed to the person to whom the permit was issued. 
(Code 1976, § 11-115) 
Sec. 22-169. - Circuses, revival tents, road shows and similar installations. 
(a)  Circuses, revival tents, road shows, exhibitions, concessions, tents and other installations of a similar nature that provide self-contained generating and distribution facilities shall obtain a temporary permit from the chief electrical inspector who shall be responsible for determining that all wiring used shall be reasonably safe to persons and property and that the work is done in a manner to render it safe from fire and electrical shock. The fee for this permit shall be $100.00. 
(b)  Circuses, revival tents, carnivals, road shows, exhibitions, concessions, tents, and other installations of a similar nature that do not provide self-contained generating equipment shall employ a registered electrical contractor in a supervisory capacity, who shall be responsible and obtain permits in the name of the owner, exhibitor or operator for all electrical work done on the premises. No electrical work except that covered by section 22-237 shall be done on a service and circuit basis as covered in section 22-171. Portable equipment, appliances, fixtures, switchboards and feeders shall be approved as specified in section 22-95. 
(c)  Permits issued under this section shall be of a temporary nature and the applicant shall state on his request the period of time the service is required and shall remove, or apply and receive a written extension of time for the wiring so approved, at the termination of the time requested. 
(d)  All wiring used in conjunction with public assemblies shall be safe to persons and property and the electrical inspector shall satisfy himself that the work is done in a manner to render it safe from fire and electrical shock. 
(Code 1976, § 11-116) 
Sec. 22-170. - Holiday decorations. 
(a)  All electrical decorations installed on public property or on streets, alleys, areas, or sidewalks accessible to the public shall be maintained during their period of operation by a registered electrical contractor. Permits shall be obtained for each contact made to the permanent wiring of the installation, stating the length of the festoon, the wattage connected, and, when requested by the chief electrical inspector, plans and details of the electrical installation. 
(b)  Permits issued under this section shall be limited to a specific period of time. At the termination of the period stated, or for any valid reason, in the judgment of the chief electrical inspector, the decorations shall be removed by the person obtaining the permit. 
(Code 1976, § 11-117) 
Sec. 22-171. - Permit and inspection fees. 
    It shall be illegal to do electrical work without a permit, unless authorized by the electrical inspector for urgent occasions. Any person granted a permit for electrical installation of conductors or equipment shall pay to the city an inspection fee in such an amount as specified below: 
(1)  Minimum fee per permit ..... $10.00 
a.  Permit fee ..... 10.00 
b.  Temporary pole ..... 10.00 
c.  Reinspection ..... 10.00 
d.  Working clearance ..... 20.00 
(2)  New service fees: 
a.  100 amps or less ..... 40.00 
b.  125 amps ..... 50.00 
c.  150 amps ..... 60.00 
d.  200 amps ..... 70.00 
e.  250 amps ..... 80.00 
f.  More than 250 amps ..... 100.00 
(3)  Change of or increase service ..... 20.00 
(4)  Relocate service ..... 20.00 
(5)  T.V. cable transformer ..... 20.00 
(6)  Inspection to re-set meters ..... 10.00 
(7)  Added circuits to panelboards ..... 20.00 
(8)  Mobile homes ..... 20.00 
(9)  That section of work controlled by each meter shall be charged according to the above fees. 
(10)  Temporary poles are to be used during construction or remodeling for a period of 12 months from the date the permit was issued. The director of planning or the electrical inspector shall notify the electrical power company to disconnect the service after the twelfth month. 
(Code 1976, § 11-118; Ord. No. O-2001-22, § 1, 7-17-01) 
Sec. 22-172. - Payment of fees. 
    All fees required under this division shall be due when electrical permits are issued. 
(Code 1976, § 11-119) 
Sec. 22-173. - Doubling of fee. 
    In case any work for which a permit is required by this division is started or proceeded with prior to the obtaining of such permit, the fee for such permit shall be doubled. The payment of such doubled fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with the requirements of this article in the execution of the work nor from other penalties prescribed in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-120) 
Sec. 22-174. - Issuance of permit. 
    If the chief electrical inspector shall find that the electrical work described in the permit application will conform with all legal requirements, and if the applicant has complied with all provisions of this article, a permit for such installation shall be issued. 
(Code 1976, § 11-121) 
Sec. 22-175. - Unlawful acquisition of permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to secure or furnish a permit for the installation, alteration, or repair of electrical conductors or equipment to any person not entitled to such permit under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-122) 
Sec. 22-176. - Violations of article not authorized. 
    The issuance of a permit under the provisions of this division shall not be taken as permission to violate any of the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-123) 
Sec. 22-177. - Performance of work restricted. 
    The work indicated on the application for a permit required by this division shall be performed only by the applicant, and no other person shall perform any of the electrical work shown on the application. 
(Code 1976, § 11-124) 
Sec. 22-178. - Wrongful use of permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, alter, or repair any electrical conductors or equipment by authority of a permit issued to and for the use of some other person. 
(Code 1976, § 11-125) 
Sec. 22-179. - Limitation of permits. 
    Each specific permit issued by the chief electrical inspector under the provisions of this division shall expire by limitation and become null and void if the work authorized by such permit has not been started within 30 days from the date of the issuance of such permit, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned at any time for a period of 30 days after the work is started. Before such work can be started again, a new permit shall be obtained. 
(Code 1976, § 11-126) 
Sec. 22-180. - Revocation of permits. 
    The chief electrical inspector shall have the right to declare a permit null and void if there has been misrepresentation of facts or any violation of the provisions of this article or for any other just cause. 
(Code 1976, § 11-127) 
Sec. 22-181. - Notice of completion of work; inspection. 
    Upon the completion of any electrical installation for which a permit has been obtained, it shall be the duty of the person making the installation to notify the electrical inspector, who shall inspect the installation within 24 hours, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and holidays, of the time such notice is given. 
(Code 1976, § 11-128) 
Sec. 22-182. - Procedure when work to be concealed. 
    When any electrical equipment is to be hidden from view by the permanent placement of parts of the building, the person installing the equipment shall notify the electrical inspector, and such equipment shall not be concealed until it has been inspected, approved, and authorized by the electrical inspector by written notice posted on the jobsite, or until three working days, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, shall have elapsed from the time of such notification. Where the concealment of electrical equipment proceeds continuously, the person installing such equipment may apply in writing to the chief electrical inspector for periodic inspections, but concealment of such work shall not be done until written notice has been posted on the jobsite. The electrical inspectors have the authority to require building contractors to open such work which in any manner conceals electrical wiring that has been closed without their knowledge or permission, and in no case shall inspectors issue clearance until satisfied that the work is in accordance with the provisions of this article. Inspectors shall also have the right to refuse to issue a clearance on any wiring that is concealed in such a manner that it cannot be fully determined that it has been done in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-129) 
Sec. 22-183. - Final certificate of approval. 
    When the electrical inspector finds the electrical installation to be in conformity with the provisions of this article, he shall issue to the person making the installation a certificate of approval, when requested, authorizing the use of the installation and connection to the supply of electricity and shall send a notice of such authorization to the agency supplying the electric service. The chief electrical inspector shall be deemed the judge of whether the installation of electric conductors and equipment has been made in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-130) 
Sec. 22-184. - Connection to installations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make connection to a supply of electricity or to supply electricity to any electrical equipment for which a permit is required, or which has been disconnected by the order of the chief electrical inspector, until a written certificate of approval has been issued by the electrical inspector authorizing the connection and use of such equipment; provided, however, that the electrical inspector may authorize a temporary connection in writing. 
(Code 1976, § 11-131) 
Sec. 22-185. - Reinspections. 
    The electrical inspector may periodically reinspect existing installations of electrical conductors and equipment. When the installation of any conductors or equipment is found to be in a dangerous or unsafe condition, the person owning, using, or operating the installation shall be notified in writing and shall make the necessary repairs or changes required to place such conductors or equipment in safe condition and have such work completed within the period specified by the chief electrical inspector. 
(Code 1976, § 11-132) 
Sec. 22-186. - Condemnation. 
(a)  If, in the judgment of the chief electrical inspector after inspection, the electric conductors, appliances or equipment in any building or structure are unsafe or dangerous to persons or property, the inspector has the authority to cause such wires or appliances to be disconnected from the source of electrical energy supplying these conductors or equipment, and may at his discretion seal the control switches for such conductors, appliances and equipment in an open or disconnected position, whereupon he shall give written notice to the owner or his agent or by posting such notice at the site and shall also notify the electric utility company serving the premises. Thereafter, it shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit electric current to be supplied to the electrical conductors, appliances or equipment so sealed until they shall have been made safe and the inspector shall have issued a certificate of approval to that effect. 
(b)  When the electrical inspector condemns all or part of any electrical installation, the owner may, within five days after receiving written notice thereof, file a petition in writing for review of such action of the electrical inspector by the electrical board, upon receipt of which the board shall at once proceed to determine the facts, and within five days shall make a decision in accordance with its findings. 
(Code 1976, § 11-133) 
Sec. 22-187. - Removal of dead wires and unused apparatus. 
    It shall be the duty of the electrical inspector to cause all dead wires, unused poles or electric apparatus on the outside of buildings or in streets or alleys to be removed at the expense of the owners thereof by giving such owners written notice thereof. 
(Code 1976, § 11-134) 
Sec. 22-188. - Interference. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to in any manner change or alter electrical conductors or equipment in or on any building. If in the course of the erection of a building or structure, electrical conductors or equipment are in such position as to interfere with the erection or completion of the structure, notice shall be immediately given the owner and/or authorized person installing the electrical conductors or equipment, and the needed change shall be made by such authorized person. 
(Code 1976, § 11-135) 
Secs. 22-189-22-205. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BOARD OF ELECTRICIANS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 22-206. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a board of electricians in and for the city. 
(Code 1976, § 11-78) 
Sec. 22-207. - Composition. 
    The persons selected to serve on the board of electricians shall be qualified and determined as follows: 
(1)  One registered electrical contractor who is an active master electrician. 
(2)  One representative of a local electrical power company. 
(3)  One person not an electrician who shall have a knowledge of residential, commercial and industrial building construction. 
(4)  Officer of the local fire or fire marshal department. 
(5)  Architect or engineer. 
(6)  The chief electrical inspector of the city, who shall be an ex officio member without voting privileges. 
    Two alternates selected to serve on the board of electricians shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  A registered electrician. 
(2)  A person of the general public who resides in Pharr. 
(Code 1976, § 11-79; Ord. No. O-99-34, § 1, 7-20-99) 
Sec. 22-208. - Appointment of members. 
    The members of the board of electricians shall be appointed by the city manager with the consent of the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 11-80) 
Sec. 22-209. - Tenure of office. 
    The members of the board of electricians shall hold office for a term of two years from the date of their appointment and qualification until the date of reappointment, or until their successors have been appointed and qualified. No board member, other than the ex officio member, shall serve consecutively for more than two consecutive terms. 
(Code 1976, § 11-81) 
Sec. 22-210. - Removal of members. 
    Any member of the board of electricians may be removed for cause by the city commission upon recommendation of such removal for cause by the city manager, or may be removed by the city commission without such recommendation if the city commission finds that the removal of a member is for the best interest of the public. 
(Code 1976, § 11-82) 
Sec. 22-211. - Quorum. 
    Four members of the board of electricians present at any meeting shall be required for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1976, § 11-83) 
Sec. 22-212. - Compensation. 
    The members of the board of electricians shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1976, § 11-84) 
Sec. 22-213. - Officers. 
    The board of electricians shall select a chairman and secretary at the first meeting of each calendar year. 
(Code 1976, § 11-85) 
Sec. 22-214. - Procedures. 
    The board of electricians shall prescribe a procedure and order of business for hearing applications by persons desiring to engage in the electrical business within the city, and for hearing appeals from the decisions of the chief electrical inspector. 
(Code 1976, § 11-86) 
Sec. 22-215. - Referral of applicants. 
    It shall be the duty of the board of electricians to refer all applicants for master electrician to the examining agency. 
(Code 1976, § 11-87) 
Sec. 22-216. - Qualification of applicants. 
    It shall be the duty of the board of electricians to pass upon the qualifications of all persons applying for certificates to do electrical work in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 11-88) 
Sec. 22-217. - Issuance of certificates. 
    There shall be issued certificates to such persons as shall pass a satisfactory examination as referred to in this division, but this certificate shall not authorize anyone to enter into a contract for or do any installation, maintenance or repair of any electrical work unless such person shall have paid his annual registration fee as required by this article. It shall be the duty of the board of electricians to supervise the issuance of certificates of registration for master electrician, maintenance electrician, and specialist electrician. 
(Code 1976, § 11-89) 
Sec. 22-218. - Hearing appeals. 
    Any person may file an appeal with the board of electricians for a review of any decision of the chief electrical inspector, provided that such appeal is made in writing within five days after such person shall have been notified of such decision by the electrical inspector. Upon receipt of such appeal, the board shall proceed to determine whether the action of the chief electrical inspector complies with this article and within five days shall make a decision in accordance with its findings. The decision of the board shall be final. 
(Code 1976, § 11-90) 
Sec. 22-219. - Records. 
(a)  The board of electricians shall keep a minute book in which shall be recorded all transactions and business of the board. The minute book and other records shall be kept in a manner designated by the board of electricians. 
(b)  The chief electrical inspector shall keep a record of all persons qualified by the board of electricians to whom a certificate of registration has been issued. The chief electrical inspector shall not be responsible for the record of any person whose registration has not been renewed and has thereby lapsed for a period of two years. 
(Code 1976, § 11-91) 
Secs. 22-220-22-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ELECTRICIANS 

Sec. 22-236. - Registration required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who is not registered as a qualified electrician in accordance with the provisions of this article to engage in the business of electrical construction or to make any repairs, alterations, additions, or changes to any existing system of electrical conductors, wiring, apparatus, or equipment within the limits of the city except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-46) 
Sec. 22-237. - Exceptions from registration requirement. 
    The following classes of work may be carried out by persons who are not registered electricians: 
(1)  The replacement of lamps, fuses or equivalent and the connection of portable devices to suitable receptacles which have been permanently installed. 
(2)  The installation, alteration or repairing of any wiring, devices, or equipment for the operation of signals or the transmission of intelligence, where such wiring, devices, appliances, or equipment operates at a voltage not exceeding 50 volts between conductors and do not include generating or transforming equipment. 
(3)  The installation, alteration or repair of electric wiring, devices, appliances and equipment installed by or for an electrical public service corporation operating under a franchise from the city when for the use of such corporation in the generation, transmission, distribution, or metering of the electrical energy or for the use of such a corporation in the operation of street railways, signals, or the transmitting of intelligences. 
(4)  Any work involved in the manufacture or test of electrical materials, devices, appliances, or apparatus, but not including any installation of wiring other than that required for testing purposes if such equipment as complete is approved by the chief electrical inspector before it is installed or used within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 11-47) 
Sec. 22-238. - Temporary registration. 
    Any person operating in one or more of the classes of registration set out in section 22-240 in any area which becomes a part of the city by annexation or otherwise, and who is not, at the time of annexation, registered in such class or classes shall apply to the board of electricians for a temporary certificate of registration. Such temporary registration shall be valid for a period of six months to allow time for the applicant to prepare for and be examined by the examining agency in the manner provided for in this article for the various classes of registration and shall entitle the holder to operate only in the city's newly annexed area. Temporary certificates of registration shall not be renewable or transferable. 
(Code 1976, § 11-48) 
Sec. 22-239. - False representations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself as a registered electrician of any class set out in this division or to use the words "electrical contractor," "master electrician," "electrician," or words of similar import or meaning on signs, cards, stationery, or by any other manner whatsoever, unless such person is properly registered within the meaning of the words used as provided in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-49) 
Sec. 22-240. - Classification of registration. 
    Electrical registration shall be in the classifications listed below: 
(1)  Electrical contractor. 
(2)  Master electrician. 
(3)  Journeyman electrician. 
(4)  Maintenance electrician. 
(5)  Master sign electrician. 
(6)  Journeyman sign electrician. 
(7)  Elevator electrician. 
(8)  Residential electrician. 
(Code 1976, § 11-50; Ord. No. O-99-33, § 1, 7-20-99) 
Sec. 22-241. - Application for registration. 
(a)  To secure a certificate of registration as a qualified and competent electrician in any of the classes set out in this division, an application shall be made in writing and addressed to the board of electricians. The application shall show the applicant's name and such other information as may be prescribed by the board, and shall be made out on forms available in the office of the chief electrical inspector. 
(b)  Applicants for a certificate as electrical contractor, lighting maintenance contractor, elevator contractor, or building maintenance operator shall file with the application an affidavit setting forth the names of the persons who are the owners of the business or who are the officers of the firm who own the business and the name and address of the person who shall be responsible for the business. The applicants shall appear in person if requested by the board of electricians and be examined as provided in this article. 
(c)  Applicants for an examination as master electrician shall show evidence as being qualified in the electrical field or a graduate of a recognized technical school or college, and shall file with the application an affidavit showing that such applicant is not less than 21 years of age and shall have had at least five years' experience in the installation, alteration, repair, and maintenance of electrical conductors, equipment and apparatus or an experience equivalent thereto. Such applicants shall appear before the chief electrical inspector in person. 
(d)  Applicants for a certificate as maintenance electrician or specialist electrician shall appear in person before the board of electricians and be examined as prescribed in this article. Upon presentation to the chief electrical inspector of a certificate signed by the chairman or the secretary of the board of electricians stating the name and address of the applicant, the classification applied for, and that he has passed the required examination, and after the applicant has paid to the city the registration fee prescribed in this division, the chief electrical inspector shall register in the name of the applicant a certificate of registration. 
(Code 1976, § 11-51) 
Sec. 22-242. - Proof of qualification for registration. 
    Before any applicant for master electrician or electrical contractor is considered, he shall show evidence that he has successfully passed the examination as prepared and given by the Southern Standard Building Code Congress, International (Texas standard electrical examinations). A letter or a certificate issued by the examiner is sufficient. The city will continue to honor electrical certifications issued by the Valley Building Officials' Association prior to the effective date of this section, as amended. 
(Code 1976, § 11-52; Ord. No. O-94-22, § 1, 7-5-94) 
Sec. 22-243. - Reexaminations. 
    If an applicant for a master electrician license fails to pass his first examination, he shall not be examined again prior to the expiration of two calendar months from the date of such first examination. If the applicant fails to pass the second examination, he shall not be examined again prior to the expiration of six calendar months from the date of his last such examination. If the applicant fails to pass the third examination, he shall not be examined again prior to the expiration of 12 calendar months from the date of his last such examination. 
(Code 1976, § 11-53) 
Sec. 22-244. - Fees for examination and registration. 
(a)  The fees for examination shall be payable to the examining agency. Each applicant for an electrician's certificate shall pay to the examining agency the examination fee as specified. A separate fee shall be paid each time an applicant takes an examination. An applicant who fails to take the examination following the date of his application shall forfeit his fee unless an excuse is obtained prior to the examination date and provided a new application is filed before the next regular examination. 
(b)  An annual registration fee is not required to issue a City of Pharr certificate to a State of Texas licensed electrician. The certificate shall be valid from January 1 and end December 31 of the same year. 
(Code 1976, § 11-54; Ord. No. O-2004-66, § 1, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 22-245. - Bond or liability insurance for master electricians. 
    Each person, before receiving his license or renewal license as master electrician, shall make, execute and deliver to the board of city code enforcement department a corporate surety bond in the principal amount of $2,000.00, payable to the city, conditioned upon compliance with the provisions and regulations of this article and of the National Electrical Code, as adopted in this article, for electrical work within the city. In lieu of such bond, a license applicant may present proof of current prepaid liability insurance of $100,000.00 or more per person and for each occurrence for bodily injury, property damage, products and completed operations. Such bond or liability insurance shall be delivered or presented on an annual basis. 
(Code 1976, § 11-55; Ord. No. O-91-16, § 1, 5-28-91) 
Sec. 22-246. - Contractors-Individuals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of electrical contractor, lighting maintenance contractor, elevator contractor, or building maintenance operator without being registered in the manner set forth in this division, and without indicating the name by which the business shall be known. 
(b)  No electrical contractor shall establish, maintain, or advertise a place of business at any location within the city under any name other than that registered with the office of the chief electrical inspector. Any person desiring to engage in the business of electrical contracting or lighting maintenance contracting shall make application for registration at the office of the chief electrical inspector. Upon the filing of such application in proper form, and the payment of the registration fee as provided for in this division, the chief electrical inspector shall register the applicant as an electrical contractor, or lighting maintenance contractor, and shall issue to the applicant a certificate of registration, provided he has qualified, and has registered the proper address of his established place of business. 
(c)  An electrical contractor's certificate shall entitle the holder thereof to engage in the business of, and to secure permits for, the installation, addition, alteration, servicing, replacing, removing, or repair of any electrical conductors, apparatus, appliances, devices and equipment. 
(d)  If an electrical contractor shall engage in the installation, alteration or repair of any elevator equipment, then he shall have his contractor's certificate approved for such work. 
(e)  Any person engaged in the electrical contracting business shall be a qualified master electrician or shall have continuously in his employ a qualified master electrician, who shall have active supervision over, and be responsible for, carrying out the provisions of this article in its entirety. 
(f)  A lighting maintenance contractor's certificate shall entitle the holder thereof to engage in the business of repair and maintenance of lighting fixtures only, and such person engaged in the lighting maintenance contracting business shall have continuously in his employ a qualified journeyman who shall have active supervision over, and be responsible for, carrying out lighting maintenance. The chief electrical inspector shall be notified in writing if the journeyman electrician is replaced by another journeyman electrician who has qualified as required by this division. An elevator contractor's certificate shall entitle the holder thereof to engage in the business of, and to secure permits for, the installation, repairs, and alteration of any electrical wiring and equipment connected with the installation of electrical elevators. The actual work of installation shall be under the direct supervision of a qualified master, journeyman, or specialist elevator electrician. 
(g)  The office of the chief electrical inspector is hereby authorized to withhold inspections and the issuance of permits to any registered contractor who: 
(1)  Fails to correct any defect, error, or deficiency in any work installed under the authority of an electrical permit within ten calendar days after written notification thereof from the office of the chief electrical inspector. 
(2)  Fails to pay any just indebtedness to the city for inspection fees charged for specific permits. 
(h)  Every electrical contractor, lighting maintenance contractor, and elevator contractor shall have an established place of business. 
(i)  Only one registration fee shall be required in cases where the master electrician and electrical contractor are one and the same. 
(Code 1976, § 11-56) 
Sec. 22-247. - Same-Firm or corporation. 
(a)  Any person holding an electrical contractor's license shall appoint or employ or shall be a qualified master electrician. 
(b)  Any person who has been appointed or employed as a master electrician by a registered electrical contractor shall register with the chief electrical inspector in writing on a form to be furnished by the electrical inspector's office. When an applicant has complied with the requirements of this division, the chief electrical inspector shall certify him as a master electrician to a specific registered electrical contractor by placing his name on the contractor's registration certificate and by identification card issued to the registered master electrician. 
(c)  The master electrician shall perform the work or supervise and direct the installation, alteration, repair, and maintenance of electrical conductors and equipment authorized by permits issued under the authority of this article. Whenever a master electrician shall leave or be discharged from the employ of any person who is required by this article to appoint or employ a master electrician, a notice in writing thereof shall be given immediately by both the employer and the master electrician to the chief electrical inspector's office, and the permit privileges of such a person shall, without further order or action, stand suspended until the employment or appointment and registration of another master electrician as provided for in this division. When a master electrician has not acted in the capacity of a master electrician or in a supervisory position on electrical work in any city for a continuous period of two years, he may be required to be reexamined before being certified as a registered master electrician. 
(d)  No master electrician shall be permitted to use his certificate of registration in order to qualify more than one electrical contractor's license at any time. 
(e)  The master electrician, after having passed the required examination, shall be granted a certificate, showing that he has the necessary qualifications to install or direct the installation of electrical conductors, devices, apparatus, and equipment. It shall be unlawful for any master electrician to permit his name to be used or to knowingly permit himself to be held out as the officer or employee in a supervisory capacity of any person holding an electrical contractor's certificate unless he is, in fact, an officer or employee and does, in fact, supervise the installation of electrical work performed by such persons. 
(Code 1976, § 11-57) 
Sec. 22-248. - Registration of journeyman electricians. 
(a)  Applicants for a journeyman electrician's certificate shall not be less than 18 years of age and shall have had at least four years' experience in the installation, alteration, repair, and maintenance of electrical conductors and equipment, or an equivalent experience thereto. 
(b)  The master electrician and/or the electrical contractor shall designate the journeyman electricians in his employment. 
(Code 1976, § 11-58) 
Sec. 22-249. - Registration of maintenance electrician. 
(a)  Applicants for a maintenance electrician's certificate may be registered master electricians or may apply for registration as a maintenance electrician. 
(b)  Each applicant for a maintenance electrician's certificate not holding a master registration card shall be required to answer a reasonable number of questions in writing to the examining board of electricians to show that he has sufficient knowledge and training to perform maintenance work. 
(c)  The certificate of a maintenance electrician shall bear the name of the person by whom the holder thereof is regularly employed and the place of employment, and shall become null and void and re-registration shall be required each time a change is made in employer and place of employment. 
(d)  A maintenance electrician's certificate shall entitle the holder thereof to engage himself in the employ of any person holding an electrical building maintenance operator's certificate under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1976, § 11-59) 
Sec. 22-250. - Registration of specialist electrician. 
(a)  Applicants for a specialist electrician's certificate may be registered master electricians or may apply for registration as a specialist electrician in the following class: Elevator electrician (state licensed). 
(b)  Each applicant for a specialist electrician's certificate not holding a master electrician registration card may be required to answer a reasonable number of questions in writing to the board of electricians to show that he has sufficient knowledge and training to perform the work for the class of electrical specialist applied for. A specialist electrician's certificate shall entitle the holder to engage himself in the employ of any person holding a license to do the work for which the specialist has been qualified. 
(Code 1976, § 11-60) 
Sec. 22-251. - Expiration of registration. 
    Every certificate of registration provided for in this division shall expire at midnight on December 31 following the date of its issuance. 
(Code 1976, § 11-61) 
Sec. 22-252. - Renewal of registration. 
(a)  Every certificate of registration provided for in this division shall expire at midnight on December 31 following the date of its issuance, and shall be renewed by the chief electrical inspector upon application and upon payment to the city of the required renewal fee; provided, however, that if during the preceding year the applicant has been convicted of a violation of this article, it will be necessary for him to be reexamined by the examining agency. Should any certificate lapse for more than 30 days, the holder shall be considered as a new applicant, and the initial registration fee shall be charged. 
(b)  Should the holder of a certificate of registration provided for in this division take up another occupation or profession or otherwise indicate that he has abandoned his occupation as an electrician or contractor, even though he may apply for registration each year, he may be required to be examined every two years in order to maintain his registration. 
(Code 1976, § 11-62) 
Sec. 22-253. - Registration not transferable. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to lend, rent or transfer his certificate of registration issued under this division or any rights therein contained to any other person, and for any person to make use of any such rights which are not actually his own. It shall be unlawful for any person other than the chief electrical inspector or his inspector to alter or amend in any manner such certificate of registration. 
(Code 1976, § 11-63) 
Sec. 22-254. - Display of certificate. 
    Every holder of a certificate as an electrical contractor, lighting maintenance contractor, elevator contractor, and building maintenance operator shall display his certificate in a conspicuous place in his principal place of business. Every holder of a certificate as a registered master, journeyman, maintenance or specialist electrician shall carry his registration card or certificate on his person at all times while doing electrical work and shall produce and exhibit such card or certificate when requested by any inspector or officer of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 11-64) 
Sec. 22-255. - Supervision required. 
    In the actual work of installing, maintaining, altering or repairing any electric conductor or equipment for which a permit is required, there shall be present and in direct supervision a qualified electrician of the proper classification. Should it come to the notice of the chief electrical inspector or his inspectors that such supervision and control are not being maintained, the inspector may order the work to be discontinued and the person to whom the permit has been issued shall discontinue further work until proper supervision has been employed or supplied; provided, that nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the employment of apprentices or unskilled laborers assisting a person duly registered and qualified under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 11-65) 
Sec. 22-256. - Revocation of certificate; appeal. 
    If the holder of any certificate of registration issued under this division willfully violates any provision of this article, is incompetent to comply with such provisions, or such person has been found guilty of violating any such provisions, the chief electrical inspector may at any time give notice in writing to the holder of such certificate that the certificate of registration has been revoked and canceled. Such notice of revocation or cancellation of such certificate shall become final after the expiration of ten days from the date of service of such notice upon the holder of such certificate, unless on or before the expiration of such ten-day period the holder of such certificate shall file with the board of electricians a written appeal addressed to such board, in which it is requested that such board grant a hearing to the holder of such certificate of registration upon the question of whether or not the certificate issued by the board of electricians shall be canceled and revoked. The appeal, if made and filed as prescribed in this section, shall operate as a stay or postponement of such revocation and cancellation of the certificate issued, until such time as the board of electricians shall grant a hearing and make a final adjudication upon the question of whether or not such certificate should be canceled, such hearing to be held within 15 days after the date of the filing of such appeal. The judgment or decision of a majority of such board shall be final and conclusive as to all parties. At such hearing before the board of electricians, the chief electrical inspector may be represented by the city attorney. 
(Code 1976, § 11-66) 
Secs. 22-257-22-285. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PLUMBING CODE 

Sec. 22-286. - Plumbing code adopted. 
    The International Plumbing Code, 2012 Edition or the most recent edition, excluding A, promulgated by the International Code Council, is adopted as the plumbing code of the city, and shall be known as the City of Pharr Plumbing Code. 
(Ord. No. O-95-04, § 1, 1-3-95; Ord. No. O-98-12, § 1, 2-3-98; Ord. No. O-2000-35, § 1, 8-1-00; Ord. No. O-2003-51, § 1, 11-4-03) 
Sec. 22-287. - Amendments and additions to code. 
(a)  Schedule of permit fees. 
Plumbing fixtures, per fixture ..... $  6.00 
Gas line ..... 10.00 
Water or sewer line ..... 10.00 
Backflow preventer ..... 20.00 
Private sewer connection ..... 10.00 
Public sewer tap or connection (unless otherwise stated) ..... 175.00 
Sand/grease trap ..... 20.00 
Miscellaneous ..... 10.00 
Permit ..... 20.00 
(b)  Water conservation. The drainage soil rough-in tests for the plumbing system shall be made by forcing air into the system until there is a uniform gauge pressure of five pounds per square inch (psi) or sufficient to balance a ten-inch (254 mm) column of mercury. 
(Ord. No. O-95-04, § 2, 1-3-95; Ord. No. O-98-12, § 2, 2-3-98; Ord. No. O-2000-35, § 2, 8-1-00; Ord. No. O-2001-23, § 1, 7-17-01; Ord. No. O-2003-51, § 2, 11-4-03) 
Sec. 22-288. - Requirement of license and bond or liability insurance. 
    Prior to the issuance of any permit to perform plumbing work within the corporate limits of the city, a plumbing contractor shall be required to be licensed as a master plumber by the state board of plumbing examiners. The plumbing contractor shall furnish a good and sufficient bond in the sum of $5,000.00. In lieu of such bond, a licensed applicant may present proof of current prepaid liability insurance for the amount of $100,000.00 or more per person and for each occurrence for bodily injury, property damage, products and completed operations. Such bond or liability insurance shall be delivered or presented on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. O-95-04, § 3, 1-3-95; Ord. No. O-98-12, § 3, 2-3-98) 
Sec. 22-289. - Interpretation of terms. 
(a)  Whenever the term "municipality" or "city" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the City of Pharr, Texas. 
(b)  Whenever the term "corporate counsel" or "city attorney" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the attorney of this city. 
(Code 1976, § 26-19) 
Sec. 22-290. - Penalty for violation. 
    Anyone who violates this article or the code adopted in this article shall upon conviction thereof be fined in any amount not less than $1.00 nor more than $1,000.00. Each day that the violation continues to exist is a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-95-04, § 4, 1-3-9; Ord. No. O-98-12, § 4, 2-3-98; Ord. No. O-2000-35, § 5, 8-1-00; Ord. No. O-2003-51, § 6, 11-4-03) 
Sec. 22-291. - Connections with sewer or gas system, license required. 
    Before any person shall do any work or make any connections with the sewer system or the gas system in the city, or do any plumbing work connected or intended to be connected with the sewer or gas system, he shall be licensed as provided in the Plumbing License Law of 1947, as amended, such law being Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6243-101. 
(Code 1976, § 26-1) 
Sec. 22-292. - Conflicting provisions. 
    In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the code adopted by this article and applicable provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations, the provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations shall prevail and be controlling. 
(Code 1976, § 26-18) 
Sec. 22-293. - Definitions. 
(a)  Plumbing fixtures. A receptacle or device that has water supply and is equipped with a drain. 
(b)  Gas line. A gas system inside or outside a building. The system may be a new installation, repairs to an existing line or replacement of the pipes. 
(c)  Water or sewer line. A water or sewer system that is repaired or replaced. 
(d)  Private sewer connection. A sewer connection made to an existing sewer pipe on private property. An example would be two or more buildings on one lot connected to the same sanitary sewer drain. 
(e)  Public sewer tap or connection. A tap or connection made to the city's sewer main. The fee is based according to the size of the water meter. 
(f)  Miscellaneous. Any item that is not addressed in the schedule of permit fees. Examples would be inspections or reinspection of plumbing systems. 
(Ord. No. O-2003-51, § 3, 11-4-03) 
Secs. 22-294-22-320. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GAS CODE 

Sec. 22-321. - International Fuel Gas Code adopted. 
    The International Fuel Gas Code, 2012 Edition or the most recent edition, promulgated by the International Code Council, Inc., is hereby adopted as the gas code of the city, and shall be known as the City of Pharr Fuel Gas Code. 
(Ord. No. O-95-03, § 1, 1-3-95; Ord. No. O-2000-27, § 1, 6-6-00; Ord. No. O-2003-49, § 1, 11-4-03; Ord. No. O-2013-32, § 1, 9-3-13) 
Sec. 22-322. - Interpretation of terms. 
(a)  Whenever the word "municipality" or "city" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the City of Pharr, Texas. 
(b)  Whenever the term "corporate counsel" or "city attorney" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the city attorney of this city. 
(Code 1976, § 26-34) 
Sec. 22-323. - Administration and enforcement. 
    The provisions of the gas code adopted by the provisions of this article shall be administered and enforced in compliance and conformity with the provisions of chapter 1 of the Standard Plumbing Code adopted by the provisions of section 22-286. 
(Code 1976, § 26-36) 
Sec. 22-324. - Licenses. 
    The provisions of section 22-288 relative to the licensing and examination of plumbers shall apply with equal force and effect to the licensing of gasfitters. 
(Code 1976, § 26-37) 
Sec. 22-325. - Penalty for violation. 
    Anyone who violates this article shall upon conviction thereof be fined in any amount not less than $1.00 nor more than $1,000.00. Each day that the violation continues to exist is a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-95-03, § 2, 1-3-95; Ord. No. O-2000-27, § 2, 6-6-00; Ord. No. O-2003-49, § 4, 11-4-03) 
Sec. 22-326. - Conflicting provisions. 
    In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the code adopted by this article and applicable provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations, the provisions of this Code of Ordinances, state law or city ordinances, rules or regulations shall prevail and be controlling. 
(Code 1976, § 26-33) 
Secs. 22-327-22-350. - Reserved.

    The International Mechanical Code, 2012 Edition or the most recent edition, with Appendix A, promulgated by the International Code Council, Inc., is adopted as the mechanical code of the city, and shall be known as the City of Pharr Mechanical Code. 
(Ord. No. O-95-02, § 1, 1-3-95; Ord. No. O-98-09, § 1, 2-3-98; Ord. No. O-2000-44, § 1, 10-3-00; Ord. No. O-2003-52, § 1, 11-4-03; Ord. No. O-2013-32, § 1, 9-3-13) 
Sec. 22-351.1. - Amendments and additions to code. 
(a)  Schedule of Permit Fees (mechanical work, other than gas piping systems): 
(1)  For issuing each permit: $10.00. 
(2)  Fee for inspecting heating, ventilating, duct work, air-conditioning, exhaust, venting, combustion air, pressure vessel, solar, fuel oil and refrigeration systems and appliance installations shall be:

(a)  Whenever the word "municipality" or "city" is used in the code adopted by this article, it shall be construed to mean the City of Pharr, Texas. 
(b)  Whenever the words "corporate counsel" or "city attorney" are used in the code adopted by this article, they shall be construed to mean the city attorney of this city. 
(Code 1976, § 15-17) 
Sec. 22-353. - Requirement of license and insurance. 
    Prior to the issuance of any permit to perform air conditioning work within the corporate limits of the city, an air conditioning contractor shall be required to be licensed by the state department of licensing and regulation and such licensee shall show proof of personal liability insurance as required by the Texas Air Conditioning and Refrigeration Contractor License Law. 
(Ord. No. O-95-02, § 2, 1-3-95; Ord. No. O-98-09, § 2, 2-3-98) 
Sec. 22-354. - Penalty for violation. 
    Anyone who violates this article shall upon conviction thereof be fined in any amount not less than $1.00 nor more than $1,000.00. Each day that the violation continues to exist is a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-95-02, § 3, 1-3-95; Ord. No. O-98-09, § 3, 2-3-98; Ord. No. O-2000-44, § 5, 10-3-00; Ord. No. O-2003-52, § 5, 11-4-03) 
Sec. 22-355. - Conflicting provisions.
