Chapter 34 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; civic and cultural facilities and affairs, ch. 30. 
State Law reference- Emergency management, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.001 et seq.; local and interjurisdictional emergency management, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.101 et seq.; false alarm or report, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.06. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 34-1-34-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2012-23, §§ 1-21, adopted June 19, 2012, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 34-26-34-35, 34-51-34-53, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1976, §§ 9-1-9-8, 9-10, 9-11, 9-23-9-25. 

Sec. 34-26. - Legal authorities. 
(a)  The City of Pharr hereby adopts and incorporates Texas Government Code, Chapters 380, 791, 418, Texas Local Government Code Chapters 203, 240, 352, and Pharr City Charter Article III, Section 2 allowing for interlocal cooperation agreements between public entities, management and preservation of records, regulatory powers, disaster declaration and procedures, and emergency status and procedures. 
(b)  The city's presiding officer, the mayor, shall be the head of government for all ceremonial purposes and military law. In the absence of the mayor or if unable to act, the mayor pro tem shall perform the duties of mayor. In the absence of or inability of the mayor [pro] tem to act, the alternate mayor pro tem shall perform the duties of mayor in accordance with state law. 
(c)  An emergency management coordinator may be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the city's administration in accordance with established hiring practices. The coordinator shall be subject to the city's personnel policies, directives, and other applicable ordinances at all times. 
(d)  The coordinator shall be responsible for conducting a program of comprehensive emergency management within the city and for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in section 34-29 of this article. He/she may delegate authority for execution of these duties, but ultimate responsibility for such execution shall remain with the coordinator. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 1, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-27. - Powers of coordinator. 
    The powers and duties of the coordinator shall include: (1) on-going survey of actual or potential major hazards which threaten life and property within the city; and (2) an on-going program of identifying and requiring or recommending the implementation of measures which would tend to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of such hazards if a disaster did occur. As part of his/her responsibility in hazard mitigation, the coordinator shall supervise the development of an emergency operations plan for the City of Pharr, and shall recommend that plan for adoption by the presiding officer and board of commissioners along with any and all mutual aid plans and agreements which are deemed essential for the implementation of such emergency operations plan. The duties of the coordinator shall also include the causing of a survey of the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies and services which could be used during an emergency, as provided for herein, as well as a continuing study of the need for amendments and improvements in the emergency operations plan. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 2, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-28. - City participation in county emergency management. 
    The presiding officer is hereby authorized to join with the County Judge of the County of Hidalgo and the mayors of the other cities in said county in the formation of a committee, board, or authority for the County of Hidalgo and shall have the authority to cooperate in the preparation of a joint emergency operations plan and in the appointment of an emergency management coordinator with county wide jurisdiction, as well as all powers necessary to participate in a county-wide program of emergency preparedness insofar as said program may affect the City of Pharr. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 3, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-29. - Duties of presiding officer. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the City of Pharr's presiding officer shall include the following: 
(1)  The direction and control of the actual emergency operations of the Pharr emergency management plan and organization as well as the training of emergency personnel. 
(2)  The determination of all questions of authority and responsibility that may arise within related to the emergency management of the city. 
(3)  The maintenance of necessary liaison with other municipal, county, district, state, regional, federal, or other emergency response organizations. 
(4)  The marshaling, after declaration of an emergency as provided for above, of all necessary personnel, equipment or supplies from any department of the city to aid in the carrying out of the provisions of the emergency operations plan. 
(5)  The issuance of all necessary proclamations as to the existence of an emergency and the immediate operational effectiveness of the City of Pharr emergency operations plan. 
(6)  The issuance of reasonable rules, regulations or directives that are necessary for the protection of life and property in the City of Pharr. Such rules and regulations shall be filed in the office of the city secretary and shall receive widespread publicity unless publicity would be of aid and comfort to the enemy. 
(7)  The supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements, in cooperation with the representatives of the state and of other local political subdivisions of the state, and the drafting and execution, if deemed desirable, of an agreement with the county in which said city is located and with other municipalities within the county, for the county-wide coordination of emergency response efforts. 
(8)  The supervision of, and final authorization for the procurement of all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions that may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency response management within the city. 
(9)  The authorizing of agreements, after approval by the city attorney, for use of public and private property for public shelter and other purposes. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 4, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-30. - [Operational organization.] 
    The operation of the City of Pharr's emergency management shall consist of the officers and employees of the city so designated by the coordinator in the emergency operations plan, as well as all organized volunteer emergency preparedness associations or groups. The functions and duties of this organization shall be distributed among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the emergency operations plan. Such plan shall set forth the form of the organization, establish and designate divisions and functions, assign tasks, duties and powers, and designate officers and employees to carry out the provisions of this article. Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles, and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the State of Texas and of the agencies and branches of the United States Federal Government. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 5, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-31. - [Simulation of signal.] 
    Any unauthorized person who shall operate a siren or other devise so as to simulate a warning signal, or the termination of a warning, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this article and shall be subject to the penalties imposed by this article. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 6, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-32. - [Effect of emergency orders, rules, and regulations.] 
    At all times when the orders, rules, and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this article shall be in effect, they shall supersede and override all existing ordinances, orders, rules, and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. This article also supersedes Ordinances O-2009-38 and successor ordinances to O-2009-38 as may be amended from time to time to the extent that off-premises advertising shall be allowed should the City of Pharr, at its discretion, deems it necessary due to emergency uses and advertising for approved locations that further the health, safety, and general welfare of the community, inhabitants, and property without charge or expense to the City of Pharr. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 7, 6-19-12) 
Cross reference- Sign Ordinance, § 106-31 et seq. 
Sec. 34-33. - [Conflict with other rules and regulations.] 
    This article shall not be construed so as to conflict with any state or federal law or regulation or with any military or naval order, rule, or regulation. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 8, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-34. - [Exemption from liabilities.] 
    This article is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health, and safety and neither the City of Pharr, the agents and representatives of said city, nor any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, nor any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with, any order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons as the result of said activity. Any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily and without compensation grants to the City of Pharr a license of privilege, or otherwise permits the city to inspect, designate and use the whole or any part or parts of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending or practice enemy attack shall, together with his successors in interest, if any, not be civilly liable for the death of, or injury to, any person on or about such real estate or premises under such license, privilege or other permission or for loss of, or damage to, the property of such person. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 9, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-35. - [Expenditures; approval required.] 
    No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the city in carrying out any emergency response activity authorized by this article without prior approval by the board of commissioners, nor shall any person have any right to bind the city by contract, agreement, or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 10, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-36. - [Obstruction of enforcement; unlawful identification; penalty.] 
    It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to obstruct, hinder, or delay any authorized person of the city's emergency management and response unit in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this article, or to do any act forbidden by any rule or regulation issued pursuant to the authority contained in this article. It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear, carry or display any emblem, insignia or any other means of identification as a member of the city's emergency management and response unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials. Convictions for violations of the provisions of this article shall be punishable by fine not to exceed $200.00. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 11, 6-19-12) 
Sec. 34-37. - [Affirmation of personnel.] 
    Each employee or any individual that is assigned a function or responsibility shall solemnly swear or affirm to support and defend the Constitution and laws of the United States and the State of Texas, and the ordinances of the City of Pharr. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-23, § 12, 6-19-12) 
Chapter 38 - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Board of city development, art. IV, § 5. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; manufactured homes and trailers, ch. 78; planning, ch. 98; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 114; subdivisions, ch. 118; zoning, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Enterprise zone ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance relating to enterprise zones, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Secs. 38-2-38-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 38-26. - Created; duties. 
    There is hereby created a community development council for the city. The council shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city commission, and its purpose shall be to gather and coordinate data; to assist in the development of a system of priorities in the area of community development for the city; and otherwise to implement a program of community development in appropriate ways in keeping with relevant federal guidelines. 
(Code 1976, § 2-79; Ord. No. O-96-40, § 1, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 38-27. - Composition. 
    The community development council of the city shall be composed of 11 members, which members shall meet the relevant criteria of the Federal Community Development Act, as amended. Two of such members shall be residents of Census Tract No. 213; two of Census Tract No. 214; two of Census Tract No. 215; two of Census Tract No. 216; two of Census Tract No. 217; and one member at large shall be a resident of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 2-80; Ord. No. O-96-40, § 2, 9-3-96) 
Sec. 38-28. - Membership; quorum. 
(a)  Terms. The terms of office of the members of the council shall be as follows: 
(1)  Initial appointment. The city commission shall appoint three members to a term of one year; four members to a term of two years; and the remaining four members to a term of three years in accordance with Exhibit A, attached to Ordinance No. O-96-40 and incorporated herein by reference. 
(2)  Subsequent terms. Following the expiration of the initial terms, all appointments shall be for a term of three years. 
(3)  Vacancies. In the event a vacancy occurs prior to the expiration of a full term, the city commission shall appoint a new member to complete the unexpired term. All members shall serve until their successors have been appointed and qualified unless [they] forfeit their office as set out herein. 
(4)  No term limits. Any member may be reappointed upon the completion of their term. There is no limit to the number of terms any person can serve. 
(b)  Quorum. Any six members of the community development council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. The affirmative vote of a majority of those attending any meeting at which there is a quorum present shall be necessary to pass any motion, recommendation or resolution of the community development council. 
(c)  Removal from office. Any member of the community development council may be removed from office for any cause by the commission upon notice and hearing. 
(d)  Attendance. Any member of the community development council who fails to attend three consecutive meetings and whose absence is not excused by the council, or who is absent from more than 50 percent of the meetings in any calendar year will automatically forfeit their position as a member of the council. The chairman or vice-chairman of the council shall notify the city commission of such forfeiture and request that a new member be appointed. 
(Code 1976, § 2-81(a)-(d); Ord. No. O-96-40, § 3(a)-(d), 9-3-96) 
Sec. 38-29. - Officers. 
    The community development council shall elect a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary at the first meeting of the calendar year for a term of one year. The vice-chairman shall preside in the absence of the chairman. 
(Code 1976, § 2-81(e); Ord. No. O-96-40, § 3(e), 9-3-96) 
Secs. 38-30-38-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARD OF CITY DEVELOPMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 38-56. - Established. 
    Pursuant to section 5 of article IV of the Charter, the board of city development is hereby reestablished. 
(Ord. No. O-92-26, § I, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 38-57. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of the board of city development is to promote the growth, orderly development, improvement, and the increase of property values of the city through the funding of a chamber of commerce activity, an industrial development activity, and other nonprofit agencies which the board may deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. O-92-26, § II, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 38-58. - Composition; terms of members. 
    The board of city development shall consist of 11 members, who are resident citizens of the city; six of such members shall serve a term of two years or until their successors have been appointed and qualified, and five members shall serve a term of four years or until their successors have been appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. No. O-92-26, § III, 7-7-92) 
Sec. 38-59. - Appointment of members. 
(a)  The following resident citizens are appointed to the board of city development, because of their positions with the city, for four-year terms or until their successors in office are qualified and appointed: 
(1)  The mayor; 
(2)  The city manager; 
(3)  The finance director; 
(4)  Two city commissioners elected by the mayor and city commission. 
(b)  Each city commissioner shall appoint one resident citizen from the public at large to the board of city development for two-year terms or until their successors have been appointed and qualified. Every two years, such appointments shall be brought before the city commission for action. In making such appointments, the individual commissioners should appoint individuals with experience in the business, banking or financial areas to give the board the background and expertise to effectively carry out its responsibilities under the city Charter. 
(Ord. No. O-92-26, §§ IV, V, 7-7-92) 
Secs. 38-60-38-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PHARR RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVE PROGRAM 

Sec. 38-81. - General purpose and objectives. 
    The city, by adopting the following tax rebate policy and basic incentives, will promote the development and redevelopment of high-end single-family homes within the city. However, any rebate awarded before the expiration of the Pharr Residential Incentive Program shall carry its full term according to its rebate agreement approved by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-56, § 3, 12-18-17) 
Sec. 38-82. - Definitions. 
    Abatement or tax rebate means a temporary whole or partial exemption from city ad valorem taxes on eligible real property for a specific period of time on the difference between: 
    The amount of increase in the appraised value (as reflected on the certified tax roll of the county appraisal district) resulting from improvements begun after the execution of a written tax abatement 380 incentive agreement and the appraised value of such real estate prior to the execution of a written tax abatement 380 incentive agreement (as reflected on the most recent certified tax rolls of the county appraisal district for January 1 prior to the date on which the tax abatement was executed). 
    Base value is the value of the real property as determined by the county appraisal district, as of January 1 prior to the execution of the contract or agreement. 
    High-end single family home is defined as a single family detached dwelling or single family residence. For the purpose of the Pharr Residential Incentive Program it is one dwelling structure with a minimum gross living area of 2,500 square feet. The residence must have open space on all four sides and may not be attached to any other structure that has walls that extend from the ground to the roof. It must have its own heating system, separate electrical meter, facilities for living, sleeping, cooking and eating therein. It is designed to be occupied by just one household, family or social living unit consisting of a parent(s) and their children, whether natural or adopted and other relatives if living with the primary group. 
    Base value is the value of the real property, including land, as determined by the county appraisal district, as of January 1 prior to the execution of the contract. 
    Building Code means the city-adopted code pursuant to the International Building Code. 
    Capital investment includes only real property improvements such as new facilities and structures, site improvements, facility expansion, and facility modernization. Capital investment does NOT include land acquisition costs and/or any existing improvements, or personal property (such as machinery, equipment, and/or supplies and inventory). 
    City of Pharr rebate policy statement means the policy adopted by the city commission and economic development corporation II. 
    Energy star program is an international standard for energy efficient consumer products originated in the United States of America. 
    Gross living area is considered all living space "under air conditioned space" such as main rooms, bedrooms, hallways and kitchen. Unfinished attics, patios, porches and garages are not included in this measurement. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-56, § 3, 12-18-17) 
Sec. 38-83. - Eligible projects. 
    Projects that are eligible for the Pharr Residential Development Incentive Program must meet the following minimum criteria: 
    Development site for a residential subdivision must be a minimum of ten acres; 
    Lot sizes must be a minimum of 10,000 square feet; 
    All homes must be single family residential district zoned; 
    A lot and home built must meet a minimum ad valorem appraised value of $225,000.00 or 2,500 square feet of gross living area; 
    All construction must meet all the city subdivision standards and the building code regulations. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-56, § 3, 12-18-17) 
Sec. 38-84. - Municipal participation. 
(a)  Option 1. Fifty percent of public infrastructure cost. A developer may instead choose to have reimbursed 50 percent of the total dollar amount spent on materials for public improvements (water, sewer, paving and drainage) that will be dedicated to the city. The total dollar amount will be agreed upon cost estimates submitted to the development services department during the pre-construction phase of the subdivision process. In order to invoke this provision the following must be adhered to: 
(1)  Must be an eligible project under this article; 
(2)  No variances can be requested for or issued during the subdivision process; 
(3)  All subdivision requirements must be completed and verified by the City; and 
(4)  The subdivision shall be duly recorded in the offices of Hidalgo County. 
Calculation and Procedure: 
    Once 50 percent of the lots have acquired building permits for construction of homes with a gross living area of 2,500 square feet or more the developer may request reimbursement from the city in the amount 50 percent of the agreed upon public improvement construction cost. 
    Once all requirements are met and approved by the city, and within 30 calendar days of final approval, the city will issue the developer a reimbursement check in the amount outlined in the 380 incentive agreement which shall be up to 50 percent of all qualified city public infrastructure. This 380 incentive agreement shall be for four years maximum, effective 30 calendar days after subdivision recording. 
Residential Developer Incentive Program-Developer Reimbursement After Building Permits are Pulled

(b)  Option 2: Tax rebates. Residential property taxes may be rebated to the developer on a per lot basis after a house is constructed, valued by the county appraisal district and taxes have been paid to the city. Tax rebates will be assigned as follows and will not be for more than five years total: 
(1)  Year 1: One hundred percent of the increase; 
(2)  Years 2 and 3: Seventy-five percent of the increase; 
(3)  Years 4 and 5: Fifty percent of the increase. 
    Year 1 begins once the first home has paid property taxes in the development, or one year from the granting of the rebate program by the city commission to the developer regardless of whether a house has paid property taxes, whichever comes first. The 380 incentive agreement shall be for five years maximum 
(Ord. No. O-2017-56, § 3, 12-18-17) 
Sec. 38-85. - Permit fee rebates. 
(a)  For developers, the following fee rebates of 50 percent of the payment shall also be available. 
(1)  Right-of-way (curb and street cut) fees. 
(2)  Floodplain fees. 
(3)  Water permit fees. 
(4)  Sprinkler system permit fees. 
(5)  Plat application fees. 
(6)  Demolition fees. 
(7)  Zoning application fees. 
(8)  Subdivision development fees. 
(b)  All permit fee rebates must be applied for on a per subdivision basis. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-56, § 3, 12-18-17) 
Sec. 38-86. - Procedural steps. 
(a)  Application and review of submission for all permit fee rebates . 
(1)  The non-refundable application fee for incentives and/or rebates is $20.00. 
(2)  The applicant must complete and submit a city "Application for Residential Incentives" and pay the appropriate application fee to the department of development services, as applicable. 
(3)  The department of development services will review the application for accuracy and completeness. 
(4)  Department of development services will evaluate a completed and certified application based on: 
a.  The project's increase in the value of the tax base. 
b.  Costs to the city (such as infrastructure participation, etc.). 
c.  Other items which the city and the applicant may negotiate. 
(5)  If criteria and guidelines are met, the department of development services will submit to the city manager an approval and recommendation to enter into a 380 incentive agreement for consideration by the city commission. 
    All applications shall go through administrative review and final approval will be approved upon city commission approval. 
(b)  Payment of municipal property tax rebate. 
(1)  The property taxes for the property has to be paid to the city. 
(2)  After the property taxes are paid, from the amount paid, the percentage of rebate depending on the year of the project will then be paid to the person/entity that the city commission has awarded the rebate to. 
(3)  At no time will this rebate be advanced, it can only be paid once the city has received the property taxes paid on the property. 
(c)  Application execution and agreement. 
(1)  Once an applicant's eligibility is verified and a 380 incentive agreement is approved by the city commission the department of development services will inform appropriate departments administering the incentives. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-56, § 3, 12-18-17) 
Chapter 42 - COURTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; law enforcement, ch. 70. 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.001 et seq.; general law for municipal courts of record, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 30.481 et seq.; court procedures, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.01 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 42-1-42-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COURT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 42-26. - Jurisdiction. 
    The municipal court shall have jurisdiction within the city with the power to hear and determine all cases of violation of this Code, the ordinances of the city, and all other cases of which municipal courts are given jurisdiction by state law. 
(Code 1976, § 20-2) 
State Law reference- Jurisdiction of municipal court, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.003. 
Sec. 42-27. - Rules of practice and procedure. 
    The rules of practice and procedure as prescribed by state law governing trials in the state justice of the peace courts shall govern the procedure and practice of the municipal court; and the city commission may prescribe such additional rules of practice and procedure as may not be inconsistent with state law. 
(Code 1976, § 20-3) 
State Law reference- Court procedures, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.01 et seq.; justice courts, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 27.001 et seq. 
Sec. 42-28. - Clerks-Appointment. 
    There shall be appointed by the city manager a clerk and such deputy clerks of the municipal court as may be deemed necessary for the proper, efficient operation of such court. 
(Code 1976, § 20-7) 
State Law reference- Municipal court clerk, V.T.C.A., Government Code §§ 29.010, 29.011. 
Sec. 42-29. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The clerk, and deputy clerks, of the municipal court shall perform all the duties and have all the powers bestowed upon clerks of municipal courts by state law. Any clerk or deputy clerk so appointed may act as the official clerk of the municipal court and perform all acts incident to such office. 
(Code 1976, § 20-8) 
State Law reference- Duties of municipal court clerk, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.010(c). 
Secs. 42-30-42-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY JUDGE 

Sec. 42-46. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of city judge, who shall have all the power and authority as granted by and shall perform the duties as required by state law. 
(Code 1976, § 20-4) 
Charter reference- Alternate city judge, art. IV, § 4. 
State Law reference- Judge of the municipal court, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.004. 
Sec. 42-47. - Appointment. 
    The city commission shall appoint a city judge. The person appointed as city judge shall have the qualifications provided by law for other city officials; provided, however, that the judge need not be a licensed attorney. 
(Code 1976, § 20-5) 
Sec. 42-48. - Oath. 
    The city judge, prior to taking office, shall take the requisite oath of office required by the constitution and state law to be taken by the mayor. 
(Code 1976, § 20-6) 
Sec. 42-49. - Employment status. 
    The city judge shall have the same rights, privileges and obligations as any other employee of the city as set out in the personnel policies of the city, except that the city judge will be appointed by, be answerable to and serve at the will of the city commission. The city commission shall retain all the rights of supervision, regulation and termination with regard to the city judge as it had heretofore enjoyed. 
(Code 1976, § 20-6.1) 
Sec. 42-50. - Hours in attendance at municipal court. 
    The city judge shall maintain regular office hours at the office supplied therefor at the municipal court and shall remain there during such office hours unless, due to some emergency circumstance, the judge is temporarily unable to be present at municipal court. The office hours of the city judge are as follows: 
(1)  Monday, Wednesday and Friday of each week from 9:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. and from 3:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.; and 
(2)  Tuesday and Thursday of each week from 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. and from 5:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(Code 1976, § 20-6.2) 
Sec. 42-51. - Reserved. 
Sec. 42-52. - Second alternate municipal judge. 
(a)  A second alternate municipal judge position shall be created in the city; 
(b)  The second alternate judge shall be appointed for a two-year term and shall have the qualifications as set out in the City Charter; and 
(c)  The second alternate judge shall have the same duties, responsibilities, and authority as set out in the City Charter applicable law and City Code relate to the current municipal and alternate judges. 
(Ord. No. O-2017-30, §§ 1-3, 8-7-17) 
Secs. 42-53, 42-54. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COURT FUNDS 

Sec. 42-55. - Technology fund. 
(1)  Establishment. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a municipal court technology fund, known as the fund, pursuant to Article 102.0172 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, as amended. 
(b)  The fund shall be maintained in the general revenue account. 
(2)  Fee; assessment and collection. 
(a)  The fee shall be in the amount of $4.00. 
(b)  The fee shall be assessed and collected from each defendant upon conviction for misdemeanor offense(s) in the municipal court as a cost of court. A defendant is considered convicted if: 
1.  A sentence is imposed on the person; 
2.  The person is placed on community supervision, including deferred adjudication community supervision; or 
3.  The court defers final disposition of the person's case; 
4.  The person pays any fine of any amount. 
(c)  The fee shall be collected on conviction for an offense committed on or after September 17, 2002. 
(d)  The clerk of the court shall collect the fee and pay the fee to the director of finance of the city, who shall deposit the fee into the municipal court technology account of the general revenue fund. 
(3)  Designated use and administration of the fund. 
(a)  The fund shall be used only to finance the purchase and maintenance of technological enhancements for the municipal court of the City of Pharr, Texas, including the following as allowed by law and as may be amended: 
1.  Computer system; 
2.  Computer networks; 
3.  Computer hardware; 
4.  Computer software; 
5.  Imaging system; 
6.  Electronic kiosks; 
7.  Electronic tickets writers; or 
8.  Docket management systems. 
(b)  The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the city commission. 
(4)  Expiration and administration of fund. In accordance with Article 102.0172 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, this section and the assessment and collection of the municipal court technology fee expires September 1, 2005. The purpose of the use of any funds remaining in the fund shall continue to be used and administered as required by this section and for that purpose this section remains in effect. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-43, §§ I-III, VII, 9-17-02; Ord. No. O-2004-63, §§ I-III, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 42-56. - Security fund. 
(1)  Establishment. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a municipal court security fund, known as the fund, pursuant to Article 102.017 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(b)  The security fund shall be maintained in the general revenue account. 
(2)  Fee; assessment and collection. 
(a)  The fee shall be in the amount of $3.00. 
(b)  The fee shall be assessed and collected from each defendant upon conviction for misdemeanor offense(s) in the municipal court as a cost of court. A defendant is considered convicted if: 
1.  A sentence is imposed; 
2.  The person is placed on community supervision, including deferred adjudication community supervision; or 
3.  The court defers final disposition of the person's case; 
4.  The person pays any fine of any amount. 
(c)  The fee shall be collected on conviction for an offense committed on or after December 6, 2002. 
(d)  The clerk of the court shall collect the fee and pay the fee to the director of finance of the city, who shall deposit the fee into the municipal court security account of the general revenue fund. 
(3)  Designated use and administration of the fund. 
(a)  The fund shall be used only to finance the purchase of security devices for the municipal court of the city, including: 
1.  Tape recorder security video and audio cameras (2) for court room; 
2.  Security video cameras for the administrative offices; 
3.  Intercom devices for the court; 
4.  Security alarm button to police department. 
(b)  The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the city commission. 
(4)  Expiration and administration of fund. This section and the assessment and collection of the municipal court security fee will continue at the will of the city commission. The purpose of the use of any funds remaining in the security fund shall continue to be used and administered as required by this section and for that purpose this section remains in effect. 
(Ord. No. O-2002-54, §§ I-III, VII, 11-19-02) 
Sec. 42-57. - Juvenile case manager fund. 
(a)  Authority; creation of juvenile case manager fee and fund. 
(1)  The City of Pharr hereby adopts Section 102.0174 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. As a result, there is hereby created a juvenile case manager fee (the "fee"), as authorized by legislative authority. The fee shall be in the amount of $5.00. The governing body further finds that this section furthers good government, peace, or order of the municipality. 
(2)  Except as otherwise herein provided, a defendant who is convicted of a fine-only misdemeanor offense in municipal court shall pay the fee as a cost of court. A person is considered convicted of an offense if: 
 Judgment, sentence, or both are imposed on the person; 
 The person is placed on deferred disposition; or 
 The court defers final disposition or imposition of the judgment and sentence. 
(3)  The municipal judge may waive the fee in cases of demonstrated financial hardship on the part of a convicted defendant if the defendant is indigent, has insufficient resources or income to pay the fee, or is otherwise unable to pay all or part of the underlying fine or costs. 
(4)  All fees collected by the municipal court shall be deposited into the juvenile case manager fund (the "fund") established under this section. 
(5)  The fund may be used only to finance the salary and benefits of a juvenile case manager that is employed the municipal court under Articles 45.056(a) of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(b)  Juvenile case manager. The Board of Commissioners of the City of Pharr, Texas hereby further authorizes the municipal court to create a juvenile case manager position and to employ a juvenile case manager to provide services in cases involving juvenile offenders before the municipal court consistent with the court's statutory powers. All provisions and authority granted in accordance with Ordinance O-2008-28 shall remain in effect and govern the position of juvenile case manager. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-37, §§ 1, 2, 9-3-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2013-37, §§ 1, 2, adopted Sept. 3, 2013, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included as § 42-57. 
Secs. 42-58-42-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes:

Secs. 42-61-42-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - COURT MARSHAL 

Sec. 42-71. - Court marshal, created. 
    There is hereby created the office of court marshal, to be filled by the qualified persons, appointed as provided by the Pharr City Charter and personnel policies, and administered by the municipal court judge and alternate judges in the furtherance of court related matters. There may be more than one court marshal appointed and employed at any time. The court marshal shall meet all qualifications necessary to be a certified peace officer by the Texas Commission on Law Enforcement Officers Standards and Education. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-68, § 1, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 42-72. - Duties. 
    The court marshal(s), acting under the direction of the municipal court judge and alternate judges through the municipal court administrator, shall perform the following duties: 
(a)  Execute warrants of arrest, subpoenas and other legal process issuing out of the municipal court; 
(b)  Execute other warrants of arrest, subpoenas and legal process as determined by the city clerk through the municipal court administrator; 
(c)  Other duties as assigned, such duties not to be in conflict with provisions of this section and ordinance. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-68, § 2, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 42-73. - Same authority; noncivil service; other provisions applicable. 
(a)  The court marshals shall serve as peace officers and have full police authority in the exercise of their assigned duties; however, they shall not be assigned the duties which are presently assigned to the police department of the City of Pharr. 
(b)  The court marshals are not members of the police department of the City of Pharr, and shall not be covered under the municipal civil service provisions of Chapter 143 of the [Texas] Local Government Code; however, they are eligible for membership in the Texas Municipal Retirement System and any other authorized benefits as approved by the city manager and subject to applicable probationary periods and other personnel related actions. 
(c)  The court marshals are subject to any and all personnel policies and ordinances, as amended, and are at all times at-will employees serving at the discretion of the City of Pharr. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-68, § 3, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 42-74. - Oath of office. 
    Each court marshal shall be required to take an oath of office before entering upon the discharge of his or her duties. The oath shall be subscribed by the person taking it and shall be filed and preserved in the office of the city clerk. 
    The form of oath shall be the same as required for members of the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. O-2004-68, § 4, 10-19-04) 
Chapter 46 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Candidate for city office, V.T.C.A., Election Code § 143.001 et seq. 

Sec. 46-1. - Conduct generally. 
    All elections pertaining to municipal affairs shall be in all things held and conducted and returns thereof made in accordance with the laws of the state and the Charter of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1) 
Sec. 46-2. - Voting hours. 
    Except as provided in V.T.C.A., Election Code § 41.032, all elections for the selection of officials shall be held between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2) 
Sec. 46-3. - Election officers or judges. 
    All city elections shall be conducted by one presiding election judge for each election precinct, and such assistant judges or clerks as may be deemed necessary to be appointed by the mayor. Such officers shall be compensated as the city commission shall direct from time to time. 
(Code 1976, § 10-3) 
Sec. 46-4. - Early voting. 
    Each qualified voter who desires to cast an early vote and who is eligible to do so shall be entitled to an official ballot and the right to cast such ballot in accordance with the provisions of V.T.C.A., Election Code ch. 81 et seq. Application for the early voting ballot shall be made to the city clerk and the voted ballot returned to him. 
(Code 1976, § 10-4) 
Sec. 46-5. - Procedure for getting candidate's name on ballot. 
    Any eligible and qualified person may have his name printed upon the official ballot as an independent candidate for the office of mayor or commissioner, or other city office, by filing his sworn application with the mayor at least 30 days prior to the election day. The application shall state the specific office or place being sought by the applicant and that the applicant is eligible and qualified under the laws of the state to become a candidate for and hold the office being sought, if elected. 
(Code 1976, § 10-5) 
Sec. 46-6. - General duties of officers. 
    In all city elections, the mayor, city clerk or city commission shall do and perform each act in other elections required to be done and performed respectively by the county judge, the county clerk or the commissioners' court. 
(Code 1976, § 10-6) 
Sec. 46-7. - Notice of election. 
    In all city elections the mayor, or if he fails to do so, the city commission, shall order the election and give notice and appoint election officers to hold the election. In general elections for officers the notice or proclamation shall be issued and posted at the polling places not later than 30 days before the first Tuesday in April of the year in which the election is to be held. 
(Code 1976, § 10-7) 
Sec. 46-8. - Posting of candidates' names. 
    The names of all those who have filed their sworn applications to have their names printed on the official ballot as candidates shall be posted by the city clerk in a conspicuous place at his office for the inspection of the public for at least ten days before he orders the ballots to be printed. 
(Code 1976, § 10-8) 
Sec. 46-9. - Objection to candidates. 
    All objections to the regularity or validity of the application of any person shall be made within five days after the posting of such candidate's name by written notice filed with the city clerk, setting forth the grounds for such objections. In case no such objection is filed within the time prescribed, the regularity or validity of the application of no person whose name is so posted shall be thereafter contested. 
(Code 1976, § 10-9) 
Sec. 46-10. - Preservation of records. 
    The city clerk shall preserve in his office for a period of two years all applications, notices of objections and other related papers regarding city elections. 
(Code 1976, § 10-10) 
Sec. 46-11. - Printing of name on ballots. 
    Any person eligible to the office of mayor or commissioner, or other office, who has filed his sworn application in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall have his name printed on the official ballots. 
(Code 1976, § 10-11) 
Sec. 46-12. - Withdrawal of candidate. 
    Any person who has qualified as a candidate under the provisions of this chapter and whose name may be printed on the ballot may cause his name to be withdrawn at any time before the official ballots are actually printed by filing in writing with the city clerk a request to that effect over his own signature, duly attested to by a notary public. No name so withdrawn shall be printed on the ballots. 
(Code 1976, § 10-12) 
Sec. 46-13. - Printing of ballots. 
    Not later than 20 days before the city general election, the city clerk shall have the official ballots printed. 
(Code 1976, § 10-13) 
Sec. 46-14. - Election proclamation, posting. 
    The chief of police shall post a properly executed copy of the election proclamation and notice at the place where the election is to be held. Such notice shall be posted at least 30 days before the date of such election. 
(Code 1976, § 10-14) 
Sec. 46-15. - [General and special municipal elections.] 
(a)  Definitions. Words and phrases used in this section shall have the meanings set forth in this subsection, unless the context of their usage clearly requires otherwise. Words and phrases that are not defined below shall be given their common, ordinary meaning unless the context clearly requires otherwise. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense shall include the future tense (and vice versa); words in the plural number shall include the singular number (and vice versa); and words in the masculine gender shall include the feminine gender (and vice versa). Headings and captions are for reference purposes only. 
    Election shall mean and be defined herein as any general or special election that occurs regularly within the city, or that occurs as a result of a failure to achieve a majority of the votes necessary in a general election, and a special election caused as a result of a petition that meets local and state requirements. This definition also incorporates by reference the meanings within the Texas Election Code and Texas Constitution. 
    Person shall mean and be defined for the purposes of interpreting, implementing, and enforcing this section as any qualified elector that timely submits an application for a place on the ballot for an election or who submits an instrument requesting or causing an election to occur. 
    Pharr Board of Commissioners shall mean and be defined for the purposes of interpreting, implementing, and enforcing this section as the mayor and/or any commissioner. 
    Qualified elector shall mean a qualified voter as defined by applicable statutory and constitutional provisions as may be amended from time to time. A qualified elector shall not include a person who is in default or delinquent to the city for any municipal funds owed at the time a timely application for a place on the ballot or instrument causing an election to occur is submitted or thereafter. 
(b)  Fees; amount; exception; alternate procedure. 
(1)  From the effective date of this section, there shall be charged a filing fee for any application to be submitted for election to any place or position of the governing body also known as the Pharr Board of Commissioners. The fee charged shall also be paid by any person or persons that cause an election to take place by virtue of submission of an instrument including but not limited to a petition, as allowed by charter or applicable state or federal laws. A filing fee need not be paid if an election is caused as a result of the passage of any ordinance at the discretion of the governing body. 
(2)  The filing fee to be paid in accordance with subsection (1) of this section shall be $1,000.00 for each person that timely submits an application or instrument requesting or causing an election to occur. The fee shall be paid in full with sufficient funds attached to a timely application for a place on the ballot or other instrument causing an election to occur. 
(3)  The filing fee will be used by the municipality to offset the costs of conducting a general or special election including but not limited to the following: purchase or rental of voting machines, labor, goods, materials, professional services, promotion and advertising, postage, transportation, copying, legal fees, and education. 
(4)  As an alternative to the payment of a filing fee as required in subsections (1) and (2) of this section, a person shall attach to a timely application for a place on the ballot or other instrument causing an election to occur, either of the following: 
a.  A sworn affidavit from an authorized representative of a legally formed 501(c)(3) non-profit organization located wholly or partly in the city, that testifies to the following: 
1.  Legal name of the organization; 
2.  Declaration that the organization is currently a legally formed 501(c)(3) non-profit organization that has been located wholly or partly in the city for not less than an entire calendar year; 
3.  Identifies by name, address, and date of birth the person as having been authorized and approved to provide volunteer community service to the organization; and 
4.  Confirmation that the person performed not less than 520 hours of community service to the organization without compensation during the calendar year immediately preceding the person's submission of an application for a place on the ballot or other instrument causing an election to occur. 
b.  A sworn affidavit from the city clerk or designee, or minutes approved from the city evidencing that the person has performed not less than 520 hours of service to the city by official means as an elected or appointed member of the governing body, board, committee, or commission, without compensation during the calendar year immediately preceding the person's submission of a timely application for a place on the ballot or other instrument causing an election to occur. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-39, §§ 1, 2, 8-2-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2010-39, §§ 1, 2, adopted August 2, 2010, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included as § 46-15.
