(21)  Foods, food containers, and single service items are to be covered and stored in a way to prevent contamination. 
(22)  Open, unprotected displays of foods are not allowed. 
(23)  All mobile units must be returned to commissary or food establishment daily for cleaning. 
(24)  The vehicle must have firm name on both sides of the vehicle in three-inch letters and permit number on the front bottom right hand side window within 24 hours of the permitting inspection. 
(25)  A commissary or food establishment is required for a mobile food vendor to operate in the City of Pharr. 
(26)  The vehicle must be returned to the commissary daily for servicing and loading of food products. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-03, § 1, 2-17-14) 
Sec. 62-195. - Ice cream trucks. 
(a)  The vehicle must be clean, inside and out, painted, and in good condition. Only one servicing window is allowed on the curbside of the vehicle. 
(b)  The vehicle must be equipped with left and right outside rear view mirrors and two wide-angle mirrors; one located in the front and one located in the back of the vehicle. 
(c)  The vehicle must be equipped with signs reading WATCH FOR CHILDREN and/or STOP FOR CHILDREN in five-inch letters on both the front and the back of the vehicle. It is recommended that signs be present on all four sides of the vehicle. 
(d)  The vehicle must have firm name on both sides of the vehicle in three-inch letters and permit number on the front bottom right hand side window within 24 hours of the permitting inspection. 
(e)  All vehicles must be equipped with operable four-way hazard lights and at least one permanently affixed amber light on the top of the vehicle. Lights must be turned on at all sales stops. 
(f)  The use of mechanical loudspeakers or sound amplifiers on trucks or other moving vehicles for the purpose of advertising any show, sale or display of merchandise is prohibited. Vehicles will not be permitted with a sound generating device attached. 
(g)  Floors and floor coverings must be constructed of a smooth and durable material, such as linoleum or metal, and must be easily cleanable. Carpeting of any type is strictly prohibited. The use of anti-slip floor covering will be allowed. 
(h)  Walls and ceilings must be smooth, easily cleanable and non-absorbent. No carpet or exposed raw wood is allowed. 
(i)  All equipment must be mounted and properly secured to eliminate unsafe conditions. 
(j)  Food storage units must be clean, in good repair, and properly designed to maintain the food product at 10 degrees Fahrenheit or below. A visible thermometer must be provided. 
(k)  All ice cream must be pre-wrapped, sealed, labeled and obtained from an approved source. 
(l)  Pre-packaged candy, chips and soft drinks must be sold in single portion units. No hot foods such as nachos, hot dogs, cheese Cheetos, etc. 
(m)  If soft drinks are cooled on wet ice, a retention tank must be provided for drainage purposes and must be disposed of at a designated commissary or food establishment. 
(n)  A trash receptacle must be available to the customer from the outside of the vehicle. 
(o)  A commissary or food establishment is required for a mobile food vendor to operate in the City of Pharr. 
(p)  Copies of the mobile food vendor permit must be retained on the vehicle at all times. 
(q)  All drivers must possess a current Texas Driver's License, Texas License Plate and a Texas Safety Inspection Sticker. 
(r)  Vendors shall not sell, distribute, or offer for sale, any products or services within two city blocks or 600 feet, whichever is greater, of the grounds of any public, private, parochial, elementary or secondary school between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. on days when school is in session. 
(s)  Vendors shall limit their hours to true daylight, which is defined as 30 minutes before sunrise to 30 minutes after sunset. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-03, § 1, 2-17-14) 
Sec. 62-196. - Offenses and regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any individual as the agent or employee of another regulated mobile food vendor under this section to sell edible goods in the city unless its principle or employer has received a permit under this section. 
(b)  A permit issued under this section is not transferable. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for an individual to sell edible goods while displaying a valid permit by the City of Pharr in the name of another individual, organization, or entity. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any individual directly or through an agent or employee to sell goods within the corporate limits of the City of Pharr after the expiration of the permit issued by the city under this section. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for an individual directly or through an agent or employee to misrepresent on the permit affidavit any acts that are regulated under this section. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any individual directly or through his agents or employees to represent that the issuance of a permit by the City of Pharr constitutes city's endorsement or approval of the product for sale. 
(g)  It shall be unlawful to operate a mobile food vendor operation that is not in compliance with the Texas Food Establishment Rules as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-03, § 1, 2-17-14) 
Chapter 66 - HUMAN RELATIONS[1]

State Law reference- Texas Fair Housing Act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1f. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISCRIMINATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 66-26-66-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FAIR HOUSING 

Sec. 66-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrator means the individual designated as the human relations administrator by the city manager. 
    Council means the city community development council. 
    Disability means a mental or physical impairment that substantially limits at least one major life activity, a record of such impairment, or being regarded as having such impairment. The term does not include current illegal use or addiction to any drug or illegal or federally controlled substance, and does not apply to an individual because of an individual's sexual orientation or because that individual is a transvestite. 
    Discriminatory housing practice means an act that is unlawful under sections 66-44-66-46. 
    Dwelling means any: 
(1)  Structure or part of a structure that is occupied as, or designed or intended for occupancy as, a residence by one or more families; or 
(2)  Vacant land that is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location of a structure or part of a structure described by subsection (1) of this definition. 
    Family includes a single individual. 
    To rent means and includes to lease, to sublease, to let and otherwise to grant for a consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. 
(Code 1976, § 16-32) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 66-42. - Declaration of policy. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to bring about, through fair, orderly and lawful procedures, the opportunity for each person to obtain housing without regard to his race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin. It is further declared that this policy is grounded upon a recognition of the inalienable right of each individual to provide for himself and his family a dwelling according to his own choosing; and further, that the denial of such rights through considerations based upon race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin is detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the city and constitutes an unjust denial or deprivation of such inalienable right which is within the power and the proper responsibility of government to prevent. 
(Code 1976, § 16-31) 
Sec. 66-43. - Familial status. 
    A discriminatory act is committed because of familial status if the act is committed because the person who is the subject of discrimination is: 
(1)  Pregnant; 
(2)  Domiciled with an individual younger than 18 years of age in regard to whom the person: 
a.  Is the parent or legal custodian; or 
b.  Has the written permission of the parent or legal custodian for domicile with that person; or 
(3)  In the process of obtaining legal custody of an individual younger than 18 years of age. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Property Code § 301.004. 
Sec. 66-44. - Discrimination in the sale or rental of housing. 
    Except as exempted by section 66-47, it shall be unlawful: 
(1)  After the making of a bona fide offer, to refuse to sell or rent, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make unavailable or deny, a dwelling to any person because of race, color, religion, sex, familial status or national origin. 
(2)  To discriminate against any individual in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, religion, sex, familial status or national origin. 
(3)  To make, print or publish, or cause to be made, printed or published, any notice, statement or advertisement with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin, or an intention to make any such preference, limitation or discrimination. 
(4)  To represent to any person because of race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin that any dwelling is not available for sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available. 
(5)  For profit, or with the hope or expectation of profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin. 
(Code 1976, § 16-33) 
Sec. 66-45. - Discrimination in the financing of housing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any bank, building and loan association, insurance company or other corporation, association, firm or enterprise, a part of whose ordinary course of business is making loans secured by commercial real estate, to deny a loan to a person applying therefor for the purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling, or to discriminate against such person in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance, because of the race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin of such person. 
(Code 1976, § 16-34) 
Sec. 66-46. - Discrimination in the provision of brokerage services. 
    It shall be unlawful to deny any person access to or membership or participation in any multiple listing service, real estate brokers' organization or other service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings, or to discriminate against such person in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation on account of such person's race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin. 
(Code 1976, § 16-35) 
Sec. 66-47. - Sales and rentals exempted from application of division. 
(a)  This division does not apply to: 
(1)  The sale or rental of a single-family house sold or rented by the owner if: 
a.  The owner does not: 
1.  Own more than three single-family houses at any one time; or 
2.  Own any interest in, nor is there owned or reserved on the person's behalf, under any express or voluntary agreement, title to or any right to any part of the proceeds from the sale or rental of more than three single-family houses at any one time; and 
b.  The house is sold or rented without: 
1.  The use of the sales or rental facilities or services of a real estate broker, agent, or salesman licensed under the Real Estate License Act (Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6573a), or of an employee or agent of a licensed broker, agent, or salesman, or the facilities or services of the owner of a dwelling designed or intended for occupancy by five or more families; or 
2.  The publication, posting, or mailing of a notice, statement, or advertisement prohibited by section 66-44(3); or 
(2)  The sale or rental of the rooms or units in a dwelling containing living quarters occupied by or intended to be occupied by not more than four families living independently of each other, if the owner maintains and occupies one of the living quarters as the owner's residence. 
(b)  The exemption in subsection (a)(1) of this section applies only to one sale or rental in a 24-month period if the owner was not the most recent resident of the house at the time of the sale or rental. 
(c)  Nothing in this division shall prohibit a religious organization, association or society or any nonprofit institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or society from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion or from giving preference to such persons. 
(d)  Nothing in this division shall prohibit a private club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose or purposes provides lodgings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members. 
(Code 1976, § 16-36) 
Sec. 66-48. - Complaints-Generally. 
(a)  Any person who claims to have been injured by a discriminatory housing practice or who believes that he will be irrevocably injured by a discriminatory housing practice that is about to occur (referred to in this section as "person aggrieved") may file a complaint with the administrator. Such complaints shall be in writing and shall identify the person alleged to have committed or alleged to be about to commit the discriminatory housing practice and shall set forth the particulars thereof. The administrator is directed to prepare and adopt from time to time standard complaint forms and to furnish them without charge to any person aggrieved. 
(b)  The administrator shall receive and accept notification and referral of complaints from the secretary of housing and urban development pursuant to the provisions of title VIII, Fair Housing Act of 1968, Public Law 90-284, and shall treat such complaints in the same manner as complaints filed directly by the person aggrieved. 
(c)  If, in the course of any investigation as provided in section 66-49 on a complaint filed with or referred to the administrator, he shall receive credible evidence and shall have probable cause to believe that the persons named in such complaint have committed a discriminatory housing practice on grounds not stated in such complaint, the administrator shall refer the question to the original complainant for supplementary complaint; and such supplementary complaint shall thereafter be treated in the same manner as an original complaint filed by a person aggrieved. 
(d)  If at any time the administrator shall receive or discover credible evidence and shall have probable cause to believe that any persons have committed a discriminatory housing practice as to which no complaint has been filed or is about to be filed, the administrator may refer the question to the person aggrieved, who may prepare and file a complaint upon his own motion and in his own name; and such complaint shall thereafter be treated in the same manner as a complaint filed by a person aggrieved. 
(e)  Upon the filing or referral of any complaint under this section, the administrator shall furnish a copy of the complaint to the persons named in the complaint, together with any other information available. 
(f)  A complaint under subsections (a), (c), (d) and (e) of this section shall be filed within 180 days after the alleged discriminatory housing practice occurred, and not otherwise. Complaints shall state the facts upon which the allegations of a discriminatory housing practice are based. Complaints may be reasonably and fairly amended at any time prior to hearing. A respondent may file an answer to the complaint against him and may amend his answer at any time prior to hearing. Both complaints and answers shall be signed. 
(Code 1976, § 16-37) 
Sec. 66-49. - Same-Investigation. 
(a)  Upon the filing of a complaint as provided in section 66-48, the administrator shall cause to be made a prompt investigation of the matter stated in the complaint. In connection with such investigation, the administrator may question and take and record testimony and statements of such persons who appear and may examine, record and copy documents which are produced. 
(b)  During or after the investigation of a complaint under this division, the administrator shall, if it appears that a discriminatory housing practice act has occurred or is about to occur, attempt by informal endeavors to effect conciliation, including voluntary discontinuance or rectification of the discriminatory housing practice and voluntary compliance and adequate assurance of future voluntary compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(c)  If conciliation of a discriminatory housing practice is effected, the administrator shall disclose nothing said or done in the course of such conciliation in such a way as to make a public identification of the persons named in the complaint without the written consent of the persons concerned, subject to the requirements of law. 
(Code 1976, § 16-38) 
Sec. 66-50. - Same-Council hearing. 
(a)  Upon completion of the investigation and informal endeavors at conciliation by the administrator, but within 30 days of the filing of the complaint with the administrator, and if conciliation has not been effected, the administrator shall refer the complaint to the council, together with the answer of the respondent, if any, and a full report of his investigation and activities in the matter. 
(b)  Upon referral of a complaint by the administrator, the council shall promptly set a date for the hearing on such matter. This date shall be within 30 days of the date on which the administrator referred the complaint. At least five days' prior written notice of the hearing shall be given to the persons alleged to have committed or to be about to commit the discriminatory housing practice. The hearing shall be conducted in a fair and impartial manner and shall be open to the public. Proof of the matters alleged within the complaint may be presented by the administrator. If the complainant and the persons alleged to have committed a discriminatory housing practice shall fail to appear at the council hearing, either personally or by representative, after notice as provided in this section, then such hearing shall be deemed waived by such persons. 
(c)  If, after the hearing held pursuant to this section, a majority of the councilmembers present shall determine on the basis of the evidence at the hearing that the complaint is well founded, the council shall forthwith, by persuasion, education and entreaty, diligently attempt to secure, within a reasonable time not to exceed 30 days, voluntary discontinuance of any discriminatory housing practice. 
(Code 1976, § 16-39) 
Sec. 66-51. - Certification to city attorney. 
    If the council shall determine that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred and if a hearing before the council on the complaint alleging such violation has been waived or if the council has held a hearing and the efforts of the council to secure voluntary compliance have been unsuccessful, the council shall cause the administrator to certify in writing to the general counsel of the city that such discriminatory housing practice has occurred and request prosecution thereof in the municipal court of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 16-40) 
Sec. 66-52. - Legal proceedings. 
(a)  Upon certification by the administrator pursuant to the direction of the council, the general counsel shall prosecute the complaint of discriminatory housing practice in the municipal court to final conclusion. 
(b)  The certification to the general counsel and the actions to be taken pursuant to this division shall be cumulative of all other remedies and procedures for the effectuation and enforcement of this division and the prosecution of alleged violators of this division. 
(Code 1976, § 16-41) 
Sec. 66-53. - Unlawful intimidation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether or not acting under color of law, by force or threat of force to willfully injure, intimidate or interfere with, or attempt to injure, intimidate or interfere with: 
(1)  Any person because of such person's race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin and because such person is or has been selling, purchasing, renting, financing, occupying or contracting or negotiating for the sale, purchase, rental, financing or occupation of any dwelling, or applying for or participating in any service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings; 
(2)  Any person because that person is or has been, or in order to intimidate such person or any other person or class of persons from: 
a.  Participating, without discrimination on account of race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin, in any of the activities, services, organizations or facilities described in subsection (a) of this section; or 
b.  Affording another person or class of persons opportunity or protection so to participate; or 
(3)  Any person because that person is or has been or in order to discourage such person or any other person from lawfully aiding or encouraging other persons to participate, without discrimination on account of race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability or national origin, in any of the activities, services, organizations or facilities described in subsection (a) of this section, or participating lawfully in speech or peaceable assembly opposing any denial of the opportunity so to participate. 
(Code 1976, § 16-42) 
Sec. 66-54. - Cooperation with federal agencies. 
    The council and the administrator are authorized and encouraged to cooperate with the secretary for housing and urban development pursuant to the provisions of title VIII, Fair Housing Act of 1968, Public Law 90-284, and may render such service to the secretary as they shall deem appropriate to further the policies of this division. 
(Code 1976, § 16-43) 
Chapter 70 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 70-1. - Arrest without warrant. 
    The chief of police or any other police officer of the city, in the exercise of sound discretion, may arrest without warrant any person who commits an offense against any law or city ordinance in the presence of such officer, or any person who is found in suspicious circumstances which reasonably show that such person has been guilty of some felony or breach of the peace, or violation of some municipal ordinance, or is about to commit some offense against some state law or municipal ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 27-1) 
State Law reference- Arrest without warrant, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 14.01 et seq. 
Sec. 70-2. - Refusing to aid an officer. 
    If any person, being called on by the chief of police or any other peace officer, shall refuse or fail to aid such officer in any manner in which, by law, he may be rightfully called on to aid or assist in the execution of a duty incumbent upon such officer, he shall be punished as provided in section 1-6. 
(Code 1976, § 27-2) 
Secs. 70-3-70-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 70-26. - Established. 
    The city police department is hereby created and established for the necessary protection of the lives and property of persons situated in the city, and for the maintenance of the public peace. 
(Code 1976, § 27-16) 
Sec. 70-27. - Composition. 
    The police department shall consist of a chief of police, a number of police officers, and other employees as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1976, § 27-17) 
Sec. 70-28. - Chief generally. 
    The chief of police shall be appointed and removed by the city manager with the advice of the city commission. The chief of police shall perform such duties as are assigned to him by the city manager and as stated in Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, and generally delegated to chiefs of police in home rule municipalities. 
(Code 1976, § 27-18) 
Sec. 70-29. - Rules, regulations. 
    The chief of police shall promulgate rules and regulations concerning the actions and behavior of officers and employees of the police department, and violations of such rules or regulations shall be cause for discharge. 
(Code 1976, § 27-19) 
Sec. 70-30. - Personnel generally. 
    Police officers and other employees shall be appointed and removed by the chief of police with the advice of the city manager. Police officers and employees shall be persons of integrity and honor. Officers are charged with the duties of carrying out the purposes and aims of the police department as set out in this article, enforcing the ordinances of the city and the laws of the state, and officers shall be required to state on oath that they will do so. 
(Code 1976, § 27-20) 
Sec. 70-31. - Number of employees authorized. 
    The city commission shall authorize the number of police officers and employees in the police department by approving a number of positions therefor as recommended by the city manager and set out in the annual city budget, or amendment thereto. 
(Code 1976, § 27-21) 
Sec. 70-32. - Compensation. 
    The salary of the chief of police, police officers and other employees of the police department shall be as approved by the city commission after recommendation by the city manager, as set out in the annual city budget or amendment thereto. 
(Code 1976, § 27-22) 
Sec. 70-33. - Disposition of stolen or unclaimed property. 
(a)  Title. This section shall be known as the disposition of stolen property ordinance. 
(b)  Procedures. The procedures of this section shall be followed by the police department regarding the disposition of allegedly stolen or otherwise unclaimed property that comes into the possession of the police department. 
(c)  Identification. All property that comes into the possession of the police department shall be tagged and marked with proper identification showing: 
(1)  The date received; 
(2)  The representative of the police department who comes into possession of the article; and 
(3)  The circumstances under which that person came into possession of the article in question. 
(d)  Auction list. 
(1)  After the expiration of 30 days from the date the police department came into possession of the stolen or otherwise unclaimed property, it may be placed upon an auction list to be prepared by the officer of the police department who has the specific responsibility for maintaining and identifying evidence. 
(2)  At the time the item is placed upon the auction list, a letter shall be mailed by the police department to the individual believed to be the owner of the property, if one is known, at his last known address, such letter being sent by certified mail, with return receipt requested. 
(e)  Sale. If the purported owner of the stolen or unclaimed property does not respond within 30 days of the certified letter sent pursuant to this section, or if the letter is returned marked "unclaimed," such property may be sold as detailed in this section. 
(f)  Auction. The police department may hold an auction as often as needed to dispose of property which is unclaimed, provided that all items sold at auction shall have been held by the department a minimum of six months. When an auction is to be held, the police department shall publish an advertisement in the Pharr Press and/or in another newspaper of general circulation in the city, announcing the date an auction is to be held, generally describing the items to be sold, and announcing two dates on which such items may be viewed by persons believing the department is in possession of items belonging to them, provided that one of such viewing dates shall be a Saturday or a Sunday. The viewing times on the dates thus announced shall be between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on each of the two days. The viewing dates shall be held within seven days of the auction sale. 
(g)  Viewing articles. A person may only view items alleged to have been stolen from him or lost by him in another manner. In order for the individual to view any article, he must provide information to complete a police report if one has not been prepared pertaining to his loss. If the property is deemed to have been stolen, an offense report should be prepared. In order to claim property and take possession of such property, the individual must provide evidence of ownership of such property which is deemed sufficient by the identification officer of the police department. The individual may produce a canceled check showing purchase or a receipt for purchase, or furnish a sufficient description of the property to satisfy the identification officer. 
(h)  Release of property. If the identification officer is satisfied that the individual who claims the item of stolen or abandoned property is the owner of such property, he may release the property to the owner after executing a property release form which states the manner in which the property was lost by the individual, the person who released the property, and the name, address and telephone number of the person to whom the property was released. Only the identification officer may release property in this manner. 
(i)  Disposition of unclaimed property. All property not claimed after following the procedures set out in this section shall then be sold at a public auction called in accordance with the notice in the newspaper. All items may be sold to the highest bidder for cash only, and the proceeds of such sale shall be forfeited to the city. 
(j)  Waiver of claim to stolen property. Any party who fails to file an offense report with the police department pertaining to a theft of his property within 30 days of the date of the alleged theft shall waive any claim to file an action against the city for wrongful sale of his property under the provisions of this section. 
(k)  Exceptions to provisions of section. It is specifically provided that this section shall not apply to items held as evidence in a pending criminal case but only to unclaimed property not the subject of a criminal case. 
(Code 1976, § 27-23) 
Secs. 70-34-70-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POLICE RESERVE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2014-27, §§ 1, 2, adopted July 1, 2014, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 70-61-70-66, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former article pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1976, §§ 27-48-27-52. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
State Law reference- Police reserve force, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.012. 

Sec. 70-61. - Qualifications and standards. 
(a)  An auxiliary police force to be known as Pharr Police Reserve is hereby established. The Pharr Police Reserve shall be composed of eligible and qualified persons who have volunteered to join the organization; that has been notified that an application for membership has been accepted; and that has complied with all the rules, regulations and orders provided for the conduct and control of the members thereof. The Pharr Police Reserve shall not exceed 20 active members. The police reserve shall be separate and distinct from the police department of this city, but shall be at the discretion, direction, and control of the chief of police. The minimum requirements for consideration and appointment to the Pharr Police Reserve are as follows: 
(1)  Must be at least 21 years of age of the time of appointment; 
(2)  Must have graduated from high school or attained a GED certificate and completed 12 college or university credit hours; 
(3)  Must possess a valid Texas driver's license (at least class C); 
(4)  Must be a citizen of the United States; 
(5)  Must be licensed as a peace officer by the Texas Commission on Law Enforcement; 
(6)  Shall meet the minimum standards for appointment in accordance with established rules and regulations of the Texas Commission on Law Enforcement; and 
(7)  Shall possess character that will positively promote the Pharr Police Reserve and the Pharr community. 
(b)  An eligible and qualified candidate nominated for appointment by the chief of police shall subscribe to an oath that he or she shall observe and obey the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the State of Texas, the laws of this nation, this state and this city, and shall carry out the duties of a member of the police reserve force to the best of his or her ability. 
(c)  The duties of a member of the Pharr Police Reserve shall be subject at all times to the direction, supervision and control of the chief of police. Any member shall assist the regular members of the police department of this City of Pharr in the enforcement of law and the maintenance of peace and order during periods of emergency designated by the chief of police. The chief may by order establish rules and regulations to govern the police reserve, to fix specific duties of its members, and he may command members of the police reserve to obey the instructions of regular police officers in carrying out their orders. The chief may prescribe other duties than those mentioned herein to be performed by the police reserve, not inconsistent with the provisions hereof. 
(d)  An identification card or such other insignia or evidence of identity as the chief of police may prescribe shall be issued to each member, who must carry the card or other identification at all times while on duty, and must surrender it upon the expiration or termination of his membership. All commissions shall be good until expiration or revoked. 
(e)  A member of the police reserve force who is not a peace officer as described by V.T.C.A., Code of Criminal Procedure art. 2.12, as may be amended from time to time, may act as a peace officer only during the actual discharge of official duties. Such members may carry a weapon only when authorized to do so by the chief of police and only when discharging official duties as a peace officer. A member who qualifies as a peace officer pursuant to V.T.C.A., Code of Criminal Procedure art. 2.12 may be authorized by the chief of police to carry a weapon or act as a peace officer at all times, regardless of whether the person is engaged in the actual discharge of official duties, or the chief of police may limit the authority of the person to carry a weapon or act as a peace officer to only those times during which the person is engaged in the actual discharge of official duties. 
(f)  Regardless of whether he or she is a peace officer as described by V.T.C.A., Code of Criminal Procedure art. 2.12, a member is: 
(1)  To act only in a supplementary capacity to the regular police force, and may not assume the full-time duties of regular police officers without complying with the requirements for regular police officers; and 
(2)  Not eligible for participation in any program provided by the governing body that is normally considered a financial benefit of full-time employment, or in any pension fund created by statute for the benefit of full-time, paid peace officers, and exempt from V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 1702, as may be amended from time to time. 
(g)  The chief of police shall prescribe the uniform and badges for the members of the police reserve and direct the manner in which the same shall be worn. Any person other than a member of said force who shall wear such uniform or badge shall be deemed guilty of a class C misdemeanor. Members of the police reserve shall wear uniforms and badges at all times while on duty unless otherwise approved by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-27, § 2, 7-1-14) 
Secs. 70-62-70-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - INTERLOCAL ASSISTANCE 

Sec. 70-91. - Aid to other cities, counties-Authorized. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 362, the chief of police is authorized to assign the regularly employed law enforcement personnel of his department to assist any other county, municipality or joint airport in the state, upon request by proper authority, when, in the opinion of the mayor or other officer authorized to declare a state of civil emergency in the other county, municipality or joint airport, a need exists in such other county, municipality or joint airport for the services of additional law enforcement officers to protect the health, life and property of such other county, municipality or joint airport, its inhabitants and the visitors thereto, by reason of disaster, riot, threat of concealed explosives, or unlawful assembly characterized by force and violence, or threat thereof, by three or more persons acting together or without lawful authority. 
(Code 1976, § 27-34) 
Sec. 70-92. - Same-Compensation of city officers. 
    When any law enforcement officer of this city is ordered by proper authority to perform peace officer duties outside the territorial limits of the city, he shall be entitled to the same wage, salary, pension and all other compensation and all other rights for such service, including injury or death benefits, the same as though the service had been rendered within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 27-35) 
Sec. 70-93. - Aid to this city-By other cities, counties. 
    Whenever any law enforcement officer of any other county or municipality is assigned to this city under authority of an order adopted by the governing body of such other county or municipality, to assist under circumstances as described in section 70-91, which may exist in this city, such officer shall be considered as a peace officer of this city and shall be under the command of the chief of police while so assigned; and he shall have all the powers of a regular law enforcement officer of this city as fully as though he were within the county or municipality where regularly employed, and his qualifications for office where regularly employed shall constitute his qualifications for office in this city, and no other oath, bond or compensation shall be required. 
(Code 1976, § 27-36) 
Sec. 70-94. - Same-Compensation reimbursed. 
    When any law enforcement officer is assigned to this city from another county or city under the circumstances described in section 70-91, upon request of the proper authority of this city, the city will, upon proper request, reimburse the county or city furnishing the services of such law enforcement officer for his actual expenses of travel, food and lodging from the services of such law enforcement officer in this city, for the county or city where he is regularly employed. 
(Code 1976, § 27-37) 
Chapter 74 - LIBRARY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; amusements and entertainments, ch. 14; civic and cultural facilities and affairs, ch. 30; parks and recreation, ch. 90. 
State Law reference- Library systems, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 441.121 et seq.; municipal right of eminent domain, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 251.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 74-1. - Created; acceptance of gifts. 
(a)  A municipal library is hereby created within the framework of the governmental organization of the city, which shall be known as the Pharr Memorial Library; and it shall function according to the laws of the state, the Charter of the city, and the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  The city hereby accepts all gifts and donations of books and equipment heretofore made for the Pharr Memorial Library, with grateful thanks to the donors both of books and time; and it is ordained that such books and equipment, together with such additions as may be made from time to time, shall constitute and form the books and equipment of the Pharr Memorial Library. 
(Code 1976, § 18-1) 
Sec. 74-2. - Management of library. 
    The city manager shall be responsible for the operation of the Pharr Memorial Library. 
(Code 1976, § 18-2) 
Sec. 74-3. - Return of materials. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to retain or fail to return any books, articles or other library materials beyond the date designated by the Pharr Memorial Library at the time such book, article or material is removed by consent of the library and charged out to the person removing such material at the library or any extensions of time granted in writing by the library. 
(b)  Late charges and penalties. 
(1)  Any person failing to return to the library any books, articles or other library materials beyond the date designated shall be liable for late charges for each day of such retention or other penalties, including replacement cost of the books, articles or other library materials. 
(2)  The library privileges of the borrower shall be suspended until all borrowed items are returned and/or all late charges and other penalties are paid. 
(Ord. No. O-94-38, §§ 1-3, 12-6-94) 
Sec. 74-4. - Issuance of library card to minor; responsibility of parent or guardian. 
    Before any library privilege card may be issued to a minor, the adult guardian or parent of such minor shall cosign the application, agreeing to be responsible for the return of materials borrowed by the minor and for payment of late charges and penalties incurred by the minor for violation of this chapter. In the event a minor fails to timely return library materials, the adult cosigning on the application shall be notified of the violation of this chapter by the minor. In the event the adult fails to timely return such materials borrowed by the minor, the adult shall be responsible for payment of late charges and penalties accruing therefor and have their library privileges suspended until such late charges and penalties are paid. 
(Ord. No. O-94-38, § 4, 12-6-94) 
Sec. 74-5. - Penalties not exclusive. 
    The penalties prescribed in this chapter shall in no way be interpreted to preclude prosecution by the appropriate authorities of any person whose actions constitute a misdemeanor or felony under applicable law and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. O-94-38, § 6, 12-6-94) 
Secs. 74-6-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIBRARY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2007-40, adopted July 17, 2007, was not specifically amendatory of the Code. The editor has treated the provisions as superseding article II, §§ 74-31-74-39, designating these new provisions as § 74-31. Former article II pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Code 1976; and Ord. No. O-94-38, adopted Dec. 6, 1994. 

Sec. 74-31. - Creation; membership/officers, appointments; number of members; quorum. 
(a)  The City of Pharr hereby creates the Pharr Memorial Library Board. The board shall be composed of nine regular members, and one ex officio member. The ex officio member shall not be entitled to vote on any matters of the board. 
The members shall be selected by a majority vote of the City of Pharr Board of Commissioners. A majority of the members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Thereafter, the board shall annually select through from its membership a chairman, a vice chairman, and secretary. 
(b)  All members shall serve a two-year term. Appointments to fill vacancies on the board prior to the expiration of a term shall be for the remainder of the term. 
(c)  The board shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city commissioners. The board in all things shall obtain, pursue, and satisfy the requirements necessary to oversee the operations of the library, programs, and expansion. 
(d)  The board shall not be authorized to create any debts or incur expenses on behalf of the city incident to the operation of its board, projects, and programs unless expressly authorized to do so by the city. 
(e)  The board is hereby authorized to establish its own rules and procedures, not in conflict with this or any other ordinance, the city Charter, or any state or federal laws. 
(f)  The board shall provide for regular and special meetings necessary to carry out the functions and its business as set out in this article. All meetings, regular and special called, shall be conducted within the boundaries of the City of Pharr, Texas. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-40, § 1, 7-17-07) 
Chapter 78 - MANUFACTURED HOMES AND TRAILERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; businesses, ch. 26; community development, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 54; health and sanitation, ch. 62; planning, ch. 98; signs, ch. 106; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 114; subdivisions, ch. 118; taxation, ch. 122; traffic and vehicles, ch. 126; utilities, ch. 130; zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference- Manufactured Housing Standards Act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 5221f; size and weight of vehicles, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d-11; sanitation and health protection, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 341.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dependent mobile home or travel trailer means a mobile home or travel trailer which does not have a flush toilet and bath or shower. 
    HUD Code manufactured home means a structure constructed on or after June 15, 1976, and a "mobile home" is a structure constructed before June 15, 1976; both of which are transportable in one or more sections, which in the traveling mode are eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length, or when erected on site, are 320 or more square feet, and which are built on permanent chassis and designed to be used as dwellings, with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, including plumbing, heating, air conditioning and electrical systems. When the term "mobile home" appears in this chapter, it shall also include HUD Code manufactured homes unless the language specifically excludes HUD Code manufactured homes. 
    Independent mobile home or travel trailer means a mobile home or travel trailer which has a flush toilet and a bath or shower. 
    Lot or space means an area designated for the occupancy of a travel trailer or mobile home, which can either be purchased or rented by an occupant. 
    Mobile home or travel trailer means any vehicle or similar portable structure having no original foundation other than wheels, jacks, blocks or skirtings, and so designed or constructed as to permit occupancy for dwelling or sleeping purposes. 
    Mobile home and/or travel trailer lot means a plot of ground within a mobile home and/or travel trailer park designed for the accommodation of one mobile home or travel trailer, with or without pay. 
    Mobile home and/or travel trailer park means any plot of ground upon which one or more mobile homes or travel trailers, occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, are located, regardless of whether or not a charge is made for such accommodations. 
    Natural or artificial barrier means any river, pond, canal, railroad, levee, embankment, fence or hedge. 
    Park means a mobile home and/or travel trailer park. 
    Travel trailer or recreational vehicle means a structure less than eight feet in width or less than 40 feet in length or less than 320 square feet when erected on-site. 
(Code 1976, § 19-1; Ord. No. O-95-14, § 1, 3-7-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-2. - Location restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, place or store any type of mobile home or homes, or any trailer house used for living purposes, with or without wheels, except in compliance with the provisions of the city's zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 19-2) 
Sec. 78-3. - Existing trailers and mobile homes. 
    Any mobile home or travel trailer now existing and being located and situated upon any parcel of land within the city shall immediately upon being moved become subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter. No other mobile home or travel trailer shall be placed on such lot, park, plat or parcel of real property unless the terms and conditions of this chapter are fully complied with. 
(Code 1976, § 19-3) 
Secs. 78-4-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME AND/OR TRAVEL TRAILER PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 78-31. - Office building required. 
    Each mobile home and/or travel trailer park shall be provided with a building to be known as the office, in which shall be kept copies of all records pertaining to the management and supervision of the park, as well as all rules and regulations of the park; and such records, rules and regulations shall be available for inspection by law enforcement officers, public health officials and other officials whose duties necessitate acquisition of the information contained therein. The home of the owner or operator of the park may be used as the office building, provided that it is easily accessible to the occupants of the park. 
(Code 1976, § 19-16) 
Sec. 78-32. - General duties of owner. 
    In addition to the other provisions of this article, it shall be the duty of the owner, his agent, representative or manager to: 
(1)  Provide for regular inspection of the water and sanitary conveniences. 
(2)  Provide for the collection and removal of garbage and other waste material. 
(3)  Prohibit the placing or storage of unsightly material or vehicles of any kind. 
(Code 1976, § 19-17) 
Sec. 78-33. - Rules and regulations for park. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner, his agent, representative or manager to prescribe rules and regulations for the management of the park; to make adequate provisions for the enforcement of such rules; and to subscribe to any and all subsequent rules and regulations which may be adopted for the management of the park. Copies of all rules and regulations shall be furnished to the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 19-18) 
Sec. 78-34. - Maintenance. 
    Every person owning or operating a mobile home and/or travel trailer park shall maintain such park, and any facilities, fixtures and permanent equipment in connection therewith, in a clean and sanitary condition and shall maintain such equipment in a state of good repair. 
(Code 1976, § 19-19) 
Sec. 78-35. - Additional construction. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating a mobile home and/or travel trailer park or occupying a mobile home or travel trailer to construct or permit to be constructed in such park or in connection with such mobile home or travel trailer any additional structure, building or shelter in connection with or attached to a mobile home or travel trailer; except, however, awnings of canvas, metal or wood, suitably constructed, may be attached to the mobile home or travel trailer, as well as rooms for the express purpose of increasing the mobile home or travel trailer's living area. These rooms shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  Any additional living area must comply with all zoning ordinances for the mobile home district. 
(2)  The strength of materials and structure shall meet the minimum standards as prescribed by the Standard Building Code. 
(3)  No additions will be allowed on rental lots or spaces. All additions must be on lots or spaces which are owned or are being purchased by the applicant. If the lot or space is being purchased, the city must receive written approval from the lienholder authorizing the addition prior to issuance of a building permit. 
(4)  Any addition must be completely dismantled and removed from the site at such time as the mobile home or travel trailer is removed from the property. 
(5)  Any addition must be approved by the park manager and/or the architectural review committee of the subject park, if any, prior to issuance of a building permit. 
(6)  Any addition cannot exceed 100 percent of the mobile home's or travel trailer's original living area, not including garages, carports or storage rooms. 
(7)  A mobile home, including park models, cannot be placed temporarily or permanently in any space or lot designated for travel trailers. 
(8)  A travel trailer, including recreational vehicles, cannot be temporarily or permanently placed in a space or lot designated for mobile homes or park models. 
(Code 1976, § 19-20; Ord. No. O-95-14, § 1, 3-7-95) 
Sec. 78-36. - Bottled gas and fuel handling. 
    Bottled gas for cooking purposes shall not be used at individual mobile home or travel trailer lots unless the containers are properly connected by copper or other suitable metallic tubing. Bottled gas cylinders shall be securely fastened in place. No cylinder containing bottled gas shall be located in a mobile home or travel trailer or within five feet of a door thereof. State and local regulations applicable to the handling of bottled gas and fuel oil must be followed. 
(Code 1976, § 19-21) 
Secs. 78-37-78-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 78-51. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate, within the limits of the city, any mobile home and/or travel trailer park unless such person shall first obtain a license therefor. 
(Code 1976, § 19-31) 
Sec. 78-52. - Application. 
    Applications for a mobile home and/or travel trailer park license shall be filed with the city commission. Applications shall be in writing, signed by the applicant, and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location and legal description of the mobile home and/or travel trailer park. 
(3)  A complete plan of the park showing compliance with divisions 3 and 4 of this article. 
(4)  Plans and specifications of all buildings and other improvements constructed, or to be constructed, within the mobile home and/or travel trailer park. 
(5)  Such further information as may be requested by the city commissioners to enable them to determine if the mobile home and/or travel trailer park will comply with the legal requirements. 
The application and all accompanying plans and specifications shall be filed in triplicate with the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 19-32) 
Sec. 78-53. - Fees. 
    The annual license fee for each mobile home and/or travel trailer park shall be $25.00 per year or fraction thereof. The fee for the transfer of such license shall be $5.00. 
(Code 1976, § 19-33) 
Sec. 78-54. - Investigation, inspection. 
    The city manager, city health officer and city planning and zoning commission shall investigate the applicant for a license under this division and inspect the proposed plans and specifications. Each of them shall then make a report to the city commission concerning such applicant and include therein their recommendations relative to the issuance of a license. If the mobile home and/or travel trailer park will be in compliance with all provisions of this article and all other applicable ordinances or statutes, the city commissioners may approve the application; and, in the case of proposed parks, make such approval contingent upon the completion of the park according to the plans and specifications submitted with the application. 
(Code 1976, § 19-34) 
Sec. 78-55. - Issuance. 
    Upon approval of the application for a license required by the provisions of this division by the city commission, the city clerk shall issue such license upon payment of the required license fee. 
(Code 1976, § 19-35) 
Sec. 78-56. - Building permit required. 
    No person shall erect or construct or proceed with the erection or construction of any building or structure, nor add to, enlarge, alter, repair, move, convert, extend or demolish any building or structure, or install any plumbing, electrical or mechanical equipment as a part of a building or structure, or make any other improvement in any building or structure, or cause such work to be done within a house trailer park or mobile home park without first obtaining a building permit therefor from the building inspector. 
(Code 1976, § 19-36) 
Sec. 78-57. - Duration. 
    Each license issued under the provisions of this division, and any transfer thereof, may be granted at any time during the year and shall expire at the end of the fiscal year of this city, unless previously revoked or terminated. 
(Code 1976, § 19-37) 
Sec. 78-58. - Transfer. 
    Upon application for a transfer of a license granted under the provisions of this division, the city commission may issue such license transfer upon payment of the required transfer fee. 
(Code 1976, § 19-38) 
Sec. 78-59. - Posting of license. 
    The license certificate issued under this division shall be conspicuously posted in the office of or on the premises of the mobile home and/or travel trailer park at all times. 
(Code 1976, § 19-39) 
Sec. 78-60. - Revocation-Grounds. 
    The city commission may revoke any license issued under the provisions of this division for the violation of any applicable provision of this Code, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation by the licensee, his agents or employees. 
(Code 1976, § 19-40) 
Sec. 78-61. - Same-Hearing. 
    Before any license issued under the provisions of this division may be revoked by the city commission, the city commission shall give ten days' notice to the licensee and hold a hearing thereon. 
(Code 1976, § 19-41) 
Sec. 78-62. - Same-Reissuance. 
    After any license issued under the provisions of this division shall have been revoked, such license may be reissued if the reasons for such revocation have been duly corrected. 
(Code 1976, § 19-42) 
Secs. 78-63-78-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PHYSICAL LAYOUT 

Sec. 78-81. - Drainage. 
    Every mobile home and/or travel trailer park shall be located on a well-drained site, and shall be so located that its drainage will not endanger any water supply. All such parks shall be in areas free from marshes, swamps or other potential breeding places for insects or rodents. 
(Code 1976, § 19-51) 
Sec. 78-82. - Minimum area of lots. 
    Each mobile home and/or travel trailer lot provided in a park shall have a minimum of 2,500 square feet, and shall be at least 35 feet wide and clearly defined. 
(Code 1976, § 19-52) 
Sec. 78-83. - Clearance between individual units. 
    Mobile homes or travel trailers shall be so harbored on each lot that there shall be at least a 25-foot clearance between mobile homes and/or travel trailers; provided, however, that with respect to mobile homes and/or travel trailers parked end to end, the end-to-end clearance shall be at least ten feet. 
(Code 1976, § 19-53) 
Sec. 78-84. - Proximity to buildings, boundary. 
    No mobile home or travel trailer shall be located closer than ten feet from any building within the park or from any property line bounding the park. 
(Code 1976, § 19-54) 
Sec. 78-85. - Driveways. 
    All mobile home and/or travel trailer lots shall abut on a driveway of not less than 25 feet in width, which shall have unobstructed access to a public street, alley or highway. All driveways shall be gravel or hard-surfaced, well marked in the daytime and lighted at night. 
(Code 1976, § 19-55) 
Sec. 78-86. - Walkways. 
    Walkways not less than two feet wide shall be provided from mobile home and/or travel trailer lots to service buildings. The walkway shall be gravel or hard-surfaced, well marked and lighted at night. 
(Code 1976, § 19-56) 
Sec. 78-87. - Location. 
    Mobile home and travel trailer parks may be located only in conformity with the comprehensive zoning ordinance of the city; and in addition to the requirements contained therein, each boundary of the park must be at least 100 feet from any permanent residential building located outside the park, unless separated therefrom by a natural or artificial barrier, or unless a majority of the property owners according to such area within 100 feet consent in writing to the establishment of the park; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to mobile home and/or travel trailer parks already in existence and operation at the time of the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, and such existing and operating parks shall be treated as a nonconforming use insofar as the requirements of this section are concerned. 
(Code 1976, § 19-57) 
Secs. 78-88-78-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SANITATION 

Sec. 78-106. - Water supply generally. 
    Each site used as a mobile home and/or travel trailer park shall be supplied with water from the city water lines if such line is within 150 feet of the site, otherwise to be provided with an ample and adequate supply of water of safe, sanitary quality approved by the city health officer. A water service pipe shall be installed for furnishing water to each trailer. 
(Code 1976, § 19-66) 
Sec. 78-107. - Plumbing compliance. 
    All plumbing installations in a mobile home and/or travel trailer park shall comply with the plumbing and health ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 19-67) 
Sec. 78-108. - Toilet buildings and sanitary facilities. 
    Each house trailer park, mobile home park and/or travel trailer park that has and provides plots thereon for the parking of dependent trailers shall be provided with a toilet building for each sex, each of which buildings shall be located not more than 200 feet from any plot provided for such dependent trailers. The toilet buildings shall be roofed and shall be provided with light and ventilation by means of windows and an area of not less than one-eighth of the floor area of the room which they serve. The openings shall be screened with mesh not less than 16-mesh per inch. The toilet building shall be provided with artificial lights having an intensity of not less than ten candlepower, which lights shall be kept burning continuously at night. The toilet buildings shall have floors and sidewalks to a height of six inches of concrete or other impervious material. 
(Code 1976, § 19-68) 
Sec. 78-109. - Minimum equipment for toilet buildings. 
(a)  Generally. Each toilet building shall have the following facilities as a minimum: 
(1)  One slop (janitor's) sink. 
(2)  Floor drain. 
(3)  Hot and cold running water. 
(4)  One laundry tray for each 15 unit plots in a separate compartment from the water closets and lavatories, or automatic washing machines substituted for each laundry tray required in excess of one. 
(b)  Males. In addition to the facilities required by subsection (a) of this section, the toilet building for males shall contain the following minimum facilities based upon the number of unit plots set aside for use by either tents or house trailers: 
(1)  One flush water closet for every 15 unit plots or fraction thereof. 
(2)  One urinal for every 15 unit plots or fraction thereof. 
(3)  One lavatory or washbasin for every ten unit plots or fraction thereof. 
(4)  One shower bath for every ten unit plots or fraction thereof. 
(c)  Females. Each toilet building for females shall have the following facilities based on the unit plots set aside for use by either tents or house trailers: 
(1)  One flush water closet for every ten unit plots or fraction thereof. 
(2)  One lavatory or washbasin for every ten unit plots or fraction thereof. 
(3)  One shower bath for every ten unit plots or fraction thereof. 
(Code 1976, §§ 19-69-19-71) 
Sec. 78-110. - Waste disposal. 
(a)  All waste from mobile home and/or travel trailer parks shall be discharged into a public sewer through an approved sewer connection where within 150 feet of a sewer, or otherwise to an adequate septic tank constructed as required by law. 
(b)  All garbage in a mobile home and/or travel trailer park shall be placed in garbage cans with tops, and wastepaper shall be placed in suitable containers. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to permit waste or material from sinks, showers or other fixtures or utensils in house trailers or mobile homes, or garbage, to be disposed of on any street or in any other manner, except as provided in this section or as approved by the city health officer. 
(Code 1976, § 19-72) 
Chapter 82 - NATURAL RESOURCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26; floods, ch. 58; planning, ch. 98; utilities, ch. 130; vegetation, ch. 134. 
State Law reference- Lease of municipal oil, gas or mineral land, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 253.005; disposition of the public domain (oil and gas), V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 52.001 et seq.; oil and gas generally, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code ch. 81 et seq., and Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6049h et seq.; access to property and records, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 91.1012; municipal regulation of exploration and development of mineral interests, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code § 92.007. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 82-1-82-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OIL AND GAS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2011-39, §§ 1-28, 30, adopted August 17, 2011, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 82-26-82-32, 82-51-82-66, 82-101-82-106, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. O-2010-41, §§ 1-28, 30, adopted August 17, 2010. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 54. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-26. - Definitions. 
    The following meaning shall be given to the following words used in this article; the word "he" shall include she, it and they; the word "him" shall include her, it and them; the word "person" shall mean natural persons, husband and wife, joint tenants, tenants in common, corporations , partnerships, joint stock associations, municipal corporations in the State of Texas; the word "city" shall mean the incorporated City of Pharr; the words "city clerk" shall mean the City Clerk of Pharr; the word "mayor" shall mean the Mayor of Pharr; and the word "owner" or "owners" as used in this article shall mean the owner in fee simple or a mineral owner by a good and merchantable title of or in and to the particular real estate referred to, subject only to liens to secure debts, and lien holders shall not be considered an owner. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 1, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-27. - Findings and purpose. 
    It appearing to the city commission that certain persons may commence the search for and, if found, the production of oil and/or gas within the city limits of the City of Pharr, and it appearing to the city commission that it is necessary and desirable that the drilling of wells for and production there from of oil and/or gas be regulated in order to promote the public welfare and to guard and protect the persons, lives and properties of the people in the city and of those passing through the city from the dangers and hazards of the escape of gas, fire, explosions, cratering and other dangers indicant to oil fields and production of oil and gas, this article, is, therefore, passed for the purpose of protecting the health, life and property, to preserve and enforce good government, order and security of the City of Pharr and its inhabitants, and for the purpose of preventing nuisances in the exploration, drilling for and production of oil/or gas within the city limits of Pharr. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 2, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-28. - Location in streets. 
    It shall be unlawful to drill any well for oil or gas within any of the streets or alleys of the city. It shall be unlawful to block, encumber of close up any street or alley in the drilling or production operations, except by special permit by order of the governing body, and then only temporarily. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 3, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-29. - Location near residence, commercial building. 
    No well for oil or gas shall be drilled not permit be given to drill any such well for oil or gas within 500 feet of any residence or commercial building without the permittee first having secured the permission of the owner or owners or authorized representatives thereof to drill such well. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 4, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-30. - Location near school, church, public building. 
    No well for oil or gas shall be drilled and no permit shall be given to drill a well for oil or gas where the hole is to be drilled within less distance than 400 feet from any school building and 100 feet from the boundary line of any land used as a school, church, or public building site in the City of Pharr. No well shall be drilled-in or drill steam test made within 700 feet of any school or church grounds in the City of Pharr during school hours or from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., any day school is in session or at a time when church is being held. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 5, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-31. - Right of entry for inspections, tests. 
    Those in control of the drilling or operations of any oil or gas well in the City of Pharr shall permit the City Inspector of Pharr to come upon the premises and make inspections and tests at all reasonable hours. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 22, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-32. - Violation of article. 
(a)  Any violation of any of the terms of this article, whether herein denominated as unlawful or not, shall be deemed a class c misdemeanor, and any person convicted of any such violation shall be fined in any sum not exceeding $200.00, and each day of the continuance of such violation shall be considered as a separate offense and be punishable separately, and any person, agent or employee engaged in any such violation shall on conviction be so punished therefore. 
(b)  Should any person or business commit violate this article, the city attorney may take any action to enforce this or any ordinance to prevent and summarily abate and remove any unlawful conditions. These actions may include but not be limited to allowing for municipal resources and personnel to: abate any premises or property, closure, condemn, remove any person or thing, court action, suspend, cancel, or void any license or permit issued by the City of Pharr, and any and all other relief as may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 30, 8-17-11) 
Secs. 82-33-82-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DRILLING AND OPERATION OF WELLS 

Sec. 82-51. - Earthen slush or mud pits. 
    No earthen slush or mud pits shall be dug or used within the corporate limits of the City of Pharr in the drilling of any oil or gas well, other than reserve pits, completely surrounded by a fence of at least four feet in height. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 6, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-52. - Wastes, trash, wastewaters to be removed. 
    No waste, refuse, trash, waste oil or waste water shall be permitted to remain on the premises where an oil or gas well is being drilled or being produced. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 7, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-53. - Fencing. 
    All oil and/or gas wells when completed shall be enclosed by a good and substantial smooth net wire fence, sufficiently high and properly built so as ordinarily to keep persons and animals out of the enclosure. Gate to the enclosure to be kept locked when the permittee or his employees are not at the premises. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 8, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-54. - Removal of derricks, other equipment. 
    After any oil and/or gas well is brought into production, all derricks shall be timely taken down after the completion of the well and there shall remain on top of the ground during the natural flowing life of the well, only a Christmas Tree and pipes leading thereto or leading there from. All flares, separator tanks and all other equipment shall be removed from drilling site as soon as well is completed and is completely tested and the same shall not be allowed to be kept within the corporate limits of the City of Pharr unless the Board of Commissioners of the City of Pharr, after a thorough study, determine that allowing the same to remain within the corporate limits of the City of Pharr will not deface the city or will not be unsafe to citizens of the City of Pharr. Nothing in this section shall, however, be construed as prohibiting the installation of all necessary reconditioning of the well and when the time comes where the natural flow has ceased, or become so light as to make necessary the installation of pumps, all such derricks and equipment may be installed for such purpose and the pumping equipment maintained for said well. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 9, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-55. - Casing-Generally. 
    In the drilling of an oil and/or gas well, new pipe with a mill test pressure of not less than 1,000 pounds per square inch shall be set for surface casing at a dept of not less than 1,250 feet below the surface and cemented from the bottom of the pipe to the surface with proper mixture of cement. Cementing shall be by the pump and plug method. Cement shall be allowed to stand under pressure a minimum of 24 hours before drilling plug or initiating test. Casing shall be tested by pump pressure in the following manner; remove mud from hole and replace with water; apply pump pressure of at least 1,000 pounds per square inch; if at the end of 30 minutes the pressure shows a drop of 100 pounds or more, casing shall be condemned. After corrective operation, casing shall be condemned. After corrective operation, casing shall again be tested in the same manner until the same shall be found to comply with the above specifications. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 10, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-56. - Same-For production or oil string. 
    In the drilling of an oil and/or gas well, the producing or oil string shall be new casing that has been tested to 3,000 pounds per square inch and after cementing it, it shall be tested by pump pressure in the following manner; pump pressure of at least 3,000 pounds per square inch shall be applied. If at the end of 30 minutes, the pressure shows a drop of 100 pounds, or more, the casing shall be condemned. After corrective operation, the casing shall again be tested in the same manner until the same conforms to the above specifications. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 11, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-57. - Determination of position of producing horizon; cementing producing string. 
    The position of the producing horizon in any oil or gas well shall be determined by coring and/or testing. The producing string shall be cemented at the top of such producing horizon or lower. Cementing shall be by the pump and plug method. A sufficient quantity of cement shall be used so that it will fill the annular space back of the pipe to a distance of not less than 600 feet above shallowest and capable of producing oil or gas in commercial quantities. Cement shall be allowed to stand a minimum of 48 hours under pressure before drilling plug or initiating tests. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 12, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-58. - Pressure control equipment. 
    A ram type blow-out preventer, master gate and other connections for keeping any oil or gas well under control at all times shall be installed as soon as pressure is released from the surface casing. The blowout preventer shall be of dual control or of such type of construction and operation as to satisfy any test which may be required by the railroad commission, or city inspector. Blow-out preventer shall be tested at least once every eight hours. All control equipment shall be in good working order and condition at all times and shall have been tested to at least 6,000 pounds pressure. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 13, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-59. - Drilling fluid. 
    After the setting of surface casing, as in this article provided, and drilling operations commenced, there shall be kept at all times a mud laden fluid for drilling purposes of a minimum weight of nine and one-half pounds per gallon and a viscosity not greater than 50 sections based upon the American Petroleum Institute method of testing, and such mud laden fluid shall be tested during drilling operations each eight hours; and just before a well is to be drilled in or a drill steam test made, the mud laden fluid shall be tested while circulating and shall be made to conform to the above specifications before proceeding. When coming out of the hole with the drill pipe, the drilling fluid shall be circulated until equalized and a fill-up line shall be turned into the casing to insure a full load of fluid on the bottom of the hole at all times. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 14, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-60. - Equipment mufflers. 
    All steam exhausts on pumps, boilers and equipment used for drilling well shall be equipped with mufflers. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 15, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-61. - Bradenheads. 
    All wells shall be equipped with Bradenhead with working pressure of not less than 5,000 pounds per square inch. Bradenheads shall not be welded and, as soon as installed, the same shall be equipped with the proper pipe connections and valves accessible at the surface. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 16, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-62. - Pressure for Christmas tree fittings. 
    Christmas tree fitting or well head connections shall have a minimum working pressure of 5,000 pounds per square inch or a minimum test pressure of 10,000 pounds per square inch. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 17, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-63. - Tubing for natural flowing wells. 
    All natural flowing wells shall be equipped with and produced through tubing of not more than three inches in diameter. Bottom of tubing shall not be higher than the top of the producing sand. If tubing is perforated, the perforations shall not extend above the top of the sand. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 18, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-64. - Flow control. 
    All wells shall be equipped with adequate choke, or beans, to properly control the flow thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 19, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-65. - Proximity of boiler, generator. 
    No boiler or electric lighting generator shall be operated nearer than 150 feet of any producing well or an oil tank. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 20, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-66. - Time for swabbing, bailing operations, drillstem tests. 
    All swabbing and/or bailing operations and/or drill steam tests on oil or gas wells shall be done and completed in the daylight hours after sunrise and before sunset, except wells referred to in section 82-30 hereof. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 21, 8-17-11) 
Secs. 82-67-82-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT FOR WELL 

Sec. 82-101. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commence to drill a well for oil or gas within the City of Pharr, or to work upon or to assist in any way in the prosecution of any such well, without a permit for such well and for the prosecution of such development having first been issued by the city if accordance with the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 23, 8-17-11)
