Sec. 82-102. - Application. 
(a)  [Generally; cash deposit.] Every application for a permit to drill a well for oil and gas shall be in writing, signed by the applicant or some authorized person in his or its behalf. It shall be filed with the city clerk and be accompanied with a cash deposit of $3,000.00, which cash deposit shall be held in a special fund until the permit is issued and the well is commenced to be drilled. 
(b)  [Map.] The application shall also be accompanied with a map or a plot of the exact location of this proposed well. In making such location the permittee may take into consideration improvements which now exist. 
(c)  [Bond.] Such application shall also be accompanied with a duly executed bond as a drilling bond given by the applicant, as to do business in the State of Texas, as surety, payable to the Mayor of the City of Pharr and his successors in office, conditioned that if the permit be granted the applicant and his or its assigns will comply with the terms and conditions of this article in the drilling of the well, that the applicant will restore the streets and sidewalks and other public places of the city, which may be injured in the operations, to their former condition; will clear the lots and blocks of all litter, machinery, derricks, buildings, trash and waste erected, used or allowed in the drilling of such well when the well shall be completed as a producing well or plugged and abandoned as a dry hole. Such bond shall be in the sum of $25,000.00, or in such amount as the city's governing body may determine, and before the permit will be issued) said bond shall be approved by the mayor and filed with the city clerk. Said bond shall become effective by at least 24 hours prior to the time drilling on well commences and shall remain in full force and effect until such well is abandoned as a dry hole and plugged, or completed as a producing well. 
(d)  [Insurance.] 
(1)  In addition to such bond, permittee shall carry public liability insurance in a minimum amount of $300,000.00 for one person and $1,000,000.00 for one accident, and property damage insurance in a minimum amount of not less than $1,000,000.00 for one accident, with a company authorized to do business in the State of Texas, which shall be in force and effect during the drilling of such well and until the completion thereof as a producing well or the abandonment and plugging thereof as a dry hole. A certificate of insurance shall be furnished by such permittee to accompany such application and shall be subject to the approval of the governing body of the city. 
(2)  In the event lily such well is completed as commercially producing well, then permittee shall be required to carry public liability insurance in a minimum of $300,000.00 for one person, and $1,000,000.00 for one accident, and property damage insurance in a minimum amount of not less than $1,000,000.00 for one accident, which shall remain in force and effect and be so carried as long as such well is producing oil or gas or either of them in commercial quantities and until plugged and abandoned. A certificate of insurance, subject to the approval of the governing body of the city, is to be furnished annually by permittee or the owner and operator of such well, showing that such insurance is carried. 
(e)  [Reception well for recycling.] A permit for an input or reception well for recycling purposes may be obtained by a person owning oil and/or gas wells in the city at some convenient place in the city, under the same terms and conditions as provided in this section for the obtaining of a permit to drill a well for oil and gas, exception that such well shall be drilled in accordance with this article, and that there may be maintained upon its site such machinery as is necessary for the production of pressure and recycling purposes. Such well shall be for recycling purposes only and not to produce oil or gas. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 24, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-103. - Issuance; location restricted. 
    If an application be found by the city clerk to comply in all respects with the terms of this article, and the board of commissioners of the city authorizes him, he shall issue a permit for the drilling of the well applied for. The permit shall specify the particular location of the well to be drilled and it shall be unlawful for the permittee to drill else where without the approval of the city clerk in writing as authorized by the board of commissioners of the city. Such permit shall be authority for and a franchise granted to the permittee to use the streets and alleys for pipe lines, telephone poles, and lines and other equipment for the purpose of conveying into the city drilling mud or fluid, gas and water for drilling operations and other service connected therewith, and for conveying out of the city oil and gas and other products produced from any well, but it shall be a condition of said franchise that all pipe lines shall be buried beneath the surface of the streets and alleys and to such depth as determined by the board of commissioners of the city which shall be safe for the pressure carried, and further conditioned that the permittee, at his own expense, shall at all times restore and repair the streets and alleys of any injury caused by permittee in laying pipes and conduits and that he will not injure the lines of franchise holders or public service lines. If the permit for a well shall be refused or the drilling of the well for which the permit is issued is not commenced within the time specified in this article, the cash deposit provided for in the preceding section shall be returned to the applicant, except there shall be retained therefrom $100.00 as a filing and consideration fee. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 25, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-104. - Fee. 
    The permit fee of $3,000.00 in this article provided to be paid by the permittee for a permit for the drilling in the City of Pharr, shall accrue to the city and shall be full and complete compensation for all franchises granted and the expenses of inspection and other fees that may be incurred by the city for the supervision and inspect ion of the drilling, production operations of such well and all other operations connected therewith for which such permit fee was paid. Nothing in this section shall, however, relieve the permittee from the obligation to properly repair the streets, alleys and public properties in case they are used in such drillings or production operations. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 26, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-105. - Use of land restricted. 
    Neither this article nor any permit issued hereunder shall be interpreted to grant any right or license to the permittee to enter upon or occupy in any respect in the drilling or production operations any land not under contract or lease to him, except by the written consent of the owner. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 27, 8-17-11) 
Sec. 82-106. - Expiration. 
    If any permittee who has been granted a permit hereunder does not in good faith commence operations for the drilling of a well for oil and gas within six months from the date of the issuance of such permit, then such permit shall be null and void and no well shall be drilled on such particular location described in said permit, until another permit is granted therefore on the same terms and conditions as provided in this article for the granting of a permit. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-39, § 28, 8-17-11) 
Secs. 82-107-82-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEISMOGRAPHIC SURVEYS 

Sec. 82-121. - Permit requirement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct seismographic testing within the city unless a public hearing has been held and a permit has been authorized by the city council to allow seismographic testing within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-13, § I, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 82-122. - Permit application fee. 
    Every application for a permit to conduct seismographic testing shall be in writing, signed by the applicant or some person duly authorized to sign on his behalf and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of $250.00 for the basic permit, plus $1,200.00 per linear mile for mobile vibratory units and/or receiver testing lines within or surrounded by the City of Pharr after permit is approved. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-13, § II, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 82-123. - Conditions for permit. 
    All approved permits shall be subject to the following conditions unless waived by the city council: 
(a)  The work to be performed under this permit shall be restricted to be performed between the dates requested for the permit. Additional dates shall require approval from the city council. 
(b)  The applicant shall furnish a map or plat which indicates the exact location and length of the seismic survey. The map shall be sufficient to enable the City of Pharr to locate the applicant's operations hereunder. The applicant shall limit its use of the subject premises of the area indicated for the lines except for purposes of direct ingress and egress to the seismic line area. 
(c)  The permittee shall employ, at its expense, an independent vibration/technician engineer selected by the city, to monitor vibratory operations within the city limits of the City of Pharr to ensure work to be performed in a manner not to damage city water lines, sewer lines, sewer manholes, lift stations, water towers, booster stations, storm drainage lines, drainage structures, roadways, water wells and public/private structures. 
(d)  The permittee shall not conduct vibrous operations on or over any property for which the applicant has not first secured the permission of the property owner. 
(e)  The permittee shall not conduct vibrous operations within 50 feet of a residential or nonresidential building without the consent of the building owner. 
(f)  Vibrating over water, gas or sewer pipe lines shall not be allowed; nor shall it be allowed within 300 feet of any sewer lift station. 
(g)  No shot holes, dynamite or charges shall be placed within or detonated within the city limits of the City of Pharr, Texas. 
(h)  No vibrating or vibrous operations shall be conducted by the permittee within 1,000 feet of water wells and water towers/booster stations. 
(i)  The permittee shall pay for any actual damages resulting from permittee's activities, including but not limited to land, fences, streets, roads, water lines, sewer lines, storm drainage lines, drainage structures, water wells and any other damages incurred resulting from the permittee's activities. 
(j)  Seismographic surveys shall be by vibroseis technique only. 
(k)  Vibratory work shall not be conducted on paved city streets unless the applicant obtains the consent of the city. 
(l)  During permitted activities, when necessary, the permittee shall provide protection for the traveling public with flagmen. The permittee shall, at its expense, hire the police department to escort vibratory equipment and assist geophysical cable road crossing crews with traffic control when necessary. 
(m)  The permittee shall not lay any lines or cables across any public road without prior consent of the city. 
(n)  The permittee shall not conduct vibrous operations within 150 feet of a drainage or irrigation structure without prior consent of the city. 
(o)  No shrubs, trees on any public road facility will be disturbed or removed unless authorized by the public works department. 
(p)  No vibratory work shall be done on road shoulders, back slope or ditches that are wet or soft. 
(q)  If any vibratory work is to be done within or adjacent to any irrigation or drainage district, the permittee shall, prior to commencing operations, consult with and reach an agreement with the irrigation and drainage district concerning the location of seismographic work with reference to the facilities of said irrigation district. 
(r)  Damage caused to any public road facilities, water lines, sewer lines, storm drainage lines, drainage structures and water wells by permittee's seismic operations shall be repaired or replaced by the city and the permittee will be billed for any such expenses in connection therewith. 
(s)  Each permit shall provide that if any dispute arises as to any terms and conditions of the permit, permittee shall stipulate that venue for all purpose shall be in Hidalgo County, Texas, and if it becomes necessary to file suit to recover any damages caused by permittee's operations thereunder, the permittee agrees to pay reasonable attorney's fees, together with court costs, if the city is successful in recovering damages. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-13, § III, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 82-124. - Insurance and indemnification. 
    Prior to a permit being issued, the applicant shall furnish to the city a certificate of insurance, naming the City of Pharr as an additional insured for losses resulting from the permittee's seismic operations within the city limits. Such policy shall provide the following minimum coverage: 
General Liability $2,000,000 General Aggregate (other than products/completed operations) $1,000,000 Products/Completed Operations Aggregate $1,000,000 Personal/Advertising Injury $1,000,000 Each Occurrence Excess Liability/Umbrella $2,000,000 
Each Occurrence Combined Single Limit Bodily Injury and Property Damage Automobile Liability $1,000,000 Combined Single Limit Bodily Injury and Property Damage Workers' Compensation/Employer Liability $1,000,000 
Each Accident Bodily Injury by Accident $1,000,000 
Policy Limit Bodily Injury by Disease $1,000,000 
Each Employee Bodily Injury by Disease  
    Such insurance certificate shall contain a provision that at least 15 days' written notice shall be given to the city prior to cancellation, alteration or modification of such insurance. The permittee assumes full responsibility for any and all damages sustained resulting from the permittee's seismic operations within the city limits. The permittee agrees to indemnify and save harmless the City of Pharr, its officers, agents and employees from any and all liabilities, demands, actions, losses, damages and costs resulting from such operations. This indemnification shall cover the costs of defense for claims resulting from the applicant's use or occupancy of the City of Pharr properties or right-of-way, including but not limited to claims, liabilities and actions based upon acts or omissions of negligence of not only the permittee, but also the City of Pharr, its officers, agents and employees resulting from applicant's seismic operations within the city limits. Upon demand permittee shall at its expenses provide the required defense to the City of Pharr, its officers, agents and employees, through competent legal council acceptable to the city. 
    The permittee agrees to comply with all the requirements of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Pharr while conducting its operations. Written permission must be obtained from all private property owners before applicant performs any operation on private property. Vibratory operations shall only be conducted between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. No vibratory operations shall occur on Saturday and Sunday. Receiver line crews and surveyor crews shall work during daylight hours only. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-13, § IV, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 82-125. - Notification. 
    Notices shall be published in the official newspaper of the City of Pharr in the manner and order set forth below: 
(1)  The city shall publish notice of the public hearing in the official newspaper of the City of Pharr 15 days prior to the hearing before the city council. After the city council has authorized a permit for a seismographic survey, permittee shall publish a first notice in the aforementioned publications at least three days prior to the start of any cable and geophone operations or vibratory testing. Running time: One [day]. 
(2)  The permittee shall deliver, in person, second notice to persons along each seismic line on the day cable and geophone operations and vibratory testing first begins. Such work may continue with no more than ten consecutive working days of nonproduction. If vibratory testing does not occur during this time, the permittee shall publish a subsequent notice in the official newspaper of the City of Pharr on the days such work will restart. The permittee shall republish all subsequent notices to coincide with such intermittent work. Running time: One day for each occurrence. Final notice: Scheduled to be published by the permittee when such vibratory testing is approximately 50 percent complete. Running time: One day. 
(3)  The notices to be published shall appear in the official newspaper of the City of Pharr in the classified section under legal notices and will detail the approximate dates and times (starting and ending) and identify the general location of the work to be performed. The notices shall include the company's name, name of local contact and local phone number. The city public works department shall be notified when the notice has been placed with the newspaper and the dates it will be published. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-13, § V, 2-15-00) 
Sec. 82-126. - Inspection. 
    When deemed necessary by the public works department, any and all vibrator testing to be performed on city right-of-way shall be observed and inspected by a city representative. The applicant must contact the city's public works department 24 hours in advance of any vibratory testing and if deemed necessary, a representative shall be scheduled to be present for monitoring purposes. The expense of such inspection services shall be billed to the applicant and such amounts shall be reimbursed to the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2000-13, § VI, 2-15-00) 
Chapter 86 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 62; parades and processions, § 126-266 et seq. 
State Law reference- Suit to abate prostitution, gambling, etc., V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code § 125.001 et seq.; preemption of criminal offenses by Penal Code, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 1.08; municipal public health powers, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 122.006; abatement of health nuisances, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 341.011 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Model glue. 
(a)  Sales restricted. Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall sell, offer for sale, deliver or give to any individual under 17 years of age any glue or cement commonly known as model airplane glue, plastic cement, household cement, cement, paint, spray paint, spray paint product or any other similar substance, if such glue or cement or paint contains one or more of the following volatile solvents: 
Toluol 
Hexane 
Trichloroethylene 
Acetone 
Toluene 
Ethyl acetate 
Methyl ethyl ketone 
Trichloroethane 
Isopropanol 
Methyl isobutyl ketone 
Methyl cellosolve acetate 
Cyclohexanone 
(b)  Exception to sales restriction. The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply where the glue or cement is sold, delivered or given simultaneously with and as part of a kit used for the construction of model airplanes, model boats, model automobiles, model trains or other similar models. 
(c)  Inhaling of prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to inhale any glue or cement containing one or more of the solvents named in subsection (a) of this section with the intent of obtaining an intoxicating or narcotic effect thereby. 
(Code 1976, § 21-1) 
State Law reference- Volatile chemicals, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 484; abusable glues and aerosol paints, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code ch. 485. 
Sec. 86-2. - Fireworks. 
    No person shall sell, offer for sale, cast, throw or discharge any squib, rocket, firecracker, torpedo, grenade, or other combustible fireworks of whatever name in the city except as may be authorized under this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 21-2) 
State Law reference- Fireworks V.A.T.S., Insurance Code art. 5.43-4. 
Sec. 86-3. - CATV franchise required for operation of system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a community antenna television system within the city without having first obtained a valid franchise from the city. Included in the definition of community antenna television system but not limited thereto is the use of coaxial cable, microwave relay, leased wire, and any other method by which television signals may be brought into a home of a subscriber for a fee. 
(Code 1976, § 21-3) 
Sec. 86-4. - Abandoned refrigerators or airtight containers. 
(a)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure, or within any warehouse or storage room or any unoccupied or abandoned dwelling, building or other structure, under such circumstances as to be accessible to children, any icebox, refrigerator or other airtight or semiairtight container which has a capacity of 11/2 cubic feet or more and an opening of 50 square inches or more and which has a door or lid equipped with a latch or other fastening device capable of securing such door or lid shut. 
(b)  Penalty. An offense under this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $200.00. 
(Code 1976, § 21-4) 
State Law reference- Unlawful storage of refrigerators and other containers, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 756.011 et seq. 
Sec. 86-5. - Interfering with, obstructing city officials, employees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, in any manner, to interfere with, prevent or otherwise obstruct any officer or employee of this city in the performance of his official duties. 
(Code 1976, § 21-5) 
Sec. 86-6. - Possession of handgun prohibited; penalty. 
(a)  The possession of any handgun by any person, unless such person is a licensed peace officer under the laws of the state and is carrying a handgun under the course and scope of his employment is prohibited on all city-owned premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to carry a handgun in violation of the provisions of this section. This section is intended to be interpreted liberally so as to prohibit handguns from any all city property that state law allows municipalities to regulate. The city manager is hereby authorized to post notice of this prohibition at the entrance of all city premises. Any person carrying a handgun in violation of this prohibition shall be considered to be entering the premises of the city in violation of Penal Code § 30.05, said section being the criminal trespass statute of the state. 
(b)  Any violation of the provisions contained in subsection (a) above shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine of $500.00. 
(Ord. No. O-96-05, §§ 1, 2, 1-16-96) 
Sec. 86-7. - Nuisances. 
(a)  Authority; area: 
(1)  The City of Pharr hereby adopts in its entirety the Texas Local Government Code, Chapter 217, Subchapter C, §§ 217.041, 217.042 as may be amended from time to time. This section and provisions herewith shall be included in the Pharr Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  As matters related to the public's health, safety, and welfare are of the utmost concern, the City of Pharr shall be authorized to enforce, through its city attorney, this section as may be allowed by law herein. This section is effective and shall be enforced within the corporate boundaries of the City of Pharr and within 5,000 feet outside the limits. 
(b)  Definition(s): 
    Nuisance shall be defined for purposes of this section as any activity which arises from unreasonable, unwarranted, or unlawful use by a person or business of property, working obstruction, or injury to the right of another or the public, and producing such material annoyance, inconvenience, or discomfort that law will presume resulting damage. 
    Business shall be defined for purposes of this section as an entity with any interest in property, wholly or in part, with the right of control. 
(c)  Enforcement: Should any person or business commit a nuisance, or allowed the commission of any act or condition that creates a nuisance, the city attorney may take any action to enforce this or any ordinance to prevent and summarily abate and remove a nuisance. These actions may include, but not be limited to, allowing for municipal resources and personnel to: abate any premises or property, closure, condemn, remove any person or thing, court action, suspend, cancel, or void any license or permit issued by the City of Pharr, and any and all other relief as may be necessary. 
(d)  Penalties: 
(1)  Any violation of this section shall be subject to both civil and criminal penalties. A criminal conviction shall be a Class C misdemeanor. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. 
(2)  A liable party shall be subject to a civil penalty up to $1,000.00 per day, or the maximum allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-2008-52, §§ 1-4, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 86-8. - Prohibiting the discharge of firearms and fireworks. 
(1)  Authority; area. 
(a)  The City of Pharr hereby adopts and enacts this section that shall be enforceable within the municipality's municipal boundaries and extra territorial jurisdiction. This section and provisions herewith shall be included in the Pharr Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  As matters related to the public's health, safety, and welfare is of the utmost concern, the City of Pharr shall be authorized to enforce, through its city attorney, this section as may be allowed by law herein. 
(2)  Definition(s). 
    Firework shall be defined for purposes of this section as any object defined as such in accordance with V.T.C.A., Occupations Code ch. 2154, including but not limited to: a composition or device designed to produce a visible or audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration, detonation, which may include but not be limited to the following: squib, rocket, firecracker, torpedo, grenade, Roma candle, skyrocket, combustible object, or anything containing gun powder or other explosive matter. 
    Firearm shall be defined for purposes of this section as a gun, pistol, revolver, rifle, or any other firearm as may defined by state law. 
(3)  Prohibition; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge a firearm or firework of any kind within the municipality's municipal boundaries and extra territorial jurisdiction. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to police officers acting in the line of duty, any licensed shooting gallery, or independent pyrotechnic operator contracted by the municipality to conduct a public display. 
(4)  Enforcement; punishment; penalties. 
(a)  Should any person or business violate the prohibitions contained herein, or allow the commission of any act or condition that proximately resulted in a violation of this section, the city attorney may take any action to enforce this [section] or any ordinance to prevent and summarily abate the action and remove or seize any objects used to violate this section. These actions may also include, but not be limited to, allowing for municipal resources and personnel to: abate any premises or property, closure, condemn, remove any person or thing, court action, suspend, cancel, or void any license or permit issued by the City of Pharr or a state or federal agency, and any and all other relief as may be necessary. 
(b)  Any violation of this section shall be subject to both civil and criminal penalties. A criminal conviction shall be a Class C misdemeanor. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. If conduct constituting an offense under this section also constitutes an offense under another law, the person may be prosecuted under all applicable laws. 
(c)  A liable party shall be subject to a civil penalty up to $1,000.00 per violation, or the maximum allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-02, §§ 1-4, 1-20-09; Ord. No. O-2010-04, §§ 1-4, 2-16-10) 
Sec. 86-9. - Loitering within the corporate municipal boundaries. 
(a)  Authority; area: 
(1)  The City of Pharr hereby adopts and enacts this section that shall be enforceable within the municipality's municipal boundaries. This section and provisions herewith shall be included in the Pharr Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  As matters related to the public's health, safety, and welfare are of the utmost concern, the City of Pharr shall be authorized to enforce, through its city attorney, this section as may be allowed by law herein. 
(b)  Definition(s): 
    Loiter, loitering shall mean and be defined for purposes of this section as: to be dilatory; to be slow in movement; to stand around or move slowly about; to stand idly around; to saunter; to delay; to linger; to lag behind; or to prowl. Loiter does not include similar circumstances where such conduct is due to physical defects or conditions. 
    Parking lot shall mean any area in, at or adjacent to a restaurant, drive-in restaurant, store retail or wholesale business establishment, office building, professional building, recreational building, multifamily residential area, referred to in this section as a premises, or any public building or space used, designed or intended for the parking of any type of vehicle, including motor vehicles, by members of the general public, and maintained for the convenience of customers, clients, patients, members or patrons of one or more business establishments, public offices or organizations. 
(c)  Prohibition; exceptions: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person, whether alone or in any grouping or assemblage of persons, to loiter, as defined in this section, in, on, or about any place, public or private, within the corporate limits of the city, when not otherwise engaged in a lawful pursuit relating to the use of the premises and without the owner's consent, or to leave a motor vehicle unattended on a parking lot, except for the purpose of entering into a premises, or returning therefrom, except with the consent and approval of the owner or operator or manager of such parking lot. 
(2)  For the purposes of this section, the fact that a premises is closed shall constitute prima facie proof that a person is not engaged in a lawful pursuit relating to the use of the premises. Furthermore, if any parking lot is clearly marked by any sign or device declaring time limits or other restrictions relating to parking, then a violation by any person of such restrictions shall be prima facie proof of such owner's nonconsent to any person parking or congregating on such parking lot. Failure to post a notice or sign prohibiting conduct shall not affect the enforcement of this section. 
(3)  This section shall not apply to police officers acting in the line of duty, or to persons participating in a municipal, community, school, or church event, or a fundraising gathering, election, or parade. 
(d)  Enforcement; punishment; penalties: 
(1)  Should any person or business violate the prohibitions contained herein, or allow the commission of any act or condition that proximately resulted in a violation of this section, the city attorney may take any action to enforce this or any ordinance to prevent and summarily abate the action and remove or seize any objects used to violate this section. These actions may also include but not be limited to allowing for municipal resources and personnel to: abate any premises or property, closure, condemn, remove any person or thing, court action, suspend, cancel, or void any license or permit issued by the City of Pharr or a state or federal agency, and any and all other relief as may be necessary. 
(2)  Any violation of this section shall be subject to both civil and criminal penalties. A criminal conviction shall be a Class C misdemeanor. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. If conduct constituting an offense under this section also constitutes an offense under another law, the person may be prosecuted under all applicable laws. 
(3)  A liable party shall be subject to a civil penalty up to $350.00 per violation, or the maximum allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-03, §§ 1-4, 1-20-09) 
Sec. 86-10. - Prohibition of actual or attempted entry, possession, or sale of any goods during city sponsored event. 
(a)  Authority; area. 
(1)  The City of Pharr hereby adopts and enacts this section that shall be enforceable within the municipality's municipal boundaries and extra territorial jurisdiction. This section and provisions herewith shall be included in the Pharr Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  As matters related to the public's health, safety, and welfare is of the utmost concern, the City of Pharr shall be authorized to enforce, through its personnel and city attorney, this section as may be allowed by law herein. 
(b)  Definition(s). 
    Goods shall be defined for purposes of this section as any type of food or beverage. 
(c)  Prohibition; exceptions; conspiracy to circumvent. 
(1)  During any officially sponsored City of Pharr event or activity, it shall be unlawful for any person, business, or other entity to allow or cause the actual or attempted entry, possession, or sale of any goods, within any prohibited area, without authorization from the City of Pharr. 
(2)  It shall be an exception to this section if such actual or attempted entry, possession, or sale, of any goods obtained city authorization or was allowed in furtherance of any activity within the city sponsored event. 
(3)  It shall also be unlawful to knowingly conspire to circumvent this section by allowing the unauthorized use, transfer, or possession of a permit or other authorization or agreement. 
(d)  Enforcement; punishment; penalties. 
(1)  Should a violation or attempted violation of this section occur, the city attorney and other city personnel may take any action to enforce this section to prevent and summarily abate the action, remove or seize any goods and other objects used to violate this section. These actions may also include, but not be limited to, allowing for municipal resources and personnel to: abate any premises or property, closure, remove any person or thing, court action, suspend, cancel, or void any license or permit issued by the City of Pharr, and any and all other relief as may be necessary. 
(2)  Any violation of this section shall be subject to both civil and criminal penalties. A criminal conviction shall be a Class C misdemeanor. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. If conduct constituting an offense under this ordinance also constitutes an offense under another law, the person may be prosecuted under all applicable laws. 
(3)  A liable party shall be subject to a civil penalty up to $250.00 per violation, or the maximum allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-2010-14, §§ 1-4, 3-2-10) 
Sec. 86-11. - Gang free zones. 
(a)  Authority; area. 
(1)  The City of Pharr hereby adopts and enacts this section in accordance with Section 71.029 of the Texas Penal Code, as amended, that shall incorporate the attached Exhibit displaying the City of Pharr's Gang Free Zones. 
(2)  As matters related to the public's health, safety, and welfare is of the utmost concern, the City of Pharr adopts the Gang Free Zone mapping for use by any and all branches of government including but not limited to local, state, and federal prosecutors and federal, state, and local judicial branches in furtherance of the enforcement, punishment, and interpretation of any and all applicable offenses and offenders. 
(b)  Cumulative clause; repealer. This section shall incorporate herein all other ordinances that may require use or reference to the adopted mapping for Gang Free Zones. Any ordinance or directive in conflict with this section is repealed to the extent of the conflict, and this section shall supersede any provisions in conflict herewith. All other provisions shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-22, §§ 1, 2, 6-5-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2012-22, §§ 1, 2, adopted June 5, 2012, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included as § 86-11. The exhibit referenced above is not set out herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the city offices. 
Sec. 86-12. - Class C misdemeanor designation. 
(a)  Code violations that impose fine; criminal act. As stated herein, any violator that is the subject of a fine between $500.00 and $5,000.00, or as may be allowed by law, may be charged with a Class C misdemeanor. Any violations arising from this section shall also be subject to the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. Any violator that fails to appear on any charge, may also be subject to a Class C misdemeanor charge as allowed by law. This section is not exclusive, and any person may be subject to charges arising from other applicable laws and respective punishment. 
(b)  Municipal authority. Any municipal personnel, including but not limited to code enforcement officers, law enforcement, and authorized fire department personnel, shall invoke this section and any other applicable criminal charge classified as a Class C misdemeanor. The Courts, City Attorney and designated prosecutor, and judiciary of the City of Pharr are also hereby authorized to invoke this section and applicable punishment, relief, restitution, and fines. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-50, §§ 2, 3, 12-17-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2013-50, §§ 2, 3, adopted Dec. 17, 2013, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included as § 86-12. 
Secs. 86-13-86-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CURFEW FOR MINORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2013-48, §§ 2-10, adopted Dec. 3, 2013, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 86-31-86-39, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. O-2009-41, §§ 2-10, adopted Oct. 27, 2009. 

Sec. 86-31. - Purpose. 
    This article sets forth regulations for the presence of minors in public places during specified times of day. These regulations encompass prevailing community standards for the purpose of furthering responsible conduct, and advancing family responsibility and of promoting public safety and welfare for all persons. The board of commissioners has determined that a curfew meets a very real need and is a significant factor in protecting juveniles and minimizing juvenile delinquency and promoting the public's health, safety, and welfare. The board of commissioners also finds that there are persons upon the streets of the city who represent an influence that is detrimental to the health, safety, welfare and morals of minors considering their peculiar vulnerability and their inability to make critical decisions in an informed and mature manner and that minors who fall under this influence, in turn, represent a detriment to the health, safety, welfare and morals of the community as a whole and lead to increased crime and fear among citizens for their safety and welfare and that of their minor children. The board of commissioners also finds that commercial recreational facilities are very limited in the city. The curfew hours cited by this article reflect the community standard of the appropriate hour for cessation of outdoor activities by minors in public places. The curfew also takes into account the hours which present the highest risk for nocturnal crimes and for the congregating of minors with potential risks incident to immaturity. Therefore, the board of commissioners finds that this article is necessary and that it serves the community's interest in protecting our minors from criminal and other unhealthy influences. The board of commissioners has determined that parental and community responsibility for the whereabouts of minors is a community norm. As parental and community control increases, the likelihood of juvenile delinquency decreases. Therefore, legal sanctions to enforce parental and community responsibility has been shown to be significantly effective in minimizing the incidence of juvenile delinquency and in protecting the minors and the community at large. The board of commissioners hereby determines that the curfew for minors will accomplish under local conditions the purposes stated herein. The board of commissioners is mindful that minors in the city have the right to use the public places, streets and ways, to exercise their rights to free speech and association, to travel, to be employed and to be involved in school, church and other association activities and find that any restrictions upon these rights are essential for the purposes set out herein and are limited to meeting the essential needs found herein and are otherwise scrupulously protected herein. It is the desire and intent of the board of commissioners that in assessing penalties for violation of section 86-33 of this article, the court should utilize to the full extent of the law procedures and sentences other than monetary fines to that the minor bears the burden for violation of the ordinance rather than a parent of such minor. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-48, § 2, 12-3-13; Ord. No. O-2018-34, § 2, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 86-32. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article, the following words and terms, unless the context indicates a different meaning, shall have the meanings given as follows: 
    City means The City of Pharr, County of Hidalgo, Texas. 
    Minor means any person under the age of 17 years of age, or as otherwise defined by the Texas Family Code (title III). 
    Person means any person having legal custody, or control, of a minor such as: 
(1)  A natural or adoptive parent; 
(2)  A legal guardian; 
(3)  A person who stands in loco parentis; or 
(4)  As a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of a court of competent jurisdiction; and 
(5)  Any person with control over a public place, establishment, or other organized association or event. 
    Prohibited hours shall also refer to herein for all purposes as the curfew. The prevailing standard of time, whether Central Standard Time or Central Daylight Savings time, generally observed at that hour by the public in the city. It shall be prima facie the time then observed in the city administrative offices and police station. 
    Public place means any place accessible by the public, a business or public facility, a way or place, of whatever nature, opened to the use of the public as a matter of right, or for purposes of vehicular travel a street, or in the case of a sidewalk thereof, for pedestrian travel. The term street includes the legal right-of-way, including but not limited to the traffic lanes, curbs, sidewalks, whether paved or unpaved, and any grass plots or other ground found within the legal right-of-way of the street. The term street applies irrespective of what it may be called or informally named, whether alley, avenue, road, roadway, highway or otherwise. 
    Remain means to stay behind, to tarry and to stay unnecessarily upon the streets, including but not limited to the congregating of groups (or of interacting minors) in which any minors involved would not be using the streets for ordinary or serious purposes such as mere passage or going home. Within this meaning, this article does not prohibit mere presence, but is intended as an article prohibiting "remaining." 
(Ord. No. O-2013-48, § 3, 12-3-13; Ord. No. O-2018-34, § 3, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 86-33. - Curfew hours for minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under 17 years of age to be or remain in or upon any public place within the city during the following curfew periods beginning at: 
(1)  10:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; 
(2)  12:01 a.m. until 6:00 a.m. on any Friday or Saturday; and 
(3)  9:00 a.m. until 2:30 p.m. during the effective regular school calendar requiring student attendance. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-48, § 4, 12-3-13; Ord. No. O-2018-34, § 4, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 86-34. - Exceptions. 
    It shall be a defense to the accusation of unlawful conduct pursuant to section 86-33 of this article for the accused minor to demonstrate that he or she was: 
(1)  Accompanied by a legal guardian or parent (biological, adoptive, or step-parent) of such minor. 
(2)  Accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent or legal guardian of such minor to take said parent's place in accompanying said minor for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area. 
(3)  When exercising First Amendment Rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly. 
(4)  Returning home, by a direct route from a school activity, or an activity of a religious or other voluntary association. 
(5)  Engaged in activities organized by the schools. In such cases, such activity shall have been organized by or through the schools or other similar organization in a regular course. 
(6)  Involved in interstate or intrastate motor vehicle travel, with consent of an authorized legal guardian or parent. This section specifically exempts interstate travel beginning or ending in the city. This section does not exempt travel merely in or around the city. 
(7)  Involved in an emergency that was a result of unforeseen circumstances that required immediate action including but not limited to: fire, natural disaster, automobile accident, and any other possible situation that threatened serious harm, injury, or loss of life. 
(8)  Each of the foregoing exceptions, and the several limitations such as provisions for notification, are severable, as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-48, § 5, 12-3-13; Ord. No. O-2018-34, § 5, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 86-35. - Responsibility of persons in presence of minor. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, as defined herein, to knowingly permit or by inefficient control allow such minor to be or remain upon any public place under circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise outside the scope of, this article. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge that a person should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a minor in that person's legal custody. It shall be no defense that a person was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of such minor. It shall be a defense to the accusation of unlawful conduct pursuant to this section of this article for the accused person to demonstrate that the person has reported an inability to control the minor to a law enforcement agency with jurisdiction over the person's place of residence, establishment, or public place, or to demonstrate that the person has enrolled in any parenting classes at a public or private educational institution. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-48, § 6, 12-3-13; Ord. No. O-2018-34, § 6, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 86-36. - Police procedures. 
(a)  A police officer of the city, upon finding or having attention called to any minor on the streets in prima facie violation of the this article, should follow the complete police department juvenile procedures. In the absence of convincing evidence such as a birth certificate, a police officer on the street shall on the first instance use his best judgment in determining age. In following the police department juvenile procedures, a police officer must act in accordance with the Texas Family Code as it is now enacted or may be hereafter amended. In the case of the first violation by a minor, the juvenile officer or other designated police officer shall send to a parent written notice of said violation, by certified mail, with a warning that any subsequent violation may result in enforcement of parental responsibility and of applicable penalties. 
(b)  The prohibition enacted by this article shall apply to persons as defined herein. If a police officer takes into custody for violation of this article a minor who is discovered to be under the age of ten years, such minor shall not therefore be accused of unlawful conduct pursuant to this article. Instead, the officer is to release such minor to his or her parent, guardian, custodian or other responsible person as may be authorized as soon as practicable pursuant to the city police department juvenile procedures. This subsection shall not be construed as a defense to prosecution of the parent of such minor charged with an offense. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-48, § 7, 12-3-13; Ord. No. O-2018-34, § 7, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 86-37. - Penalties. 
    If, after notice pursuant to section 86-36 of a first violation by a minor, a person violates section 86-33 (in connection with a second violation by said minor) this shall be treated as a first offense by the person. Upon conviction for such first offense, a person may be fined an amount not to exceed $100.00. Upon conviction for a subsequent offense of violation of this article, a person may be fined in an amount no more than $200.00 for each subsequent conviction. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-48, § 8, 12-3-13; Ord. No. O-2018-34, § 8, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 86-38. - Referral. 
    Any minor who shall violate any of the provisions of this article more than two times shall be referred by the juvenile officer to the Hidalgo County Juvenile Probation Department for processing as a child having engaged in conduct indicating a need for supervision. In making any such referral, the juvenile officer shall follow the appropriate police department juvenile procedures. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-48, § 9, 12-3-13; Ord. No. O-2018-34, § 9, 9-17-18) 
Sec. 86-39. - Construction and severability. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the board of commissioners of the city that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this article are severable; and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this article shall be declared unconstitutional or invalid, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this article since the same would have been enacted by the board of commissioners without the incorporation in this article of any such unconstitutional or invalid phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. It is intended by the board of commissioners in enacting this article that it be held inapplicable in any case where its application would be unconstitutional. A constitutional construction is intended and shall be given. The board of commissioners does not intend to violate the Constitution of the State of Texas or the Constitution of the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-48, § 10, 12-3-13; Ord. No. O-2018-34, § 10, 9-17-18) 
ARTICLE III. - GRAFFITI[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1, adopted March 3, 1998, added § 86-6 and subsections 86-6.1-86-6.9 to Art. I of this chapter. Inasmuch as there already exists provisions designated as § 86-6, to avoid duplication of numbers and to better organize the provisions of Ord. No. O-98-19, a new Art. III, §§ 86-40-86-49, has been added, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 86-40. - Damaging property, graffiti abatement. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for person to cut, hack, deface, break, damage, remove, paint, mark or otherwise inure any building, fence, railing, awning, post, fixture, telephone, telegraph or electric wire or post, shade tree, ornament, monument, bulletin board, sign show frame, fruit or other stand, platform, bridge or any other thing not the property or under the control of such person. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each owner or person having the right of possession of any property within the city to keep and maintain their properties, including buildings and fences or other structures, free of graffiti, and to promptly remove such graffiti from the property. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this section for any person at any time to damage, destroy or injure any public property or property of the city or of an independent school district or any improvements located thereon, or to deface any of such property by painting, marking or otherwise placing thereon any signs, paintings, words or language, whether obscene or not. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person at any time to throw upon or allow to come to rest upon any public place or property of the city or of an independent school district any trash, garbage or litter, as such terms are defined in the litter ordinance of the city. 
(e)  The violation of any of the provisions of this section is declared to be unlawful and a misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 86-45. 
(f)  The penalty provisions of this section shall not preclude the use of any other remedy a law or in equity to which the city may resort to ensure that the provisions of this section are not violated. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6), 4-7-98) 
Sec. 86-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings described to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aerosol paint means an aerosolized paint product, including a clear or pigmented lacquer or finish. 
    Graffiti means any unauthorized inscription, work, signature, symbol, design or other marking of any sort which is etched, written, painted, drawn or applied in any other way to any structure, building or property of any sort or to any portion or element therefor, whether the property is public or private. 
    Minor means any person under 17 years of age who is not and has not been married or who has not had his or her disabilities of minority removed for general purposes. 
    Owner means person with the legal right of possession to tangible property which includes, but is not limited to, the actual owner of his lessee. 
    Parent means any person having legal custody of a minor as a: 
(1)  Natural or adoptive parents; 
(2)  Legal guardian; 
(3)  Parent who stands in loco parentis; or 
(4)  Person to whom legal custody has been given by order of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
    Unauthorized means without the permission of the owner or person in control of property, whether public or private. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6.1), 4-7-98) 
Sec. 86-42. - Parental responsibility. 
(a)  The city commission has determined that parental responsibility for the activities of minors is a community norm. As parental control increases [sic]. Therefore, legal sanctions to enforce parental responsibility have been shown to be significantly effective in minimizing the incidence of juvenile delinquency and in protecting minors and the community at large. The city commission hereby determines that making the parents responsible for the activities of minors will accomplish under local conditions the purposes stated in this section. It is the desire and intent of the city commission that in assessing penalties for violation of this section, the court should utilize to the full extent of the law procedures and sentences allowable so that the minor is punished for violation of this section and that the parent or guardian of such minor also has the responsibility for payment of monetary fines or penalties. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a parent of a minor to fail to repair or pay for any property damage proximately caused by: 
(1)  The negligent conduct of the minor if the conduct is reasonably attributable to the negligent failure of the parent to exercise control and reasonable discipline of the minor; or 
(2)  The willful and malicious conduct of a minor who is at least 12 years of age but under 18 years of age. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a parent having legal custody of a minor knowingly to permit or by inefficient control to allow such minor to violate this section. "Knowingly" includes knowledge that a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts and activities of a minor. It shall be no defense that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of such minor. It shall be a defense to the accusation of unlawful conduct pursuant to this section for the accused parent to demonstrate that the parent has reported an inability to control the minor to a law enforcement agency with jurisdiction over the parent's place of residence or to demonstrate that the parent has enrolled in parenting classes at a public or private educational institution. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6.2), 4-7-98) 
Sec. 86-43. - Graffiti abatement; removal by city. 
(a)  [Assessment for removal.] Upon the failure of the responsible person to remove graffiti, the director of planning or a designee are authorized to cause the graffiti to be abated and assess the costs against the person responsible for such graffiti, if known. If the person is a minor, the cost shall be assessed against the parent. If the person responsible for such graffiti is unknown, the costs shall be borne by the city. 
(b)  [Right to remove from abutting public property.] In abating such graffiti, the city or its private contractor is expressly authorized to enter and abate graffiti upon utility cabinets and exterior walls and fences abutting public streets, property or rights-of-way. 
(c)  Graffiti abatement, private property consent forms. Property owners in the city may consent in advance to city entry onto private property for graffiti removal purposes. The city will make forms of such consent available. 
(d)  Graffiti abatement, public property. Where a structure is owned by a public entity other than the city, the removal of the graffiti may be authorized only after securing the consent of an authorized representative of the public entity having jurisdiction over the structure. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6.3), 4-7-98) 
Sec. 86-44. - Regulation of possession, sale or purchase of aerosol paint and other graffiti related items. 
(a)  Possession of aerosol paint by minor. 
(1)  Possession aerosol paint. It shall be unlawful for a minor to possess aerosol paint of any sort or character. 
(2)  Affirmative defense. It shall be an affirmative defense to a violation of this section that, at the time of possession, the minor was accompanied or supervised by a parent or guardian, a teacher in connection with a bona fide school project, a supervisor during the minor's regular employment, or that the minor possessed the aerosol paint on the property on which he or she lives or that the possession occurred as part of an organized event sponsored or supervised by the city, a school, a church or some other officially recognized entity. 
(b)  Possession of aerosol paint containers. It shall constitute an offense for any person to have in his possession any pressurized can containing paint, dye or a similar substance while upon any public highway, street, alley, easement, right-of-way or other public place, whether said person is or is not in any automobile, vehicle or other conveyance, with the intent of using said substance to place graffiti upon permanent structures within the city. 
(c)  Possession of pressurized paint containers in public parks and buildings. It shall constitute an offense for any person to have in his possession any pressurized can containing paint, dye or a similar substance while in any public park, playground, swimming pool, recreational facility or other such public place owned, operated or managed by the city, except authorized employees of the city or an individual or authorized employee of an individual or company under contract with the city. 
(d)  Store display. It shall constitute an offense for any person licensed to do business in the city to display: 
(1)  Felt tip pens, markers or the like with a writing tip larger than one-quarter inch in diameter; 
(2)  Etching materials capable of making markings, scratching, etc., on plate glass; or 
(3)  Aerosol spray cans containing paint, dye or similar substances, which container displays are now otherwise regulated by state or federal law, for sale from any self-service or self-help counter that is not under constant supervision of store personnel. 
(e)  Prohibition of certain aerosol paint container sales or purchases. 
(1)  It shall constitute an offense for any person to knowingly or intentionally sell, exchange, give or loan, or knowingly or intentionally cause or permit to be sold, exchanged, given or loaned, any aerosol paint, dye or a similar substance to anyone knowing that the person who receives the pressurized container intends to use it to place graffiti upon structures within the city. 
(2)  It shall constitute an offense for anyone to purchase any aerosol paint, dye or a similar substance with the intent of using said substance to place graffiti upon any structures within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6.4), 4-7-98) 
Sec. 86-45. - Police procedures. 
(a)  A police officer of the city, upon findings or having attention called to any minor violating this section shall follow the complete police department juvenile procedures insofar as those procedures have been approved by the juvenile courts. In the absence of convincing evidence, such as a birth certificate, a police officer on the street shall, on the first instance, use his best judgement in determining age. In following police department juvenile procedures, a police officer must act in accordance with the family code as it is now enacted or may be hereafter amended. In the case of the first violation by a minor, the juvenile officer or other designated police office shall send to a parent written notice of such violations by certified mail with a warning that any subsequent violation may result in the enforcement of parental responsibility and of applicable penalties. 
(b)  The prohibition enacted by this section shall apply only to minors defined by V.T.C.A., Family Code § 51.02. If a police officer takes into custody for violation of this section a minor who is discovered to be under the age of ten years, such minor shall not therefore be accused of unlawful conduct pursuant to this section. Instead, the officer is to release such minor to their parent, guardian, custodian or other responsible adult as soon as practicable pursuant to the city police department juvenile procedures. This subsection shall not be construed as a defense to prosecution of the minor or of the parent of such minor charged with an offense under this section. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6.5), 4-7-98) 
Sec. 86-46. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any violation of the provisions of this section, except as provided by subsections (b) and (c) herein, shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $1,000.00. 
(b)  If after notice, pursuant to section 86-44, of a first violation by a minor, this section offense by the minor shall be treated as a first offense by the parent. Upon conviction for such first parental offense, a parent shall be fined an amount not less than $100.00 and not more than $500.00. Upon conviction for a subsequent offense of violation of this section, a parent shall be fined in an amount not less than $500.00 and not more than $1,000.00 for each subsequent conviction. 
(c)  In lieu of the fine assessed herein, the municipal judge is authorized and empowered to require that any offender over the age of 18 years and any minor offender, with the written consent of their parent, spend at least eight hours and not more than 16 hours in community service to the city. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6.6), 4-7-98) 
Sec. 86-47. - Referral of minor repeat offenders. 
    Any minor who shall violate any of the provisions of this section more than two times shall be referred to the county juvenile probation department for processing as a child having engaged in conduct indicating a need for supervision. In making any such referral, appropriate police department juvenile procedures shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6.7), 4-7-98) 
Sec. 86-48. - Reward for furnishing information leading to apprehension and conviction of a person willfully damaging certain property. 
(a)  The city hereby authorizes payment of a reward of $50.00 for furnishing information to the chief of police of the city leading to the apprehension and conviction of any person willfully damaging any traffic signs, street name signs, traffic control devices, public buildings or furniture located therein, or any property of the city in violation of state and federal laws. 
(b)  If information is furnished to the chief of police leading to the apprehension and conviction of any person violating this section, the city treasurer is hereby authorized upon proper certification from the chief of police to issue a check on the general fund of the city in payment of the reward provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6.8), 4-7-98) 
Sec. 86-49. - Construction and severability. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city commission that the paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this section are severable; and if any phrase, clause, sentence or paragraph of this section shall be declared unconstitutional or invalid, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences or paragraphs of this section since the same would have been enacted by the city commission without the incorporation in this article of such unconstitutional or invalid phrase, clause, sentence or paragraph. It is intended by the city commission in enacting this section that it shall be held inapplicable in any case where its application would be unconstitutional. A constitutional construction of this article is intended and shall be given. The city commission does not intend to violate the Constitution of the State of Texas or the Constitution of the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. O-98-19, § 1(86-6.9), 4-7-98) 
Secs. 86-50-86-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - IDENTITY THEFT PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Sec. 86-61. - Program adoption. 
    The City of Pharr ("City") developed this identity theft prevention program ("program") pursuant to the Federal Trade Commission's Red Flags Rule ("Rule"), which implements Section 114 of the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act of 2003. 16 C. F. R. § 681.2. This program was developed for the utility department of the city ("utility") with oversight and approval of the city commission. After consideration of the size and complexity of the utility's operations and account systems, and the nature and scope of the utility's activities, the city commission determined that this program was appropriate for the city's utility, and therefore approved this program on May 5, 2009. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-16, § I, 5-5-09) 
Sec. 86-62. - Purpose and definitions. 
(a)  Establish an identity theft prevention program. To establish an identity theft prevention program designed to detect, prevent and mitigate identity theft in connection with the opening of a covered account or an existing covered account and to provide for continued administration of the program in compliance with Part 681 of Title 16 of the Code of Federal Regulations implementing Sections 114 and 315 of the Fair and Accurate Credit Transactions Act (FACTA) of 2003. 
(b)  Establishing and fulfilling requirements of the Red Flags Rule. The Red Flags Rule ("Rule") defines "identity theft" as "fraud committed using the identifying information of another person" and a "red flag" ("red flag") as a pattern, practice, or specific activity that indicates the possible existence of identity theft. 
Under the Rule, every financial institution and creditor is required to establish an "identity theft prevention program" tailored to its size, complexity and the nature of its operation. The program must contain reasonable policies and procedures to: 
(1)  Identify relevant red flags for new and existing covered accounts and incorporate those red flags into the program; 
(2)  Detect red flags that have been incorporated into the program; 
(3)  Respond appropriately to any red flags that are detected to prevent and mitigate identity theft; and 
(4)  Ensure the program is updated periodically, to reflect changes in risks to customers or to the safety and soundness of the creditor from identity theft. 
(c)  Red Flags Rule definitions used in this program. 
City: The City of Pharr, Texas. 
Covered account: Under the Rule, a "covered account" is: 
(1)  Any account the utility offers or maintains primarily for personal, family or household purposes, that involves multiple payments or transactions; and 
(2)  Any other account the utility offers or maintains for which there is a reasonably foreseeable risk to customers or to the safety and soundness of the utility from identity theft. 
Creditors: The Rule defines creditors "to include finance companies, automobile dealers, mortgage brokers, utility companies, and telecommunications companies. Where nonprofit and government entities defer payment for goods or services, they, too, are to be considered creditors." 
Identifying information is defined under the Rule as "any name or number that may be used, alone or in conjunction with any other information, to identify a specific person," including: name, address, telephone number, social security number, date of birth, government issued driver's license or identification number, alien registration number, government passport number, employer or taxpayer identification number, unique electronic identification number, computer's internet protocol address, or routing code. 
Program: The identity theft prevention program for the city. 
Program administrator: The utility billing and collection manager (Joe Enriquez) is the program administrator for the program. 
Utility: The utility is the utility department for the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-16, § II, 5-5-09) 
Sec. 86-63. - Identification of red flags. 
    In order to identify relevant red flags, the utility considers the types of accounts that it offers and maintains, the methods it provides to open its accounts, the methods it provides to access its accounts, and its previous experiences with identity theft. The utility identifies the following red flags, in each of the listed categories: 
(a)  Notifications and warnings from consumer credit reporting agencies. 
Red flags: 
(1)  Report of fraud accompanying a consumer credit report; 
(2)  Notice or report from a consumer credit agency of a credit freeze on a customer or applicant; 
(3)  Notice or report from a consumer credit agency of an active duty alert for an applicant; and 
(4)  Indication from a consumer credit report of activity that is inconsistent with a customer's usual pattern or activity, including but not limited to: 
a.  Recent and significant increase in volume of inquiries. 
b.  Unusual number of recent credit applications. 
c.  A material change in use of credit. 
d.  Accounts closed for cause or abuse. 
(b)  Suspicious documents. 
Red flags: 
(1)  Identification document or card that appears to be forged, altered or inauthentic; 
(2)  Identification document or card on which a person's photograph or physical description is not consistent with the person presenting the document; 
(3)  Other document with information that is not consistent with existing customer information (such as if a person's signature on a check appears forged); and 
(4)  Application for service that appears to have been altered or forged. 
(c)  Suspicious personal identifying information. 
Red flags: 
(1)  Identifying information presented that is inconsistent with other information the customer provides (example: inconsistent birth dates, lack of correlation between social security number range and date of birth); 
(2)  Identifying information presented that is inconsistent with other sources of information (for instance, social security number or an address not matching an address on a credit report); 
(3)  Identifying information presented that is the same as information shown on other applications that were found to be fraudulent; 
(4)  Identifying information presented that is consistent with fraudulent activity (such as an invalid phone number or fictitious billing address); 
(5)  Social security number presented that is the same as one given by another customer; 
(6)  An address or phone number presented that is the same as that of another person; 
(7)  A person fails to provide complete personal identifying information on an application when reminded to do so (however, by law social security numbers must not be required) or an applicant cannot provide information requested beyond what could commonly be found in a purse or wallet; and 
(8)  A person's identifying information is not consistent with the information that is on file for the customer. 
(d)  Suspicious account activity or unusual use of account. 
Red flags: 
(1)  Change of address for an account followed by a request to change the account holder's name; 
(2)  Payments stop on an otherwise consistently up-to-date account; 
(3)  Account used in a way that is not consistent with prior use (example: very high activity); 
(4)  Mail sent to the account holder is repeatedly returned as undeliverable; 
(5)  Notice to the utility that a customer is not receiving mail sent by the utility; 
(6)  Notice to the utility that an account has unauthorized activity; 
(7)  Breach in the utility's computer system security; and 
(8)  Unauthorized access to or use of customer account information. 
(e)  Alerts from others. 
Red flag: 
(1)  Notice to the utility from a customer, identity theft victim, fraud detection service, law enforcement or other person that it has opened or is maintaining a fraudulent account for a person engaged in identity theft. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-16, § III, 5-5-09) 
Sec. 86-64. - Detecting red flags. 
(a)  New accounts. In order to detect any of the red flags identified above associated with the opening of a new account, utility personnel will take the following steps to obtain and verify the identity of the person opening the account: 
Detect: 
(1)  Require certain identifying information such as name, date of birth, residential or business address, principal place of business for an entity, driver's license or other identification; 
(2)  Verify the customer's identity (for instance, review a driver's license or other identification card); 
(3)  Review documentation showing the existence of a business entity; 
(4)  Request additional documentation to establish identity; and 
(5)  Independently contact the customer or business. 
(b)  Existing accounts. In order to detect any of the red flags identified above for an existing account, utility personnel will take the following steps to monitor transactions with an account: 
Detect: 
(1)  Verify the identification of customers if they request information (in person, via telephone, via facsimile, via email); 
(2)  Verify the validity of requests to close accounts or change billing addresses; and 
(3)  Verify changes in banking information given for billing and payment purposes. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-16, § IV, 5-5-09) 
Sec. 86-65. - Preventing and mitigating identity theft. 
    In the event utility personnel detect any identified red flags, such personnel shall take one or more of the following steps, depending on the degree of risk posed by the red flag: 
(a)  Prevent and mitigate. 
(1)  Continue to monitor an account for evidence of identity theft; 
(2)  Contact the customer, sometimes through multiple methods; 
(3)  Change any passwords or other security devices that permit access to accounts; 
(4)  Not open a new account; 
(5)  Close an existing account; 
(6)  Do not close the account, but monitor or contact authorities; 
(7)  Reopen an account with a new number; 
(8)  Notify the program administrator for determination of the appropriate step(s) to take; 
(9)  Notify law enforcement; or 
(10)  Determine that no response is warranted under the particular circumstances. 
(b)  Protect customer identifying information. In order to further prevent the likelihood of identity theft occurring with respect to utility accounts, the utility will take the following steps with respect to its internal operating procedures to protect customer identifying information: 
(1)  Ensure that its website is secure or provide clear notice that the website is not secure; 
(2)  Where and when allowed, ensure complete and secure destruction of paper documents and computer files containing customer information; 
(3)  Ensure that office computers are password protected and that computer screens lock after a set period of time; 
(4)  Change passwords on office computers on a regular basis; 
(5)  Ensure all computers are backed up properly and any backup information is secured; 
(6)  Keep offices clear of papers containing customer information; 
(7)  Request only the last four digits of social security numbers (if any); 
(8)  Ensure computer virus protection is up to date; and 
(9)  Require and keep only the kinds of customer information that are necessary for utility purposes. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-16, § V, 5-5-09) 
Sec. 86-66. - Program updates. 
    This program will be periodically reviewed and updated to reflect changes in risks to customers and the soundness of the utility from identity theft. At least annually, the program administrator will consider the utility's experiences with identity theft situations, changes in identity theft methods, changes in identity theft detection and prevention methods, changes in types of accounts the utility maintains and changes in the utility's business arrangements with other entities, consult with law enforcement authorities, and consult with other city personnel. After considering these factors, the program administrator will determine whether changes to the program, including the listing of red flags, are warranted. If warranted, the program administrator will update the program or present the city commission with his or her recommended changes and the city commission will make a determination of whether to accept, modify or reject those changes to the program. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-16, § VI, 5-5-09) 
Sec. 86-67. - Program administration. 
(a)  Oversight. Responsibility for developing, implementing and updating this program lies with the finance department. The program administrator is the utility billing and collection manager. The program administrator will be responsible for the program administration, for ensuring appropriate training of utility staff on the program, for reviewing any staff reports regarding the detection of red flags and the steps for preventing and mitigating identity theft, determining which steps of prevention and mitigation should be taken in particular circumstances and considering periodic changes to the program. 
(b)  Staff training. Initially, all utility staff shall be trained either by or under the direction of the program administrator in the detection of red flags, and the responsive steps to be taken when a red flag is detected.
