Thereafter, all utility staff shall undergo update training not less than annually. Additionally, all new utility employees shall undergo training. 
(c)  Service provider arrangements. In the event the utility engages a service provider to perform an activity in connection with one or more accounts, including but not limited to franchise utility providers, the utility will take the following steps to ensure the service provider performs its activity in accordance with reasonable policies and procedures designed to detect, prevent, and mitigate the risk of identity theft. 
(1)  Require, by contract or contract amendment, that service providers have such policies and procedures in place; and 
(2)  Require, by contract or contract amendment, that service providers review the utility's program and report any red flags to the program administrator. 
(d)  Specific program elements and confidentiality. For the effectiveness of identity theft prevention programs, the Red Flag Rule envisions a degree of confidentiality regarding the utility's specific practices relating to identity theft detection, prevention and mitigation. Therefore, under this program, knowledge of such specific practices are to be limited to the finance department and those employees who need to known them for purposes of preventing identity theft. Because this program is to be adopted by a public body and thus publicly available, it would be counterproductive to list these specific practices here. Therefore, only the program's general red flag detection, implementation and prevention practices are listed in this document. 
(Ord. No. O-2009-16, § VII, 5-5-09) 
Secs. 86-68-86-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - LITTERING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2011-41, §§ 1-4, adopted Sept. 6, 2011, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included as §§ 86-76-86-79. 

Sec. 86-76. - Authority; area. 
(a)  This article and provisions herewith shall be included in the Pharr Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  As matters related to the public's health, safety, and welfare is of the utmost concern, the City of Pharr shall be authorized to enforce through its personnel, including but not limited to law and code enforcement as well as the city attorney, this article as may be allowed by law herein. This article is effective and shall be enforced within the corporate boundaries of the City of Pharr and within 5,000 feet outside the limits. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-41, § 1, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 86-77. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Business shall be defined for purposes of this article as an entity with any interest in property, wholly or in part, with the right of control. 
    Litter and/or littering shall be defined for purposes of this article as waste products such as containers, papers, wrappers, food, cans, bottles, or any other thing that is disposed on the property of another, public right of way, street, or highway without consent. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-41, § 2, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 86-78. - Littering declared unlawful; enforcement. 
    Littering shall be prohibited in the City of Pharr within the area prescribed in this article. Should any person or business litter, or allow the commission of any act or condition that causes littering, city personnel and the city attorney may take any action to enforce this or any ordinance to prevent and summarily abate and remove litter and devices causing litter to occur. These actions may include but not be limited to allowing for municipal resources and personnel to: abate any premises or property, closure, condemn, remove any person or thing, court action, suspend, cancel, or void any license or permit issued by the City of Pharr, and any and all other relief as may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-41, § 3, 9-6-11) 
Sec. 86-79. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any violation of this article shall be subject to both civil and criminal penalties. A criminal conviction shall be a Class C misdemeanor. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. 
(b)  A liable party shall be subject to a civil penalty up to $1,500.00 per occurrence, or the maximum allowed by law as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-41, § 4, 9-6-11) 
Secs. 86-80-86-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NOISE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2013-12, §§ 1-6, adopted April 16, 2013, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included as §§ 86-101-86-106. 

Sec. 86-101. - Authority; area. 
(a)  The City of Pharr hereby adopts in its entirety the V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 217, subch. C, §§ 217.041, 217.042, as may be amended from time to time. This article and provisions herewith shall be included in the Pharr Code of Ordinances. The city further incorporates V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 250, § 250.001, and V.T.C.A., Election Code ch. 61, § 61.004. 
(b)  As matters related to the public's health, safety, and welfare is of the utmost concern, the City of Pharr shall be authorized to enforce, through its city attorney, this article as may be allowed by law herein. This article is effective and shall be enforced within the corporate boundaries of the City of Pharr and within 5,000 feet outside the limits. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-12, § 1, 4-16-13; Ord. No. O-2014-22, § 1, 6-3-14; Ord. No. O-2014-35, § 1, 8-5-14) 
Sec. 86-102. - Definitions. 
    The following terms and phrases are defined herein for interpretation and use in and enforcement of this article. The definitions referenced herein shall not be used in giving meaning or interpretation to any other ordinance, rule, resolution, or legal provision not otherwise included within this article. 
    A-weighted sound level means the sound pressure level in decibels as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level so read is designated dB(A) or dBA. 
    Noise nuisance means any loud, irritating, vexing or disturbing sound originating from a nearby property under separate ownership which causes injury, discomfort, or distress of a person of reasonable nervous sensibilities, or any sound that exceeds the maximum permitted sound levels specified in this article. 
    Nonresidential property shall mean any real property that is not included in the definition of residential property as defined in this section. Without limitation, the term includes properties that have been developed other than as residential properties, properties that are undeveloped, and properties that are devoted to public purposes, such as public streets and parks. 
    Plainly audible when describing a sound or noise means any amplified sound or noise that can be clearly heard by a person with normal hearing faculties such that a reasonable person would believe such sound or noise unreasonably disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others in violation of this article. The term does not require the clear appreciation of specific words of speech or specific words of a song. 
    Property line means, with respect to single occupancy properties on the same side of a street, the line along the ground surface and its vertical extension that separates the real property occupied by one person from that occupied by another person. With respect to single occupancy properties on opposing sides of a street, the term means the curb line or line that separates the real property and the adjacent street. With respect to shared occupancy properties the term means the imaginary line that represents the legal limits of occupancy of any person who occupies an apartment, condominium, hotel or motel room, office, or any other type of occupancy from that of other occupants. 
    Residential property shall mean any real property developed and used for human habitation that contains living facilities, including provisions for sleeping, eating, cooking, and sanitation, unless such premises are actually occupied and used primarily for purposes other than human habitation. 
    Sound level means the weighted sound pressure level obtained by the use of a sound level meter and frequency weighting network as specified in American National Standards Institute specifications for sound level meters. If the frequency weighting employed is not indicated, the A-weighting shall apply. 
    Sound level meter means an instrument that is used to measure sound pressure levels. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-12, § 2, 4-16-13; Ord. No. O-2014-22, § 2, 6-3-14; Ord. No. O-2014-35, § 2, 8-5-14) 
Sec. 86-103. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  The following acts, among others not hereinafter enumerated, are declared to be unlawful and in violation of the provisions of this article when such acts are done or accomplished, caused, or carried on in such a manner, or with such volume, intensity, or with continued duration, so as to create or allow sound that may annoy, cause distress, or to disturb the quiet, comfort, or repose of any reasonable person, within the vicinity or hearing thereof, or so as to damage, endanger or injure the safety or health of humans or animals, or so as to interfere with the physical well-being of humans or animals, or so as to endanger or injure personal or real property: 
(1)  The playing or permitting or causing the playing of any radio, television, drum, juke box, musical instrument, sound amplifier, notification device, or similar device which produces, reproduces, or amplifies sound; 
(2)  The keeping of any animal, fowl, or bird, which makes frequent or long, continued noise. 
(3)  The continued or frequent sounding of any horn or other signal device on any automobile or vehicle, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle, except as a danger signal; 
(4)  The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, automobile, motorcycle, or other motor vehicle or boat, except through a properly installed muffler or other device which prevents loud or explosive noises therefrom; 
(5)  The crying, calling, or shouting, in person or by a mechanical device, or the use of any whistle, rattle, bell, gong, clapper, hammer, drum, buzzer, horn, loudspeaker or phonograph with or without an amplifier, hand organ, or other devices or instruments, musical or otherwise; 
(6)  The raucous shouting, whistling, yelling, singing, hooting, or crying of peddlers, hawkers, vendors or any other persons; 
(7)  Operating or controlling a motor vehicle in either a public or private place within the city to operate any sound amplifier which is part of, or connected to, any radio, stereo receiver, compact disc player, cassette player, or other similar device in the motor vehicle, in such a manner that, when operated, is audible at a distance of 30 or more feet from the source or, when operated causes a person to be aware of the vibration accompanying the sound in any location outside the confines of the vehicle emitting the sound, noise, or vibration; 
(8)  Operation of a sound amplification device or sound vehicle as defined and prohibited by V.T.C.A., Election Code ch. 61, § 61.004. 
(b)  The acts enumerated in the following sections of this article, among others, are declared to be unlawful in violation of this article, but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive. 
(c)  In addition to the violations established by the preceding sections of this article, it is unlawful for any person to make, assist in making, permit, continue, cause to be made or continued, or permit the continuance of any sound at any location beyond the property lines of the property on which the sound is being generated that when measured as provided in subsection (e) of this article exceeds the applicable dB(A) level listed below for the property on which the sound is received: 
(1)  Residential property: 
a.  Eighty dB(A) during daytime hours; 
b.  Seventy-five dB(A) during nighttime hours. 
(2)  Nonresidential property: Eighty-five dB(A) at all times. 
(d)  Any sound that exceeds the dB(A) levels set forth in this article under the conditions and measurement criteria set forth in this article is a violation of this article. Evidence that an activity or sound source produces a sound that exceeds the dB(A) levels specified in this section shall be prima facie evidence of a sound that unreasonably disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others in violation of this article. 
(e)  Method of sound measurement. Whenever portions of this article prohibit sound over a certain decibel limit, measurement shall be made with a type 1 or type 2 calibrated sound level meter utilizing the A-weighting scale and the slow meter response as specified by the American National Standards Institute (A.N.S.I. S1.4-1984/85A). Measurements recorded shall be taken so as to provide a proper representation of the sound being measured. The microphone of the meter shall be positioned so as not to create any unnatural enhancement or diminution of the measured sound. A windscreen for the microphone shall be used. Measurements of sound generated shall be taken from the property line of the nonresidential property or residential property where the sound is received towards the source of the sound. 
(f)  The persons responsible for violations of this article are identified as follows: 
(1)  At residential property. Any resident present at the time of the offense, and any guest or trespasser with the ability to control the level of noise at the time of the offense when no resident is present at the time of the offense. 
(2)  At nonresidential property. Any business owner, operator, manager, employee in charge, and all persons in control or in possession of the noise nuisance generating instrument or property at the time of the offense. 
(3)  At any location with an unattended noise nuisance producing machine, device, instrument, animal or combination of same. Any person who leaves unattended any machine, instrument, device, animal, or any combination of same, which thereafter commences producing or dispensing noise in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-12, § 3, 4-16-13; Ord. No. O-2014-22, § 3, 6-3-14; Ord. No. O-2014-35, § 3, 8-5-14) 
Sec. 86-104. - Enforcement. 
    Should any person or business commit a violation of this article or otherwise create a nuisance, or allowed the commission of any act or condition that violates this article or creates a nuisance, city personnel or the city attorney may take any action to enforce this or any ordinance to prevent and summarily abate any conditions or nuisance. These actions may include but not be limited to allowing for municipal resources and personnel to: abate any premises or property, closure, condemn, remove any person or thing, court action, suspend, cancel, or void any license or permit issued by the City of Pharr, and any and all other relief as may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-12, § 4, 4-16-13; Ord. No. O-2014-22, § 4, 6-3-14; Ord. No. O-2014-35, § 4, 8-5-14) 
Sec. 86-105. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to an emergency; 
(2)  Sound produced by emergency vehicles; 
(3)  Sound produced by a vehicle motor with a properly installed muffler while the vehicle is moving on a private or public right-of-way, public waterway, airport runway, railway, or moving or stationary in furtherance of commercial activities at a commercial location; 
(4)  Sound produced by any governmental body in the performance of a governmental function or in the furtherance of preparation for a governmental function; 
(5)  Sound generated at a scheduled public stadium event; by parade spectators and participants on the parade route during a permitted parade; by outdoor celebration participants sponsored or co-sponsored by the City of Pharr for the general welfare of the public; by patrons and participants using pyrotechnic devices with a permit approved by the City of Pharr; by City of Pharr sponsored pyrotechnic displays that are inspected and approved; 
(6)  Sound generated from normal activities conducted on public playgrounds and public or private school grounds, including but not limited to, school athletic and school entertainment events; 
(7)  Sound generated by any activity in which the regulation thereof has been preempted by state or federal law, including, but not limited to, sound produced by aircraft in flight and interstate commerce transactions and activities; 
(8)  Sound generated by the normal maintenance of property, such as lawn mowing, provided the activities take place from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.; 
(9)  Sound produced by the operation of any air-conditioning unit, heat pump, HVAC system, or swimming pool machinery which does not produce a sound exceeding 75 dBA on residential property or 85 dBA on nonresidential property, when measured at the nearest exterior wall of a residential or commercial building under separate ownership; 
(10)  Sound produced by construction demolition, repair, drilling, excavation, and alteration during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m., unless the work is of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and safety; 
(11)  Sounds produced by an association or private club, or a sport shooting range as defined by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 250, § 250.001, as long as the activities take place from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. 
(12)  In the interest of the public or the city's welfare being social or economic, the City of Pharr may waive any of the provisions of this article in the interest of justice. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-12, § 5, 4-16-13; Ord. No. O-2014-22, § 5, 6-3-14; Ord. No. O-2014-35, § 5, 8-5-14) 
Sec. 86-106. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any violation of this article shall be subject to both civil and criminal penalties. A criminal conviction shall be a class C misdemeanor. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. 
(b)  A liable party shall be subject to a civil penalty of $1,000.00 per day or the maximum allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. O-2013-12, § 6, 4-16-13; Ord. No. O-2014-22, § 6, 6-3-14; Ord. No. O-2014-35, § 6, 8-5-14) 
Secs. 86-107-86-109. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - ILLEGAL SYNTHETIC CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES AND RELATED PARAPHERNALIA 

Sec. 86-110. - Purpose and intent. 
    The board of commissioners finds that this article is to prohibit the use, possession, sale, ingestion, or smoking of illegal synthetic controlled substances and the use, possession, or sale of any related paraphernalia, hereinafter defined, within the city limits of the City of Pharr, Texas. Any form of delivery to include a simple gift constitutes a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-38, § 1, 8-19-14) 
Sec. 86-111. - Definitions. 
    Words and phrases used in this article shall have the meanings set forth in this section, unless the context of their usage clearly requires otherwise. Words and phrases which are not defined in this article but are defined in other ordinances of the City of Pharr shall be given the meanings set forth in those ordinances. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense shall include the future tense (and vice versa); words in the plural number shall include the singular number (and vice versa); and words in the masculine gender shall include the feminine gender (and vice versa). Other words and phrases shall be given their common, ordinary meaning unless the context clearly requires otherwise. 
    "Cigarette" that is made of tobacco or tobacco mixed with another ingredient and wrapped or covered with a material other than tobacco; and that is not a cigar. 
    "City" as used herein shall mean the City of Pharr, Texas. 
    "Illegal synthetic controlled substance" means any plant or other substance, whether described as tobacco, herbs, incense, spice, or any blend thereof, regardless of whether the substance is marketed for the purpose of being smoked, or by its design can be primarily used in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body that includes, but is not limited to any one of the following substances or chemicals: 
(1)  Salvia divinorum or salvinorin A; all parts of the plant presently classified botanically as salvia divinorum, whether growing or not, the seeds thereof, any extract from any part of such plant, and every compound, manufacture, salts, derivative, mixture or preparation of such plant, its seeds or extracts or similar structural analogs; 
(2)  Synthetic cannabinoids, commonly known as "synthetic marijuana", "K2", or "Spice". 
(3)  2-[(1R,3S)-3 hydroxycyclohexyl]-5-(2-methoyloctan-2-yl)phenol (also known as CP47,497) and homologues or similar structural analogs; 
(4)  (6aS, 10aS)-9-(hydroxymethyl)-6, 6-dimethryl-3-(2-methyloctan-2yl)-6a, 7, 10, 10a-tetrahydrobenzo[c]chromen-1-ol (also known as HU-211 or dexanabinol) or similar structural analogs; 
(5)  1-pentyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole (also known as JWH-018) or similar structural analogs; 
(6)  1-butyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole (also known as JWH-073) or similar structural analogs; 
(7)  1-pentyl-3-(4-methoxynaphthoyl)indole (also known as JWH-081) or similar structural analogs; 
(8)  1-[2-(4-morpholinyl)ethyl]-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole (JWH-200); 
(9)  5-(1,1-dimethylheptyl)-2-[(1R,3S)-3-hydroxycyclohexanol; CP-47, 497; or 
(10)  5-1,1-dimethyloctyl)-2-[1R,3S-3-hydroxycyclohexyl]-phenol(cannabicyclohexanol; CP-47, 497 C8 homologue). 
    "Marketed names of illegal synthetic products." Illegal synthetic products include the products marketed under the following commercial names, [including] but not limited to: Blaze, Dascents, Diablo, Fire N' Ice, Genie, K-2, K-2 Summit, K-2 Sex, KO Knock-Out 2, Mojo, Pandora Potpourri, Pep Spice, Safe, Salvia Divinorum, Sense, Silver, Skunk, Solar Flare, Spice, Spice Cannabinoid, Spice Diamond, Spice Gold, Spicy Green, Yucatan Fire, and Zohai. 
    "Person" means an individual, firm, corporation, partnership, organization, association, wholesaler, retailer, any licensed or unlicensed business, or other legal entity. 
    "Related paraphernalia" shall mean any device, equipment, material, object, or product that is primarily used, or intended for use, or by its design can be primarily used in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body illegal synthetic controlled substances and may include, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Kits used, intended for use or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing or harvesting derived from any illegal synthetic controlled substances. 
(2)  Kits used, intended for use or designed for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing or preparing illegal synthetic controlled substances. 
(3)  Isomerization devices used, intended for use or designed for use in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is an illegal synthetic controlled substance. 
(4)  Testing equipment used, intended for use or designed for use in identifying or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness, or purity of illegal synthetic controlled substances. 
(5)  Scales and balances used, intended for use or designed for use in weighing or measuring illegal synthetic controlled substances. 
(6)  Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from or in otherwise cleaning or refining illegal synthetic controlled substances. 
(7)  Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons and mixing devices used, intended for use or designed for use in compounding illegal synthetic controlled substances. 
(8)  Containers and other objects used, intended for use or designed for use in storing or concealing illegal synthetic controlled substances. 
(9)  Hypodermic syringes, needles and other objects used, intended for use or designed for use in parenterally injecting any illegal synthetic controlled substance into the human body. 
(10)  A metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic or ceramic pipe with or without a screen, permanent screen, hashish head, or punctured metal bowl; 
(11)  A water pipe, excluding hookahs used only for smoking legal tobacco products; 
(12)  A carburetion tube or device; 
(13)  A smoking or carburetion mask; 
(14)  A chamber pipe; 
(15)  A carburetor pipe; 
(16)  An electric pipe; 
(17)  An air-driven pipe; 
(18)  A chillum; 
(19)  A bong; or 
(20)  An ice pipe or chiller. 
    "Smoke or smoking" shall mean and includes the carrying or holding of a pipe, cigar, cigarette, hookah, or water pipe of any kind which is burning, or the igniting of a pipe, cigar, cigarette, hookah, or water pipe of any kind which is burning. 
    "Tobacco product" means: 
(1)  A cigar, smoking tobacco, including granulated, plug-cut, crimp-cut, ready-rubbed, and any form of tobacco suitable for smoking in a pipe or as a cigarette; 
(2)  Chewing tobacco, including Cavendish, twist, plug, scrap, and any kind of tobacco suitable for chewing; 
(3)  Snuff or other preparations of pulverized tobacco; 
(4)  An article or product that is made of tobacco or a tobacco substitute and that is not a cigarette or cigar. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-38, § 1, 8-19-14) 
Sec. 86-112. - Offense. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use, possess, purchase, barter, give, publicly display, deliver, sell, offer for sale, or transfer any illegal synthetic controlled substance or related paraphernalia. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a person to cause any illegal synthetic controlled substance to be sold, delivered or transferred to another person. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess illegal synthetic controlled substances or related paraphernalia with the intent to inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human body. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a person to give, sell, or distribute cigarettes and tobacco products to persons younger than 18 years of age. 
(e)  Any product containing any of the chemical compounds set forth above shall be subject to the provisions of this article, regardless of whether the product is marketed under names other than those listed above. 
(f)  The culpable mental state required by V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 6.02 is specifically negated and dispensed with and a violation is a strict liability offense. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-38, § 1, 8-19-14) 
Sec. 86-113. - Affirmative defenses. 
    It shall be an affirmative defense for a person charged with an offense that: 
(1)  The use or possession was pursuant to the direction or prescription of a licensed physician or dentist authorized to direct or prescribe such act; or 
(2)  The sale or possession of salvinorin A was in conjunction with ornamental landscaping and used solely for that purpose; or 
(3)  The use or possession was by an employee or agent of a governmental entity who is acting in the course and scope of the employee's or agent's duties and whose use or possession is in compliance with the applicable procedures established by the governmental entity for the use or possession of the product. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-38, § 1, 8-19-14) 
Chapter 90 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; amusements and entertainments, ch. 14; civic and cultural facilities and affairs, ch. 30; library, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 114; traffic and vehicles, ch. 126. 
State Law reference- Municipal parks and recreation, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1015c et seq.; public improvements, bonds, occupancy tax, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 1269j-4.1; city parks, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6081h et seq.; local parks and other recreational and cultural resources, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code chs. 315, 331 et seq.; lease of land from state parks and wildlife department, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 13.006; recreational boating fees, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.092. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Regulation of activities in city parks. 
(a)  [City parks.] The following shall be known as city parks: 
(1)  Witten Park. 
(2)  Victor Garcia Municipal Park. 
(3)  Memorial Park. 
(4)  Dr. W.H. Long Park. 
(5)  Pharr Sports Complex. 
(6)  Jones-Box Park. 
(7)  Lorenzo "Lore" Garcia Park. 
(8)  Universal Estates Park. 
(9)  Trinity Ridge Park. 
(10)  HEB Tennis Complex. 
(11)  Skate Park. 
(b)  Hours closed; exception. It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or be in or upon any Pharr City Parks that are designated in subsection (a) of this section between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., excepting those persons attending an event authorized and scheduled at such location by the city through its board of commissioners, the city manager or his duly constituted agents, representatives or licensees, or when an official city event is in progress. 
(c)  Entry into closed or fenced park areas prohibited. It shall be unlawful at any time to enter into or upon any closed-off fenced area in the designated city parks without the permission of the city or its duly authorized agent or representative, provided that such closed or fenced area is marked "keep out," "authorized personnel only," or with such other indication as may indicate that such area is restricted. 
(d)  Notice of prohibitions. Signs may be posted in the designated city parks informing the public of the rights, restrictions, or prohibitions of this or any ordinance. The City of Pharr's failure to post a sign is not an exception to the enforcement of this article. 
(e)  Citation and fine as additional remedy. A person in violation shall be penalized a fine of $50.00 for the first offense. A second offense shall subject a violator to a fine of $100.00. A third offense shall subject a violator to a fine of $250.00 and any other punishment as deemed necessary by a court. Any and all fines assessed shall be paid to the city within ten days of issuance. If such penalty is not paid within the time period prescribed, a violator shall be subject to arrest and any other penalties, fees and costs that may be assessed. 
(f)  [Additional provisions.] A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. 
(Code 1976, § 23-1(a)-(e) ; Ord. No. O-2007-39, § 1, 6-19-07) 
Sec. 90-2. - Requirements for park land dedication. 
    Neighborhood and community parks and recreational facilities are those facilities providing for a variety of recreational opportunities within convenient distances from a majority of the residences to be served thereby. Park zones will be established by the parks and recreation department and shown on the official city limits map for the City of Pharr and shall be prima facie proof that any park located therein is within such a convenient distance from any residence located therein. The ultimate residential property owners, who by reason of the proximity of their property to such parks, shall be the primary beneficiaries of such facilities. Therefore, the following requirements are adopted to effect the purposes stated. 
(Ord. No. O-99-49, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 90-3. - General requirements. 
(a)  Whenever a final plat is filed for approval with the city for the development of a residential area under zoning use district R-1, in accordance with the planning and zoning regulations of the city, such plat shall contain a clear fee simple dedication of an area of land to the city for park purposes, which area shall equal one acre for every 15 acres of proposed development. Any proposed plat submitted to the city for approval shall show the area proposed to be dedicated under this section. The required dedication of this subsection may be met by a payment of money, in lieu of land, when permitted or required by other provisions of this section. 
(b)  Whenever a final plat is filed for approval with the city for the development of a residential area under zoning use districts R-2 through R-4, in accordance with the planning and zoning regulations of the city, such plat shall be accompanied by a park development fee of $250.00 per dwelling unit. 
(c)  Whenever a building permit for new construction, remodeling or addition is applied for under zoning use districts R-3 and R-4, within the city limits, on property already platted, that creates additional residential dwelling units, such permit application shall be accompanied by a park development fee of $250.00 per dwelling unit. 
(d)  Whenever a final plat is filed for approval with the city for residential development, on property that lies outside the official city limits, but within the extra territorial jurisdiction, as defined by chapter 42 of the Local Government Code, such plat shall contain a clear fee simple dedication of an area of land to the city for park purposes, which area shall equal one acre for every 15 acres of residential development. Any proposed plat submitted to the city for approval shall show the area proposed to be dedicated under this section. The required dedication of this subsection may be met by a payment of money, in lieu of land, when permitted or required by other provisions of this section. 
(e)  The city commission declares that development of an area resulting in a land dedication smaller than five acres, for public parks purposes is impractical. Therefore, if fewer than 75 acres are proposed by a plat filed for approval, the developer shall be required to pay the applicable cash in lieu of land, amount provided by section 90-4, rather than to dedicate any land area. No plat showing a dedication of less than five acres shall be approved 
(f)  In instances where an area of less than ten acres, but more than five acres, is required to be dedicated, the city shall have the right to accept the dedication for approval on the final plat, or to refuse same, after consideration of the recommendation of the parks and recreation committee, and to require payment of cash, in lieu of land, in the amount provided by section 90-4, if the city determines that sufficient park area is already in the public domain in the area of the proposed development, or if the recreation potential for that zone would be better served by expanding or improving existing parks. 
(g)  In instances where an area equal to or greater than five acres is required to be dedicated, the city shall accept the donation of land for the final plat, provided that such land is appropriate for development of park and recreation facilities, as recommended by the parks and recreation committee. If the city deems such land as unsuitable for development of parks or recreation facilities, then the developer shall be required to pay the applicable cash, in lieu of land, amount provided by section 90-4. 
(h)  The dedication required by this section shall be made by recording the final plat and contemporaneously, by separate instrument, unless additional dedication is required subsequent to the filing of the final plat. If the actual number of completed dwelling units exceed the figure upon which the original dedication was based, such additional dedication shall be required, and shall be made by payment of cash, in lieu of land, amount provided by section 90-4, or by the conveyance of an entire numbered lot or lots to the city. 
(i)  If a development fee is paid on a property outside the city limits, and such property is later annexed into the city, such fees as have already been paid shall be credited to the development at the rate of one lot equals one dwelling unit. 
(Ord. No. O-99-49, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 90-4. - Money in lieu of land. 
(a)  Subject to approval by the city commission, a land owner responsible for dedication under this section may elect to meet the requirements of section 90-3, in whole or in part, by a cash payment, in lieu of land, in the amount set forth in subsection (b) of this section. Such payment, in lieu of land, shall be made at or prior to the time of final plat recording for subdivisions. 
(b)  The dedication requirement shall be met by a payment, in lieu of land, at a per-acre price, set from time to time by resolution by the city commission, sufficient to acquire land and develop such for neighborhood and community parks and recreation facilities or make improvements to existing parks to serve the surrounding properties in which such development is located. Unless changed by the city commission, such per-acre price shall be computed on the basis of $1,250.00 per acre of development. Cash payments may be used only for acquisition or improvements of park and recreation facilities located within the same park fee zone as the development. 
(Ord. No. O-99-49, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 90-5. - Special fund; right to refund. 
(a)  There is hereby established a special fund for the deposit of all sums paid in lieu of land dedicated for park purposes, which fund shall be known as the Park Land Dedication Fund. All interest accruing to such account shall be deposited to same, and shall be used for the same purpose as the fund. 
(b)  The city shall account for all sums paid in lieu of land dedication under this section with reference to the individual building permits or plats involved. Any funds paid for such purposes must be expended by the city within ten years from the date received by the city for acquisition or development of a neighborhood park as defined herein. Such funds shall be considered to be spent on a first in, first out basis. If not so expended, the owners of the property on the last day of such period shall be entitled to a prorate refund of such sum, computed on a square footage of area basis. The owners of such property must request such refund within one year of entitlement, in writing, or such right shall be forever barred. 
(Ord. No. O-99-49, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 90-6. - Additional requirements; definitions. 
(a)  Any land dedicated to the city under this section must be suitable for park and recreation uses. The following characteristics of a proposed area are generally unsuitable: 
(1)  Any area primarily located in the 100-year floodplain. 
(2)  Any areas of unusual topography, or slope, which renders same unusable for organized recreational activities. 
a.  Drainage areas may be accepted as part of a park if the channel is constructed in accordance with city engineering standards, and if no significant area of the park is cut off from access by such channel. 
b.  Each park must have ready access to a public street or roadway. 
(b)  For the purpose of this article, the following terms are defined as noted: 
(1)  City park. Any park which is owned, maintained or operated by the City of Pharr, Texas. 
(2)  Neighborhood park. Park of three to 15 acres, suitable for intense recreational activities such as field games, court games, playground apparatus, picnicking, etc., generally serving a population within a one-quarter to one-half mile radius of the park. 
(3)  Community park. Park of 15 acres or more, suitable for diverse activities, such as intense recreational activities, athletic complexes, swimming pools, etc., generally serving a population within a one-half to three mile radius of the park, or several neighborhoods. 
(4)  Residential dwelling unit. Any unit designed as a stand-alone dwelling, consisting of sleeping, bathing and cooking facilities. 
(5)  Commercial space. Any space designed to hold a separate commercial enterprise. 
(Ord. No. O-99-49, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Sec. 90-7. - Administrative procedures. 
(a)  The planning department shall be responsible for processing and collecting all fees. 
(b)  Before receiving a building permit or final plat approval, the land owner shall submit, on a form provided by the city, the total number of proposed dwelling units and/or commercial acreage in the development. Upon receipt of the form, the required fee or required land dedication shall be calculated based on the provisions of section 90-3(a) through (d), as appropriate. 
(c)  If money, in lieu of land, is to be paid, all payments must be paid and receipted prior to plat approval. 
(d)  If land is to be dedicated, such land shall be indicated on the final plat subject to approval by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. O-99-49, § 1, 10-5-99) 
Secs. 90-8-90-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMITTEE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 90-31. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created a parks and recreation committee. 
(Code 1976, § 23-16; Ord. No. O-2017-22, 6-5-17; Ord. No. O-2017-36, 9-5-17) 
Sec. 90-32. - Duration of terms of office; vacancy; reappointment. 
    The city board of commissioners shall appoint nine members to the city of parks and recreation committee. Said advisory committee terms shall be five members to serve a three-year term and four members to serve a two-year term. Appointments to the advisory committee shall be at the expiration of their individual term or as needed, in the event of a vacancy. The individual terms will automatically expire at 5:00 p.m. on the anniversary date of their appointed term. The city commission shall take action to reappoint the member or fill the vacancy at the next scheduled regular meeting following the expiration of the member's term. The commission may also reappoint the member at a regular scheduled or special called meeting within 30 days of the individual member's term expiration. Regardless of the date of appointment any said term will commence on the anniversary date set above. 
(Code 1976, § 23-17; Ord. No. O-2017-22, 6-5-17; Ord. No. O-2017-36, 9-5-17) 
Sec. 90-33. - Quorum. 
(a)  Five of the regular voting members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business; and 
(b)  A majority of the members of the parks and recreation committee shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1976, § 23-18; Ord. No. O-2017-22, 6-5-17; Ord. No. O-2017-36, 9-5-17) 
Sec. 90-34. - Rules of procedure. 
    The parks and recreation committee shall adopt its own rules of procedure and keep a record of its proceedings. 
(Code 1976, § 23-19) 
Sec. 90-35. - Duties. 
    The parks and recreation committee shall have the power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Act in an advisory capacity in all matters pertaining to public parks and recreation. 
(2)  Assist in the planning of parks and recreation programs, promote and stimulate public interest therein, and to that end, solicit to the fullest possible extent the cooperation of the school authorities and other public and private agencies. 
(3)  Act on special requests for special use of any of the public parks or playground facilities. 
(4)  Make rules of conduct to govern activities on all city parks and playgrounds. 
(5)  In its discretion, require membership in the parks and recreation department, set standards therefor, and require compliance with rules and regulations as a condition for maintaining such membership. 
(6)  Fix hours during which all park and recreation facilities shall be open for public use, and post notice thereof at the entrance of each facility. 
(Code 1976, § 23-20) 
Sec. 90-36. - Fiscal restraint. 
    The parks and recreation committee shall not be authorized to create any debts or incur any liability on behalf of the city unless first authorized to do so by the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 23-21) 
Secs. 90-37-90-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GOLF CLUB ADVISORY BOARD 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-41. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article: 
    Golf club shall mean the Tierra del Sol Golf Club and the entire premises thereof, including, but not limited to, the clubhouse, restaurant, pro shop, cart shed and golf club itself, and all other parts or portions thereof. 
    City shall mean the City of Pharr, Hidalgo County, Texas. 
    Lessee shall mean any person or organization of whatever nature that uses the golf course premises, facilities or equipment. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-42. - Manager. 
    The administrator in charge of the golf course shall be the golf club manager, who shall be employed and discharged by the city manager, subject to the approval of the city commission. The terms, conditions, and duties of said golf club manager's employment shall be prescribed by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-43. - Fees for use of facilities; equipment. 
    The golf club manager is hereby authorized to collect fees for the use of Tierra del Sol Golf Club facilities and equipment, such fees to be set from time to time upon the recommendation of the Tierra Del Sol Golf Club Advisory Board by minute order of the city commission. All fees charged for the use of facilities or equipment hereunder shall be due and payable to the City of Pharr, Hidalgo County, Texas. The free or reduced rate for the use of all facilities and equipment of the Tierra del Sol Golf Club is hereby prohibited to any individual, or group or to any employee or officer of the city except for marketing or public relation purposes as approved by the golf club manager upon consultation with the city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99; Ord. No. O-2002-35, § 2, 8-6-02) 
Sec. 90-44. - Sale of merchandise; concessions. 
(a)  Only the City of Pharr and its assigns may sell merchandise at the Tierra del Sol Golf Club. The use of any portion of the golf club by any individual, group, firm, or corporation other than the City of Pharr, Texas for the purpose of selling merchandise is hereby prohibited. Sale of merchandise by tax-exempt/nonprofit charitable organizations or civic groups is hereby excepted from such prohibition and shall be permitted upon the approval of the golf club manager. 
(b)  Only the City of Pharr and its assigns shall have the right to operate concessions for the sale of food, drinks (including alcoholic beverages), programs, novelties, souvenirs, etc. Sale of concessions by tax-exempt charitable organizations and civic groups are hereby exempted from such prohibition and shall be permitted upon the approval of the golf club manager. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-45. - Establishment of insurance requirements. 
    The city manager shall establish all insurance requirements pertaining to the use of the golf club and equipment. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-46. - City held harmless. 
    All lessees of the golf club shall hold the city harmless from any and all liabilities for any claim or claims resulting from their rental or use of such premises and shall indemnify the city in case of any claims resulting from their activities or occurring during their occupation of the premises. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
DIVISION 2. - ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 90-47. - Definitions. 
(a)  Whenever used in this article, the term "advisory board" shall mean "Tierra del Sol Golf Club Advisory Board" created by section 90-48. 
(b)  The term "association" shall mean an organized group of members who belong to the Tierra del Sol Golf Club. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-48. - Created; official name. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established the City of Pharr Tierra del Sol Golf Club Advisory Board. Such board shall be officially designated as the "Tierra del Sol Golf Club Advisory Board." 
(b)  The advisory board shall be composed of nine members whose appointment and terms of service, length and duration of terms, attendance requirements, and appointment procedures shall be prescribed by ordinance or state law. Each city commission member shall appoint one person to the advisory board. The presidents of each of the two golf associations shall recommend to the city commission one appointment to the advisory board. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-49. - Terms of members. 
(a)  Terms of officers. The chairman shall serve one year with no limit on consecutive terms. He shall be elected by a majority vote at the first meeting of each fiscal year. 
(b)  The city board of commissioners and the mayor shall appoint eight members to the City of Pharr Tierra Del Sol Golf Club Advisory Board and the mayor shall appoint one chairman. Said advisory board terms shall be four members to serve a three-year term and five members to serve a two-year term. Appointments to the advisory board shall be at the expiration of their individual term or as needed, in the event of a vacancy. The individual terms will automatically expire at 5:00 p.m. on the anniversary date of their appointed term. The city commission shall take action to reappoint the member or fill the vacancy at the next scheduled regular meeting following the expiration of the member's term. The commission may also reappoint the member at a regular scheduled or special called meeting within 30 days of the individual member's term expiration. Regardless of the date of appointment any said term will commence on the anniversary date set above. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99; Ord. No. O-99-35, 7-20-99; Ord. No. O-2003-24, Art. II, § 9, 6-3-03; O-2006-39, Art. II, § 9, 7-18-06; Ord. No. O-2015-51, 11-3-15; Ord. No. O-2017-01, § A, 1-16-17) 
Sec. 90-50. - Ex officio members. 
    The city commission may designate the mayor and any other officer or commissioner of the city as it sees fit to serve as an ex officio member of the advisory board, without voting privilege, who shall act in an advisory capacity only. The golf club manager shall also be an ex officio member of the advisory board, without voting privilege. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-51. - Members to receive no compensation. 
    No salary or compensation shall be paid to the members of the advisory board for their services. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-52. - Secretary. 
    The manager of the Tierra del Sol Golf Club shall be secretary of the advisory board and shall keep permanent records of all the proceedings of the board, which proceedings and records shall be available to the city commission and a copy of such proceedings shall be delivered to the city commission after such proceedings occur. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-53. - Quorum. 
(a)  Five of the regular voting members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(b)  Absences. Any board member with three or more unexcused absences in a fiscal year may be dismissed by a majority vote. Vacancies to be filled in the same manner board member was appointed. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99; Ord. No. O-2003-24, Art. II, § 13, 6-3-03; O-2006-39, Art. II, § 13, 7-18-06; Ord. No. O-2015-51, 11-3-15; Ord. No. O-2017-01, § A, 1-16-17) 
Sec. 90-54. - Time and place of regular meetings. 
    The advisory board shall meet once a month in regular session, the time and place to be set by the advisory board, to consider all matters pertaining to the business, operation and use to be made of the City of Tierra del Sol Golf Club and all facilities and equipment pertaining thereto. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-55. - Call of special meetings. 
    The golf club manager or chairman of the advisory board shall have the right to call such special meetings of the advisory board as may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-56. - General duties. 
    The advisory board shall work in close cooperation with the golf club manager and shall keep informed as to all aspects of the City of Pharr Tierra del Sol Golf Club, including, but not limited to, management, regulations, rules, purposes, maintenance, policies and ordinances established by the city commission, and it shall stimulate use of the golf club facilities and equipment. It shall, from time to time, transmit information, report, suggestions, recommendations, and advice to the city commission. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-57. - Recommendations to city commission. 
    Any and all recommendations made by the advisory board to the city commission shall be by a majority of a quorum. A minority of the advisory board members shall have a right to make a minority recommendation in writing to the city commission. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-58. - Subcommittees. 
    The advisory board is authorized to establish subcommittees for specific operational functions with a chairman for each subcommittee. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-59. - Submission of annual operational program and budget. 
    The proposed operational budget for the golf club for each year shall be submitted by the general manager to the city manager for his approval. The advisory board shall also submit to the director of finance, at a time requested by him, its annual budget, for examination and final approval by the city commission in like manner as other city departmental budgets. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-60. - Defacing golf club property. 
    Every person who shall intentionally cut, mutilate, deface, defoliate, or otherwise destroy or cause injury, in whole or in part, to any part or portion of the golf course premises, facilities, or equipment, or who shall suffer any such injury to be inflicted while equipment of whatever nature is in his custody, or who shall willfully or want only mark or deface or in any injure the golf course facilities or any part thereof, or any fixtures therein or appertaining thereto, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be fined not less than $1.00 nor more than $200.00. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-61. - Violation and penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate, participate or acquiesce in the violation of any of the provisions of this article or who shall fail to comply therewith or with any requirements thereof, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be fined not more than $200.00 nor less than $1.00; each day such violations shall be permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Sec. 90-62. - Other remedies. 
(a)  The penalty provided in section 90-60 and section 90-61 above should not be construed as exclusive, and the City of Pharr hereby provides that any other remedy available to it in the enforcement of this article, in law or in equity, is not intended to be, and is not, foreclosed by the provision of such penalty. 
(b)  The penalties prescribed in section 90-61 of this article shall not preclude a civil action for monetary damages or other relief brought by the City of Pharr against a person violating said section or against the parent, guardian, managing conservator, possessory conservator, or other person having the duty of control or reasonable discipline of a child under Texas Family Code Annotated, sections 33.01 through 33.03 (1975), as amended, where such child has violated said sections of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-99-23, § 1, 6-29-99) 
Chapter 94 - PERSONNEL[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Adoption of updated personnel policy and procedures manual. 
    The board of commissioners hereby adopts the new City of Pharr Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual, which is on file with the city and is incorporated by reference for all purposes. 
(Ord. No. O-92-30, § 1, 8-4-92; Ord. No. O-95-43, § 1, 12-19-95; Ord. No. O-2007-29, § 1, 4-17-07; Ord. No. O-2008-19, § 1, 5-6-08; Ord. No. O-2008-24, § 2, 5-22-08; Ord.
