ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 126-1. - State law adopted. 
    The provisions of the Rules of the Road (V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 541 et seq.), as amended, are hereby adopted by the city by reference as if fully set forth in this section. 
(Code 1976, § 33-1) 
Sec. 126-1.1. - Federal law adopted; penalty. 
(a)  The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations and the Federal Hazardous Materials Regulations, as adopted by the Texas Department of Public Safety, and Title 37, Texas Administration Code Chapter 3, Traffic Law Enforcement parts 359 and 362 are hereby adopted by the city. 
(b)  Each violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. Each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. O-97-01, §§ 1, 2, 1-7-97; Ord. No. O-98-18A, §§ 1, 2, 4-7-98; Ord. No. O-98-20, §§ 1, 2, 4-7-98) 
Sec. 126-2. - Enforcement generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the city police department to enforce the provisions of this chapter, all other street and traffic laws of the city and all the state traffic laws applicable to traffic in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 33-2) 
Sec. 126-3. - Payment of fine at traffic violations bureau. 
(a)  Any person who has received any notice to appear in answer to a traffic charge under this chapter may, within the time specified in the notice, appear at the traffic violations bureau and answer the charge set forth in such notice by paying a prescribed fine, and in writing pleading guilty to the charge, waiving a hearing in court and giving power of attorney to the person in charge of the bureau to make such a plea and pay such fine in court. 
(b)  Any person who has been guilty of two or more moving traffic violations, except as otherwise provided, within the preceding 12 months shall not be permitted to pay a fine at the traffic violations bureau and must make statutory bail for appearance in court. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply for juveniles. 
(Code 1976, § 33-3) 
Sec. 126-4. - Disposition of fines and forfeitures. 
    All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail of any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be paid into the city treasury and deposited in the general fund. 
(Code 1976, § 33-4) 
Sec. 126-5. - Use of rollerskates, toy vehicles and similar devices restricted. 
    No person upon rollerskates or riding in or by means of any coaster, skateboard, toy vehicle, whether motorized or not, or other similar device shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk. When so crossing, such person shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. This provision shall not apply upon any street while set aside as a play street. 
(Code 1976, § 33-5) 
Sec. 126-6. - Removing or damaging traffic barriers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a city employee, to remove or damage any barriers, either closing a street or for the purpose of warning traffic of an obstruction in the street, erected under the direction of the chief of police or street superintendent. 
(Code 1976, § 33-6) 
Secs. 126-7-126-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 126-31. - Authority of police officers to direct traffic. 
    Officers of the police department, or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police, are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or signal in conformance with traffic laws. In the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. 
(Code 1976, § 33-18) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate traffic by means of police officers, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(1). 
Sec. 126-32. - Authority of officers of fire department to direct traffic. 
    Members of the city fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity when requested by a police officer. 
(Code 1976, § 33-19) 
Sec. 126-33. - Temporary traffic control officers. 
    Under unusual conditions, the chief of police may appoint temporary traffic control officers until such unusual conditions cease to exist. These temporary officers shall have the same authority as regular officers of the police department unless they are specifically limited by the chief of police. 
(Code 1976, § 33-20) 
Secs. 126-34-126-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC SAFETY COORDINATOR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2016-38, § 1, adopted Oct. 17, 2016, repealed the former div. 2., §§ 126-56-126-58, and enacted a new div. 2 as set out herein. The former div. 2 pertained to a police-controlled traffic division and derived from the Code of 1976, §§ 33-27-33-29. 

Sec. 126-56. - Established. 
    The traffic safety coordinator position is hereby established and shall be appointed by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-38, § 1, 10-17-16) 
Sec. 126-57. - Duties of the traffic safety coordinator. 
    It shall be the duty of the traffic safety coordinator to: 
(1)  Conduct, or cause to conduct, analysis of traffic accidents and to devise remedial measures. 
(2)  Conduct, or cause to conduct, engineering investigations of traffic conditions and to cooperate with city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions. 
(3)  Place and maintain, or cause to be placed and maintained, traffic control signs, signals and devices when and as required to make effective the provisions of this chapter. 
(4)  Supervise, or cause to be supervised, the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices. 
(5)  Designate and maintain, or cause to be maintained, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalk at any intersection where, in his or her opinion, there is particular danger to pedestrian crossing the roadway, and at such other places he or she may deem necessary. 
(6)  Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he or she may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(7)  Mark lanes for traffic on street pavement as such places as he or she may deem advisable consistent with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city and the laws of the state. 
(8)  Designate streets as a stop intersection and designate the streets upon which vehicles shall stop before entering such intersections. 
(9)  Establish "no parking" or "limited parking" zones in areas not reserved for board of commissioners' consideration and where an established need exists based on vehicular and pedestrian safety. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-38, § 1, 10-17-16) 
Sec. 126-58. - Authority of the traffic safety coordinator to make traffic regulations. 
    Using the procedures and criteria prescribed in the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices and in conformance with state and federal law and city ordinances, the traffic safety coordinator is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city and to make temporary regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. No such temporary regulation shall remain in effect for more than 120 days. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-38, § 1, 10-17-16) 
Sec. 126-59. - Traffic regulations reserved for the board of commissioners. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of any other section of this chapter or any other section of this chapter or any other city ordinance, the board of commissioners shall approve by ordinance any regulations, except of a temporary or emergency type, which involve the following: 
(1)  Designation of one-way streets and alleys. 
(2)  Authorization of traffic signals. 
(3)  Establishment of speed limits on city owned streets. 
(4)  Prohibition of parking on city streets or alleys which exceeds two continuous city blocks (or approximately 660 linear feet) on one side of a street or one city block (approximately 330 linear feet)on both sides of the street. 
(5)  Designation of parking meter zones. 
(6)  Time limits and amount of deposit in metered zones. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-38, § 1, 10-17-16) 
Secs. 126-60-126-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRAFFIC SAFETY COMMITTEE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 126-81. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a traffic safety committee in and for the city. 
(Code 1976, § 33-36) 
Sec. 126-82. - Composition. 
    The traffic safety committee shall be composed of not more than 11 members. 
(Code 1976, § 33-37) 
Sec. 126-83. - Qualifications. 
    The members of the traffic safety committee shall be resident citizens of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 33-38) 
Sec. 126-84. - Appointment. 
    The members of the traffic safety committee shall be appointed by the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 33-39) 
Sec. 126-85. - Terms. 
    The members of the traffic safety committee shall serve terms concurrently with the terms of the members of the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 33-40) 
Sec. 126-86. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies occurring in the membership of the traffic safety committee shall be filled for the unexpired terms at the will of the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 33-41) 
Sec. 126-87. - Quorum. 
    Six members of the traffic safety committee shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1976, § 33-42) 
Sec. 126-88. - Duties generally. 
    The traffic safety committee shall be an advisory body. It may establish its own rules and regulations for its meetings and proceedings. It shall make a study of traffic conditions in the city and make recommendations to the city commission designed to reduce and eliminate traffic accidents, injuries and deaths resulting therefrom, and the best methods which, in its judgment, should be adopted to accomplish such result. It is desired that the traffic safety committee undertake a campaign of education of the general public as to traffic problems and its cooperation in reducing and eliminating traffic accidents, injuries and deaths. It shall seek the cooperation and coordination of any and all other civic groups created and working for the same common purpose of improving traffic conditions in the city. It shall make reports to the city commission of its work from time to time. 
(Code 1976, § 33-43) 
Sec. 126-89. - Fiscal restraint. 
    The traffic safety committee shall not be authorized to create any debts or incur any liability on behalf of the city unless first authorized to do so by the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 33-44) 
Secs. 126-90-126-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS AND DEVICES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate traffic by means of traffic control devices, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(1). 

Sec. 126-111. - Conformity with manual and specifications of state highway department; uniformity. 
    All traffic control signs, signals and devices shall conform to the manual and specifications approved by the state highway department. All signs and signals required under this chapter for a particular purpose shall, so far as practicable, be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of state law or this chapter shall be official traffic control devices. 
(Code 1976, § 33-74) 
Sec. 126-112. - Powers and duties of traffic director relative to devices. 
    The traffic director shall place and maintain traffic control signs, signals, and devices when and as required under this chapter to make effective the provisions of this chapter, and may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate traffic under this chapter or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic. It shall be the duty of the traffic director to supervise the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices, and he may test traffic control devices under actual conditions of traffic. 
(Code 1976, § 33-77) 
Sec. 126-113. - Designation of crosswalks and safety zones and marking traffic lanes. 
    The traffic director is hereby authorized to: 
(1)  Designate and maintain by appropriate devices, marks, or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at any intersection where, in his opinion, there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he may deem necessary. 
(2)  Establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(3)  Mark lanes for traffic on street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city. 
(Code 1976, § 33-78) 
Sec. 126-114. - Obedience to devices. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device applicable thereto placed in accordance with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of this city, unless otherwise directed by a police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle. 
(Code 1976, § 33-79) 
Sec. 126-115. - Necessity of signs. 
    No provision of this chapter for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if, at the time and place of the alleged violation, an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective even though no signs are erected or in place. 
(Code 1976, § 33-80) 
Sec. 126-116. - Installation of traffic lights. 
    The traffic director from time to time shall designate intersections and other places at which traffic shall be controlled by electric traffic control signals or lights and shall cause such signals or lights to be installed and maintained at such intersections or places. 
(Code 1976, § 33-81) 
Sec. 126-117. - Traffic control signals generally. 
(a)  A traffic control signal displaying different colored lights or colored lighted arrows successively or in combination may display only green, yellow, or red and applies to operators of vehicles as provided by this section. 
(b)  An operator of a vehicle facing a circular green signal may proceed straight or turn right or left unless a sign prohibits the turn. The operator shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully in the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk when the signal is exhibited. 
(c)  An operator of a vehicle facing a green arrow signal, displayed alone or with another signal, may cautiously enter the intersection to move in the direction permitted by the arrow or other indication shown simultaneously. The operator shall yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian lawfully in an adjacent crosswalk and other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
(d)  An operator of a vehicle facing only a steady red signal shall stop at a clearly marked stop line. In the absence of a stop line, the operator shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection. A vehicle that is not turning shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown. After stopping, standing until the intersection may be entered safely, and yielding the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully in an adjacent crosswalk and other traffic lawfully using the intersection, the operator may: 
(1)  Turn right; or 
(2)  Turn left, if the intersecting streets are both one-way streets and a left turn is permissible. 
(e)  An operator of a vehicle facing a steady yellow signal is warned by that signal that: 
(1)  Movement authorized by a green signal is being terminated; and 
(2)  A red signal is about to be given. 
(f)  The city may prohibit within the city's jurisdiction a turn by an operator of a vehicle facing a steady red signal by posting notice at the intersection that the turn is prohibited. 
(g)  This section applies to an official traffic control signal placed and maintained at a place other than an intersection, except for a provision that by its nature cannot apply. A required stop shall be made at a sign or marking on the pavement indicating where the stop shall be made. In the absence of such a sign or marking, the stop shall be made at the signal. 
(h)  The obligations imposed by this section apply to an operator of a streetcar in the same manner as they apply to the operator of a vehicle. 
(Code 1976, § 33-82) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.007. 
Sec. 126-118. - Flashing signals. 
(a)  The operator of a vehicle facing a flashing red signal shall stop at a clearly marked stop line. In the absence of a stop line, the operator shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection. In the absence of a crosswalk, the operator shall stop at the place nearest the intersecting roadway where the operator has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. The right to proceed is subject to the rules applicable after stopping at a stop sign. 
(b)  The operator of a vehicle facing a flashing yellow signal may proceed through an intersection or past the signal only with caution. 
(c)  This section does not apply at a railroad crossing. 
(Code 1976, § 33-83) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.008. 
Sec. 126-119. - Pedestrian control signals. 
(a)  A pedestrian control signal displaying "Walk," "Don't Walk," or "Wait" applies to a pedestrian as provided by this section. 
(b)  A pedestrian facing a "Walk" signal may proceed across a roadway in the direction of the signal, and the operator of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way to the pedestrian. 
(c)  A pedestrian may not start to cross a roadway in the direction of a "Don't Walk" signal or a "Wait" signal. A pedestrian who has partially crossed while the "Walk" signal is displayed shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety island while the "Don't Walk" signal or "Wait" signal is displayed. 
(Code 1976, § 33-84) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 552.002. 
Sec. 126-120. - Ratification of existing devices. 
    All traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings placed or erected prior to the adoption of this Code and in use for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic are hereby affirmed, ratified and declared to be official traffic control devices, provided such traffic control devices are not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter or state law. 
(Code 1976, § 33-85) 
Sec. 126-121. - Unauthorized signs, signals, markings. 
(a)  No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any road, street or highway any unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic control device or any railroad signal or sign; and no person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit upon any highway or street any traffic signal or sign bearing thereon any commercial advertising. This shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection, upon private property adjacent to streets or highways, of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official traffic signals. 
(b)  A sign, signal, light, or marking prohibited under this section is a public nuisance. The city may remove such sign, signal, light, or marking without notice. 
(Code 1976, § 33-86) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.006. 
Sec. 126-122. - Interference with traffic control device or railroad sign or signal. 
    A person may not, without lawful authority, alter, injure, knock down, or remove or attempt to alter, injure, knock down, or remove: 
(1)  An official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal; 
(2)  An inscription, shield, or insignia on an official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal; or 
(3)  Another part of an official traffic control device or railroad sign or signal. 
(Code 1976, § 33-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.005. 
Secs. 126-123-126-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES GENERALLY 

Sec. 126-140. - Definitions. 
    Whenever any words and phrases used in this chapter are not defined in this section, but are defined in the state laws regulating the operation of vehicles, any such definition therein shall be deemed to apply to such words and phrases used in this chapter. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Electronic message means a self-contained piece of digital communication that is designed or intended to be transmitted to or from a wireless communication device, other than a voice message. An electronic message includes, but is not limited to, a text-based communication, a nonverbal command or request to access or receive information from an internet site, electronic mail, a text message, an instant message or such other data that uses a commonly recognized electronic communications protocol. 
    Operate or operating means to drive or be in physical control of a motor vehicle that is in motion. 
    Operator means a person who drives or has physical control of a motor vehicle. 
    Wireless communication device has the meaning assigned in V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.425 ("use of wireless communication device; offense"). 
(Ord. No. O-2012-32, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 126-141. - Speed limits on specific streets. 
    The city commission may alter the maximum speed limits established by state law on any street or portion thereof within the city in accordance with the provisions of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 169. Whenever signs are posted giving notice of the maximum legal speed limit so established for a particular street or portion thereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle at a rate of speed in excess of such limit. 
(Code 1976, § 33-57) 
State Law reference- Speed of vehicles and authority of cities to alter prima facie speed limits established by state law, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.351 et seq. 
Sec. 126-142. - U-turns restricted. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any street in a business district or at any intersection controlled by traffic lights and shall not upon any other street or intersection so turn a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1976, § 33-62) 
Sec. 126-143. - Driving on sidewalks. 
    Any driver of any vehicle who shall drive such vehicle upon or across any sidewalk or sidewalk area of any street within the city, except on a driveway, public or private, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1976, § 33-58) 
Sec. 126-144. - Corner cutting. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle over any sidewalk area and through any driveway, parking lot or any business entrance at any intersection in making either a right or left turn, except for the purpose of coming to a complete stop to obtain or render some service or make a sale or purchase. It is the intention of this section to prohibit corner cutting by driving a vehicle from one street into another across any sidewalk and/or driveway and/or through any driveway. 
(Code 1976, § 33-60) 
Sec. 126-145. - Clinging to moving vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person traveling upon any motorcycle, coaster, sled, roller skates or any toy vehicle to cling to or attach himself or his vehicle to any moving vehicle upon any roadway. 
(Code 1976, § 33-59) 
Sec. 126-146. - Displaying advertising. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate any vehicle on any street within the corporate limits of the city for the primary purpose of displaying advertising. 
(Code 1976, § 33-61) 
Sec. 126-147. - Removing vehicle from scene of accident. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver or any other person to remove any vehicle involved in an accident from the scene of the accident until authorized to do so by a police officer of the police department of this city; provided, however, that this section shall not apply if there exists or arises a duty on the part of such driver or other person in control of such vehicle to use the vehicle in carrying any person injured in such accident to a physician or surgeon for medical or surgical treatment or to notify the police department of the accident. 
(Code 1976, § 33-45) 
Sec. 126-148. - Use of a wireless communication device; offense. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an operator of a motor vehicle to use a wireless communication device to view, send or compose an electronic message or manually engage other application software while operating a motor vehicle upon any roadway in the city, including when stopped, except as provided in subsection (b)(2). 
(b)  It is an exception to the prohibition in subsection (a) if: 
(1)  An operator of a motor vehicle uses a wireless communication device to strictly engage in a telephone conversation or to listen to a voicemail message, including dialing or deactivating a phone call; 
(2)  An operator of a motor vehicle uses a wireless communication device while stopped or standing at a position parallel to and as close as possible to the right hand edge or curb or a roadway where parking, standing or stopping in a nonemergency situation is not otherwise prohibited; or 
(3)  An operator of a motor vehicle uses a wireless communication device solely in a voice-activated or other hands-free mode. 
(c)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution of conduct prohibited in subsection (a) if: 
(1)  An operator of an authorized government vehicle uses a wireless communication device to respond to an emergency while acting in an official capacity while operating an authorized government vehicle; 
(2)  An operator of a motor vehicle uses a wireless communication device to: 
i.  Operate only a global positioning or navigation system; 
ii.  Obtain emergency assistance by contacting an emergency response service, including a rescue, emergency medical, or hazardous material response service; a hospital; a fire department; a law enforcement agency; a medical doctor's office; or an individual to administer first aid treatment; 
iii.  Obtain emergency assistance to prevent a crime about to be committed; 
iv.  Report a traffic accident or serious traffic hazard; or 
v.  Communicate with the reasonable belief that a person's life, safety or property is in immediate danger. 
(d)  Conflicting regulations. To the extent that any clause, phrase, provision, sentence or part of this section conflicts with V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.424, regarding the use of wireless communications devices while operating a motor vehicle by minors, or V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.425, regarding the use of wireless communication devices in school crossing zones, this section does not apply. 
(Ord. No. O-2012-32, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 126-149. - Left turns restricted. 
(a)  Administrative authority. It shall be the duty of the city police department to enforce the provisions of this section. It shall also be the duty of the public works director or his designee to place and maintain any and all traffic control signs, signals and devices within city right-of-way (ROW) when and as required under this section. (V.T.C.A. Transportation Code 542.202(a)(1)). 
(b)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to protect the health, safety and general welfare of all children attending any schools within the city limits and its ETJ. The section will prohibit left turns, especially within major thoroughfares, into and from school property during the school year from Monday through Friday from hours of 7:30 am to 8:30 a.m. and from 2:30 p.m. to 4:30 p.m. or as deemed necessary within any school zone inside the corporate city limits. This section will only be enforced during the school year and within school zones. 
(Ord. No. O-2016-30, §§ 2, 3, 8-15-16) 
Secs. 126-150-126-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate the stopping, standing and parking of vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(2). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 126-156. - Stop when traffic obstructed. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1976, § 33-92) 
Sec. 126-157. - Presumption of owner's responsibility for parking violations. 
    In any prosecution charging a violation of any ordinance or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such ordinance or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(Code 1976, § 33-93) 
Sec. 126-158. - Parking for more than 24 hours on public ways prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle to allow, cause or permit such vehicle to remain standing or parked on any street, alley, avenue or public way within the city for more than 24 hours continuously. 
(Code 1976, § 33-94) 
Sec. 126-159. - Angle parking. 
    Vehicles may be parked at any angle, not to exceed 45 degrees, to the curb or edge of the roadway at those places and angles where signs or markings clearly indicate that such parking is permissible, provided that no part or contents of such vehicle shall protrude into or cause a hazard with other vehicles or pedestrians in the nearest adjacent traffic lane, sidewalk or crosswalk. In no case shall this exceed 17 feet from the curb in a perpendicular direction where 30-degree angle parking is permitted or 19 feet from the curb in a perpendicular direction where 45-degree angle parking is permitted. 
(Code 1976, § 33-95) 
State Law reference- Authority to permit angle parking, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.303(c). 
Sec. 126-160. - Parking for bridge traffic. 
(a)  Designation of zone for restricted parking. 
(1)  There is hereby granted the authority to the city through its personnel and city attorney to designate at its discretion restricted commercial parking in an area ancillary or adjacent to the Pharr-Reynosa International Toll Bridge. 
(2)  The area designated may take into account areas approved by local, state, and federal agencies. The city's governing is also authorized to execute interlocal agreements as may be necessary to further the interests, execution, and enforcement of the provisions contained herein. 
(b)  Definition(s); designated use of parking areas within restricted zone. 
    Commercial transport, for purposes of this section, shall be any person, business, corporation, or other entity that is at the time engaging in commerce within the restricted parking zone created that meets the qualifications for overweight transport. 
    The use of parking spaces within the restricted area herein shall be an "Overweight Only" zone. The "Overweight Only" zone shall be used by any person, business, corporation, or other entity for the parking of any motor vehicle or other method of transportation when the operator engages in commerce within the restricted parking zone created herein that meets or exceeds allowable weight limits. 
(c)  Authority to proceed under this section; prohibited parking. 
(1)  This section is enacted pursuant to Texas Local Government Code Chapter 601, Texas Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(2), and the independent legislative authority of the City of Pharr to publicly regulate parking within its lawful boundaries and jurisdiction. 
(2)  No person, business, corporation, or other entity shall use the public parking for any use other than that declared herein. The area now known as the "Overweight Only" zone shall subject any violator to any and all penalties as allowed by law and ordinance including but not limited to fines, tow-away, and impoundment. 
(d)  Businesses, agents and employees. Any and all the owners, agents or employees of any commercial transport are required to meet any and all requirements, screening, and pre-qualifications as may be required by local, state, or federal regulations and laws. 
(e)  Notice to public. Parking signs on or near the restricted parking zone may be posted along said route to be effective at all times during the effective period of this section. Failure to erect a sign shall not affect the designation of the restricted area or zone. 
(f)  Penalties. All penalties for violators shall be subject to the provisions contained in "Traffic and Vehicles" Pharr Code of Ordinances, sections 126-156-126-188. Violators shall also be subject to Texas Local Government Code § 431.001, Texas Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(2), Texas Penal Code, and any other applicable laws. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. 
(Ord. No. O-2011-57, §§ 1-6, 10-18-11) 
Secs. 126-161-126-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESTRICTED, PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN STREETS AND PLACES 

Sec. 126-181. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this division prohibiting the standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times specified in this division or as indicated on official signs, except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(Code 1976, § 33-102) 
Sec. 126-182. - Regulations not exclusive. 
    The provisions of this division imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1976, § 33-103) 
Sec. 126-183. - Parking prohibited on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle at any time upon any of the streets described by ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 33-104) 
Sec. 126-184. - Parking restricted on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle between the hours specified by ordinance on any day, except Sundays and public holidays, within the district or upon any of the streets described by ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 33-105) 
Sec. 126-185. - Signs required. 
    Whenever any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated streets by this division or any ordinance of the city, it shall be the duty of the city traffic safety coordinator to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof; and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Code 1976, § 33-106) 
Sec. 126-186. - Stopping, standing, or parking prohibited in certain places. 
(a)  An operator may not stop, stand, or park a vehicle: 
(1)  On the roadway side of a vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street; 
(2)  On a sidewalk; 
(3)  In an intersection; 
(4)  On a crosswalk; 
(5)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of a place on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the city commission designates a different length by signs or markings; 
(6)  Alongside or opposite a street excavation or obstruction if stopping, standing, or parking the vehicle would obstruct traffic; 
(7)  On a bridge or other elevated structure on a highway or in a highway tunnel; 
(8)  On a railroad track; 
(9)  Where an official sign prohibits stopping; or 
(10)  As defined by the Standard Fire Prevention Code, chapter 6, section 602.6, access to building by fire apparatus: In a fire lane established around or adjacent to any building where such area has prominently displayed thereon a sign on the pavement, a stand, or other object adjacent thereto, the words, "Fire Lane-Parking Prohibited," and the fire lane is clearly delineated by proper markings. No person shall be guilty of a violation of this subsection unless the fire lane is clearly marked and identified. The provisions of this subsection are hereby extended to all parking areas as defined in the comprehensive zoning regulation for the city, Ordinance No. 82-13, article IV, minimum off-street parking and loading requirements. 
(b)  An operator may not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger, stand or park an occupied or unoccupied vehicle: 
(1)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(2)  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant; 
(3)  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; 
(4)  Within 30 feet on the approach to a flashing signal, stop sign, yield sign, or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway; 
(5)  Within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to a fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to a fire station within 75 feet of the entrance, if the entrance is properly marked with a sign; or 
(6)  Where an official sign prohibits standing. 
(c)  An operator may not, except temporarily to load or unload merchandise or passengers, park an occupied or unoccupied vehicle: 
(1)  Within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; or 
(2)  Where an official sign prohibits parking. 
(d)  A person may stop, stand, or park a bicycle on a sidewalk if the bicycle does not impede the normal and reasonable movement of pedestrian or other traffic on the sidewalk. 
(e)  A private vehicle operated by an elevator constructor responding to an elevator emergency shall be exempt from subsections (a)(1), (a)(5), (a)(6), (a)(9), (b) and (c) of this section. 
(f)  Subsections (a), (b), and (c) of this section do not apply if the avoidance of conflict with other traffic is necessary or if the operator is complying with the law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device. 
(Code 1976, § 33-107) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.302. 
Sec. 126-187. - Moving or impounding parked or standing vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle parked, stopped or standing in violation of any of the provisions of this article, such officer is hereby authorized to move such vehicle, or require the driver or other person in charge of the vehicle to move such vehicle. 
(b)  Any police officer is hereby authorized to remove a vehicle from a street or highway to the nearest garage or other place of safety, or to a garage designated or maintained by the city, under the circumstances enumerated in this subsection. 
(1)  When the vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct or causeway, or in any tube or tunnel, or in any fire lane, where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(2)  When the vehicle is illegally parked so as to block the entrance to any private driveway and it is impracticable to move such vehicle from in front of the driveway to another point on the street. 
(3)  When the vehicle is found upon a street and report has previously been made that such vehicle has been stolen or complaint has been filed and a warrant thereon issued charging that such vehicle has been stolen or converted. 
(4)  When any such officer has reasonable grounds to believe that the vehicle has been abandoned. 
(5)  When the vehicle is so disabled that its normal operation is impossible or impractical and the person in charge of the vehicle is incapacitated, by reason of physical injury or other reason, to such extent as to be unable to provide for its removal or custody, or is not in the immediate vicinity of the disabled vehicle. 
(6)  When the officer arrests the person driving or in control of the vehicle for an alleged offense and such officer is required to take the person arrested immediately before a magistrate. 
(7)  When, in the opinion of the police officer, the vehicle constitutes a hazard, or interferes with a normal function of a governmental agency, or by reason of any catastrophe, emergency or unusual circumstance, the safety of the vehicle is imperiled. 
(Code 1976, § 33-108) 
Sec. 126-188. - Maximum fees for impoundment of vehicles. 
(a)  The owner of any vehicle impounded under the provisions of this article shall pay, in addition to any other penalty which may be charged against him for any violation of this chapter, the cost of impounding, moving and storing the vehicle. 
(b)  The cost of impounding and storing a vehicle shall not exceed the following schedule: 
(1)  Impounding vehicle: Initial fee, not including towing charges but including first day's storage charge, not more than ..... $15.00 
(2)  Daily storage fees: 
a.  At a facility licensed by the state department of licensing and regulation, per day, not more than ..... 15.00 
b.  At a facility not licensed by the state department of licensing and regulation, per day, not more than ..... 3.00 
(Code 1976, § 33-109; Ord. No. O-91-09, § 1, 3-7-91; Ord. No. O-98-49, § 13(b), 8-18-98) 
Secs. 126-189-126-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKING FOR DISABLED PERSONS 

Sec. 126-211. - Designation of parking spaces for disabled persons; application to building code; definition. 
(a)  The owner or operator of a parking facility or of a building which has parking facilities may designate one or more parking spaces for the exclusive use of vehicles transporting disabled persons. The designation must consist of a permanently mounted sign posted adjacent to each parking space that depicts a profile view of a wheelchair with occupant in white on blue background with a statement that violators are subject to a fine of up to $200.00. Parking spaces designated for disabled persons must be at least 13 feet in width. 
(b)  Where the owner or operator of a parking facility or of a building which has parking facilities has made application for a building permit or where an application has been made for a building permit to build such a facility and the building code makes it mandatory that the owner or operator establish one or more parking spaces designated for disabled persons, such parking spaces must conform with the requirements set out in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  The traffic safety division of the police department shall mark parking spaces and set up signs which comply with this division upon request from any owner or operator of a parking facility or of a building which has a parking facility subject to subsection (b) of this section, which service shall be performed at the expense of the person or company requesting such service. 
(d)  The traffic safety division of the police department shall mark parking spaces and set up signs which comply with this division upon request of any owner or operator of a parking facility or of a parking facility which was in existence prior to the effective date of this division, which service shall be performed at the expense of the city, where and to the extent that the parking spaces set out and designated would be mandated under the present building code. 
(e)  For the purpose of this division, a disabled person is one who is certified by a licensed physician as having mobility problems that substantially impair the person's ability to ambulate or who is legally blind and who has obtained and properly displayed a specially designed license plate, symbol, tab, identification card or other device issued to disabled veterans or disabled persons by the state department of highways and public transportation. 
(Code 1976, § 33-113) 
Sec. 126-212. - Unlawful parking in space designated for disabled persons. 
    A person commits an offense if such person, acting as an operator of a motor vehicle that does not have displayed thereon a specially designed license plate, symbol, tab, identification card or other device issued to disabled veterans or disabled persons by the state department of highways and public transportation, stops, stands or parks such motor vehicle in a parking space designated for use by vehicles transporting disabled persons. 
(Code 1976, § 33-114) 
Sec. 126-213. - Removal of unauthorized vehicle. 
(a)  If the operator of a motor vehicle that does not display a specially designed license plate, symbol, tab, identification card or other device issued to disabled veterans or disabled persons by the state department of highways and public transportation stops, stands or parks the motor vehicle in a parking space designated for a vehicle transporting a disabled person, that vehicle is an unauthorized vehicle for the purposes of Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701g-2. 
(b)  An unauthorized vehicle, whether on public or private property, may be removed from a parking space designated for a vehicle transporting a disabled person, and stored, with removal and storage being at the expense of the owner or operator of the vehicle. 
(Code 1976, § 33-115) 
Secs. 126-214-126-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CUSTOMER-ONLY PARKING 

Sec. 126-221. - Designation of zone for restricted parking. 
    There is hereby created restricted public parking in an area within and between U.S. Business 83 Kelly Avenue on Cage Boulevard. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-12, § 1, 3-7-07) 
Sec. 126-222. - Definition(s); designated use of parking areas within restricted zone. 
    Customer, for purposes of this division, shall be any person, business, corporation, or other entity that is at the time engaging in commerce within the restricted parking zone created. 
    The use of public parking spaces within the restricted area herein shall be a customer-only zone. The customer-only zone shall be used by any person, business, corporation, or other entity for the parking of any motor vehicle or other method of transportation when the operator or passenger engages in commerce within the restricted parking zone created herein. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-12, § 2, 3-7-07) 
Sec. 126-223. - Authority to proceed under this division; prohibited parking. 
(a)  Pursuant to Texas Local Government Code § 431.001 and Texas Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(2), the City of Pharr is given the legal authority to regulate parking within its lawful boundaries and jurisdiction. 
(b)  No person, business, corporation, or other entity shall use the public parking for any use other than that declared herein. The area now known as the customer-only zone shall subject any violator to any and all penalties as allowed by law and ordinance including but not limited to fines, tow-away, and impoundment. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-12, § 3, 3-7-07) 
Sec. 126-224. - Applicable to businesses, agents and employees. 
    Neither the owners, their agents or employees of any business nor residents of units abutting said designated parking zone shall be considered a customer unless in compliance with the restrictions contained herein. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-12, § 4, 3-7-07) 
Sec. 126-225. - Notice to public. 
    Parking signs for customers shall be posted along said route to be effective between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-12, § 5, 3-7-07) 
Sec. 126-226. - Penalties. 
    All penalties for violators shall be subject to the provisions contained in sections 126-156-126-188 of this Code. Violators shall also be subject to Texas Local Government Code § 431.001, Texas Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(2), Texas Penal Code, and any other applicable laws. A violator shall also be subject to the maximum penalties allowed by law for failing to appear in court when charged with an offense as described herein. 
(Ord. No. O-2007-12, § 6, 3-7-07) 
Secs. 126-227-126-235. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TRUCK ROUTE FOR LARGE, OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2014-51, §§ 1.00-5.00, adopted Nov. 3, 2014, repealed, in part, the former Art. VI, §§ 126-236-126-238, 126-240, and enacted a new Art. VI as set out herein. The former article pertained to truck route and junked vehicles and derived from Ord. No. O-2006-09, §§ 1.00-4.00, adopted 2-7-06. For purposes of classification, regulations pertaining to junked vehicles have been moved to Art. VIII, at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 126-236. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Commercial motor vehicle. Every vehicle and motor vehicle which singularly or in combination has either an overall height in excess of 120 inches, or an overall length in excess of 140 inches, or an overall width in excess of 80 inches. 
    Motor vehicle. Every vehicle, as herein defined, which is self-propelled by an engine or motor. Without limitations, and by way of example only, this motor vehicle includes truck-tractors, trailers, semi-trailers, and house-trailers as the latter and defined herein below. 
    Overweight truck route. A designated section of certain city owned streets, as designated herein, over and along which overweight trucks and commercial motor vehicles may operate within the city limits of the City of Pharr, with a permit and not exceeding 125,000 pounds. 
    Semi-trailer. Every vehicle of the trailer type so designated or used in conjunction with a motor vehicle that some part of its own weight and that of its own load rests upon or is carried by another motor vehicle. 
    Street. Any public right-of-way within the corporate limits of the City of Pharr being primarily for accommodating vehicular traffic, including any unpaved portions thereof. 
    Trailer. Every vehicle without motive power designed or used for carrying property or passengers wholly on its own structure and to be drawn by a motor vehicle. 
    Truck. Any and all vehicles and motor vehicles whose body weight or whose rated or licensed combined body and load weight exceeds 10,000 pounds, whether such vehicle constitutes a single unit or is composed of two or more vehicles coupled together. 
    Truck-tractors. Every motor vehicle designed or used primarily for drawing other vehicles, and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the weight of the vehicle and load so drawn, except that the term includes a motor vehicle that is otherwise a truck-tractor, that is engaged with a semi-trailer in the transportation of automobiles or boats, and that transports motor vehicles or boats on part of the truck-tractor. 
    Vehicle. Every mechanical device, in, upon or by which any person or property may be transported or drawn upon a public highway, which may be required to be registered or licensed under the laws of this state including motor vehicles, but excepting devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 1.00, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-237. - Weight limits. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article or as provided by law, a motor vehicle, trailer, semi-trailer, or combination thereof, may not be operated upon a city street if such vehicle or combination has: 
(1)  An overall gross weight of 80,000 pounds for a commercial or industrial road; or 
(2)  An overall gross weight of 10,000 pounds for a residential road. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 2.00, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-238. - Parking of wide vehicles in residential zones. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle, including, but not limited to, a house trailer or mobile unit, having a width at its widest part in excess of 80 inches, to park or station such vehicle on a street of the city which is in or adjacent to any property owned as residential property under the city's zoning ordinance, subject however to the exception that such vehicles may be parked temporarily for loading or unloading which must be completed within a reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 2.01, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-239. - Presumption that owner of vehicle illegally parked the vehicle. 
    In any prosecution charging a violation of any ordinance or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such ordinance or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the during [duration] which, such violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 2.02, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-240. - Fees for impoundment of vehicles. 
    The owner of any vehicle impounded under the provisions of this article shall pay, in addition to any other penalty which may be charged against him or her for any violation of this article, the cost of impounding or moving said vehicle, which such cost shall not exceed the maximum rate allowable under the current wrecker ordinance of the City of Pharr Code for the type of service provided. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 2.03, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-241. - Prohibited vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated, upon a city street, any vehicle which has lugs, studs, cleats, ridges, beads or any other protuberance of metal which project more than one-fourth-inch beyond the tread or traction surface of such vehicle's tires or tracks, unless bands, wooden blocks, skids, or other devices are provided which are sufficient to protect the street from damage by reason thereof. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 2.04, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-242. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any vehicles operated by the city, or a private operator under contract with the city, as part of its municipal transit system; 
(2)  Any vehicle operated by the city, or a private contractor under contract with the city, while engaging in street maintenance, construction, or related activities; 
(3)  Any vehicle owned by a public utility while necessarily in use in the construction, installation, or repair of any public utility facility; 
(4)  Emergency vehicles of the city, or bona fide emergency vehicles from another entity; 
(5)  School buses under the jurisdiction of any public or private school within the corporate limits of the City of Pharr. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 3.00, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-243. - Permits-Overweight vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit the operation of any vehicle upon a city street which has a weight in excess of the limits set forth herein, without having first obtaining a permit thereof from the city. Any permit issued for overweight loads shall never exceed 125,000 pounds. 
    Such application for a permit shall: 
(1)  State the registered owner of the vehicle; 
(2)  Describe the vehicle, driver, and provide a copy of proof of vehicle insurance; 
(3)  Give the weight of the vehicle and the weight of the total load; 
(4)  Give the date on which vehicle will be used on city streets; 
(5)  Be dated by the applicant; and 
(6)  Give route of travel within the city. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 4.00, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-244. - Single trip permit. 
    The City of Pharr may issue a single trip permit to allow the operation of an overweight motor vehicle on city roads within the City of Pharr. The permit issued will be from destination to destination, will not exceed a 24-hour period and shall designate the city roads upon which the permitted vehicle may operate. The request for a permit to exceed the maximum vehicle weight limit must be made at least 24 hours in advance. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 4.01, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-245. - Liability. 
    Any person operating or causing to be operated a vehicle that exceeds the weight limitations set forth, with or without a permit, shall be liable to the City of Pharr for any damages to city's streets, bridges, or culverts caused by such overweight vehicles. Acceptance of a permit provided for in this article shall be conclusive evidence that the person to whom such permit is issued agrees to make good and pay all such damages upon demand therefor made by the City of Pharr. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 4.02, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-246. - Operation of overweight vehicles only on designated roads. 
    The transportation of overweight vehicles and loads authorized by this article shall be undertaken only on city roads designated within the overweight corridor, as identified in exhibit A. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 4.03, 11-3-14) 
Editor's note- Exhibit A is not set out herein, but is on file with the city. 
Sec. 126-247. - Operation only according to terms of permit. 
    The transportation of overweight vehicles and loads in violation of the terms of an overweight permit shall render the permit void except as to the permit holder's liability and indemnification. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 4.04, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-248. - Possession of permit during operation. 
    The issued permit must be in the possession of those utilizing the permit during all periods of operation. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 4.05, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-249. - Permit fees. 
Gross Weight of Vehicle Permit Fee 80,000 lbs. - 100,000 lbs. Free 100,001 lbs. - 125,000 lbs. Free  
    An administrative fee of $0.00 shall be paid by each applicant at the time of filing a permit application to cover the cost of processing the application. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 4.06, 11-3-14) 
Sec. 126-250. - Enforcement; penalty. 
    Whenever any vehicle is operated or movement made in violation of a permit issued in accordance with this article, the person to whom such permit was granted, or the driver of such vehicle, is guilty of such violation and either, but not both, persons may be prosecuted for such violation as stated herein. Any person, firm or corporation convicted of such violation shall be guilty of a petty offense and shall be fined as follows: 
(1)  First offense: Not more than $500.00. 
(2)  Second offense: Not less than $500.00 or more than $750.00. 
(3)  Third offense: Not less than $750.00 or more than $1,000.00 (no more permits shall be issued). 
    Whenever a vehicle is subject to a permit by this article and [any person] operates an overweight vehicle without first obtaining such permit shall be charged with a violation of this article and may be prosecuted as such. Any person who pleads not guilty for said violation shall be presented in court. Any person convicted of violating this article shall be fined not less than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. O-2014-51, § 5.00, 11-3-14) 
Secs. 126-251-126-265. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PARADES AND PROCESSIONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, ch. 70; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 86; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 114; zoning, app. A. 

Sec. 126-266. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any number of persons, any delegation or association of persons or for any company, circus or group to parade or assemble on the streets or public grounds within the city without first having obtained a written permit from the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 33-118) 
Sec. 126-267. - Exceptions to article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to movements of the military forces of the United States, or of the state, nor to a funeral procession being held as a part of the burial services of a human body. 
(Code 1976, § 33-119) 
Sec. 126-268. - Route, times permitted. 
    Whenever any permit is granted by the city commission under the provisions of this article, it shall designate the streets, avenues, alleys and thoroughfares over which the parade is privileged to travel and the time that the parade shall be held and completed, and if for an assembly, the place of assembly and time it shall be held and completed. 
(Code 1976, § 33-120) 
Sec. 126-269. - Driving through procession prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to drive between vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized parade procession while such vehicles are in motion, provided that such vehicles are conspicuously so designated. This section shall not apply to intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic control signals or police officers. 
(Code 1976, § 33-121) 
Sec. 126-270. - Duty of drivers in a procession. 
    Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the righthand edge of the roadway as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe. 
(Code 1976, § 33-122) 
Sec. 126-271. - Funeral processions to be identified. 
    A funeral composed of a procession of vehicles shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle of a pennant or other identifying insignia or by such other method as may be determined and designated by the traffic division. 
(Code 1976, § 33-123) 
Secs. 126-272-126-295. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - JUNKED MOTOR VEHICLES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2006-09, §§ 1.00, 3.00-3.06, 4.00, adopted Feb. 7, 2006, has been included herein as superseding former Art. VIII, §§ 126-296-126-314, which derived from Code 1976, §§ 17-61-17-79. Ord. No. O-2006-09, previously codified, in part, as Art. VI, §§ 126-236, 126-239 and 126-240, has been renumbered herein as Art. VIII, §§ 126-296-126-304, at the editor's discretion. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate junked vehicles, nuisance and set out procedures, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 683, subch. E. 

Sec. 126-296. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Junked vehicle. A vehicle that is self-propelled and inoperable and does not have lawfully attached to it, an unexpired license plate; or a valid motor vehicle inspection certificate; is wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled, or discarded; or has remained inoperable for more than 45 consecutive days. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-09, § 1.00, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 126-297. - Public nuisance. 
    A junked vehicle, including a part of a junked vehicle that is visible from a public place or public right-of-way: 
(1)  Is detrimental to the safety and welfare of the public; 
(2)  Tends to reduce the value of private property; 
(3)  Invites vandalism; 
(4)  Creates a fire hazard; 
(5)  Is an unattractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and safety of minors; 
(6)  Produces urban blight adverse to the maintenance and continuing development of the City of Pharr; and 
(7)  Is a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-09, § 3.00, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 126-298. - Penalty for maintaining a public nuisance. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if the person maintains a public nuisance described by section 126-297; 
(b)  An offense under this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $200.00; 
(c)  The court shall order abatement and removal of the nuisance on conviction; 
(d)  See section 126-304, enforcement and penalty provision. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-09, § 3.01, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 126-299. - Authority to abate nuisance; procedures. 
(a)  The City of Pharr has adopted procedures that conform to V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 683, subch. E for the abatement and removal from private or public property or a public right-of-way of a junked vehicle or part of a junked vehicle as a public nuisance. 
(b)  These procedures are as follows: 
(1)  Prohibit a vehicle from being reconstructed or made operable after removal; 
(2)  Require a public hearing before removal of the public nuisance; and 
(3)  Require that notice identifying the vehicle or part of the vehicle be given to the department not later than the fifth day after the date of removal; 
(c)  The Pharr Municipal Court shall issue necessary orders to enforce the procedures. 
(d)  Procedures for abatement and removal of a public nuisance must be administered by regularly salaried, full-time employees of the City of Pharr, except that any authorized person may remove the nuisance. 
(e)  A person authorized to administer the procedures may enter private property to examine a public nuisance, to obtain information to identify the nuisance, and to remove or direct the removal of the nuisance. 
(f)  On receipt of notice of removal under subsection (b)(3), the department shall immediately cancel the certificate of title issued for the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-09, § 3.02, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 126-300. - Notice. 
(a)  The procedures for the abatement and removal of a public nuisance under this article must provide not less than ten days' notice of the nature of the nuisance and must be sent by certified mail with a five-day return requested to: 
(1)  The last known registered owner of the nuisance; 
(2)  Each lien holder of record of the nuisance; and 
(3)  The owner or occupant of: 
a.  The property on which the nuisance is located; or 
b.  If the nuisance is located on a public right-of-way, the property adjacent to the right-of-way. 
(b)  The notice must state that: 
(1)  The nuisance must be abated and removed not later than the tenth day after the date on which the notice was mailed; and 
(2)  Any request for a hearing must be made before the ten-day period expires. 
a.  If the post office address of the last known registered owner of the nuisance is unknown, notice may be placed on the nuisance, or if the owner is located, hand delivered. 
(c)  If notice is returned undelivered, action to abate the nuisance shall be continued to a date not earlier than the 11th day after the date of return. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-09, § 3.03, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 126-301. - Hearing. 
(a)  The chief of police, or his designee, shall be the official designated by the City of Pharr governing body to conduct hearings under the procedures adopted under this article. 
(b)  If a hearing is requested, by a person for whom notice is required under section 126-300(a)(3), the hearing shall be held not earlier than the 11th day after the date of the service of notice. 
(c)  At the hearing, the junked motor vehicle is presumed unless demonstrated otherwise by the owner, to be inoperable. 
(d)  If the information is available at the location of the nuisance, a resolution or order requiring removal of the nuisance must include the vehicle's: 
(1)  Description; 
(2)  Vehicle identification number; and 
(3)  License plate number. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-09, § 3.04, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 126-302. - Inapplicability. 
(a)  Procedures adopted under section 126-299 may not apply to a vehicle or vehicle part: 
(1)  That is completely enclosed in a building in a lawful manner and is not visible from the street or other public or private property. 
(2)  That is stored or parked in a lawful manner on private property in connection with the business or a licensed vehicle dealer or junkyard, or that is an antique or special interest vehicle stored by a motor vehicle collector on the collector's property, if the vehicle or part of the outdoor storage area, if any are: 
a.  Maintained in an orderly manner; 
b.  Not a health hazard; and 
c.  Screened from ordinary public view by appropriate means, including a fence, rapidly growing trees, or shrubbery. 
(b)  In this section: 
(1)  "Antique vehicle" means a passenger car or truck that is at least 35 years old. 
(2)  "Motor vehicle collector" means a person who: 
a.  Owns one or more antique or special interest vehicles; and 
b.  Acquires, collects, or disposes of an antique or special interest vehicle or part of an antique or special interest vehicle for personal use to restore and preserve an antique or special vehicle for historic interest. 
(3)  "Special interest vehicle" means a motor vehicle of any age that has not been changed from original manufacturer's specifications and, because of its historic interest, is being preserved by a hobbyist. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-09, § 3.05, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 126-303. - Junked vehicle disposal. 
(a)  A junked vehicle, including a part of a junked vehicle, may be removed to a scrap yard, a motor vehicle demolisher, or a suitable site operated by the City of Pharr. 
(b)  The City of Pharr may operate a disposal site if its governing body determines that commercial disposition of junked vehicles is not available or is inadequate. The City of Pharr may: 
(1)  Finally dispose of a junked vehicle or vehicle part; or 
(2)  Transfer it to another disposal site if the disposal is scrap or salvage only. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-09, § 3.06, 2-7-06) 
Sec. 126-304. - Enforcement; penalty. 
    The chief of police of the City of Pharr, or his designee, shall be the principle agent for enforcement of this article, subject however, to the exception that the city manager, in his discretion, may temporarily appoint another person to enforce this article. A person commits an offense if the person maintains a public nuisance described by section 126-297, and upon conviction, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $200.00. The municipal court shall order abatement and removal of the nuisance on conviction. It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under this article that the person was excused from compliance herewith because he was acting under the provisions set forth in section 126-302 of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-2006-09, § 4.00, 2-7-06) 
Secs. 126-305-126-350. - Reserved.
